      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eIf \\( {\\frac {x}{a}}\\sin \\theta +{\\frac {y}{b}}\\cos \\theta \u003d1\\, \\) and \\( {\\frac {x}{a}}\\cos \\theta -{\\frac {y}{b}}\\sin \\theta \u003d1\\, \\) show that \\( {\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}\u003d2\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven \\( {\\frac {x}{a}}\\sin \\theta +{\\frac {y}{b}}\\cos \\theta \u003d1\\, \\) and \\( {\\frac {x}{a}}\\cos \\theta -{\\frac {y}{b}}\\sin \\theta \u003d1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSquaring and adding the two equations,we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( [{\\frac {x}{a}}\\sin \\theta +{\\frac {y}{b}}\\cos \\theta ]^{2}+[{\\frac {x}{a}}\\cos \\theta -{\\frac {y}{b}}\\sin \\theta ]^{2}\u003d1+1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {x^{2}\\sin ^{2}\\theta }{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {y^{2}\\cos ^{2}\\theta }{b^{2}}}+{\\frac {2xy\\cos \\theta \\sin \\theta }{ab}}+{\\frac {x^{2}\\cos ^{2}\\theta }{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {y^{2}\\sin ^{2}\\theta }{b^{2}}}-{\\frac {2xy\\cos \\theta \\sin \\theta }{ab}}\u003d2\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimplifying \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}[\\cos ^{2}\\theta +\\sin ^{2}\\theta ]+{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}[\\cos ^{2}\\theta +\\sin ^{2}\\theta ]\u003d2\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( ({\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{2}}})(\\cos ^{2}\\theta +\\sin ^{2}\\theta )\u003d2\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( ({\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{2}}})(1)\u003d2\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore, \\( {\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}\u003d2\\, \\) .       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDerive the Quotient Rule formula.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRecall the Product Rule: \\( {\\frac {d}{dx}}(ab)\u003dab^{\\prime }+a^{\\prime }b\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Product Rule can be applied to a quotient by noting that \\( {\\frac {a}{b}}\u003dab^{{-1}}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso note that the Power Rule and Chain Rule must be applied when taking \\( (b^{{-1}})^{\\prime }\\, \\) . Therefore, \u003c/p\u003e     \\( {\\frac {d}{dx}}\\left({\\frac {a}{b}}\\right)\\, \\)   \\( \u003d{\\frac {d}{dx}}\\left(ab^{{-1}}\\right)\\, \\)      \\( \u003da(b^{{-1}})^{\\prime }+a^{\\prime }b^{{-1}}\\, \\)      \\( \u003da(-b^{{-2}}b^{\\prime })+a^{\\prime }b^{{-1}}\\, \\)      \\( \u003d{\\frac {-ab^{\\prime }}{b^{2}}}+{\\frac {a^{\\prime }}{b}}\\, \\)      \\( \u003d{\\frac {-ab^{\\prime }}{b^{2}}}+{\\frac {a^{\\prime }}{b}}\\cdot {\\frac {b}{b}}\\, \\)      \\( \u003d{\\frac {-ab^{\\prime }}{b^{2}}}+{\\frac {ba^{\\prime }}{b^{2}}}\\, \\)      \\( \u003d{\\frac {ba^{\\prime }-ab^{\\prime }}{b^{2}}}\\, \\)   \n\u003cp\u003ewhich is the correct Quotient Rule formula. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn practice, it is usually easier to memorize just the Product Rule and apply it in both cases as here, rather than memorize two formulas.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",
      "uuid": "01a6e717-bc65-498c-84a4-ca112c92bc88",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the derivative of \\( y\\, \\) with respect to \\( x\\, \\) : \\( xy\u003dx^{y}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e For this problem, we can not solve for \\( y\\, \\) . However, we can take the derivative of the function without changing the form by the technique of \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eimplicit differentiation\u003c/a\u003e. Remember that \\( y\\, \\) is a function of \\( x\\, \\) so its derivative is \\( y\u0027(x)\\, \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The derivative of the right side comes from the formula we find, in the section for logarithmic differentiation, for the derivative of \\( g(x)^{{h(x)}}\\, \\) \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eCalc2.2\u003c/a\u003e which is \\( g^{h}(h\u0027\\ln g+{\\frac {h}{g}}g\u0027)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y\u0027x+y\u003dx^{y}(y\u0027\\ln x+{\\frac {y}{x}})\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now the first step in solving for the derivative, \\( y\u0027\\, \\) , is to get all terms involving \\( y\u0027\\, \\) on one side and all other terms on the other side \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y\u0027(x-x^{y}\\ln x)\u003dx^{y}{\\frac {y}{x}}-y\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now divide to solve for \\( y\u0027\\, \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y\u0027\u003d{\\frac {y(x^{{y-1}}-1)}{x-x^{y}\\ln x}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the derivative of \\( f(x)\\, \\) with respect to \\( x\\, \\) : \\( f(x)\u003d4^{{\\sin x}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Most calculus books will give a formula for this type of problem. For any problem where you have a constant base and an exponent that is a function of \\( x\\, \\) , the derivative can be done by memorization. If \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f(x)\u003da^{{b(x)}}\\, \\) where \\( a\\, \\) is a constant and \\( b(x)\\, \\) is some function of \\( x\\, \\) , the derivative is given by \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(x)\u003da^{{b(x)}}\\ln(a)b\u0027(x)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e To truly understand the problem though, it is better to know where the formula comes from. For this problem, take the logarithm of both sides. Then using the laws of logarithms, we know that \\( \\ln c^{d}\u003dd\\ln c\\, \\) . Thus, for this problem, \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\ln f(x)\u003d\\sin x\\ln 4\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This puts it in a form we can easily integrate as it is simply \\( \\sin x\\, \\) multiplied by a constant on the right. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {1}{f(x)}}f\u0027(x)\u003d\\cos x\\ln 4\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now solving for \\( f\u0027(x)\\, \\) and substituting in our original value of \\( f(x)\\, \\) we get \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(x)\u003d4^{{\\sin x}}\\cos x\\ln 4\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the derivative of \\( f(x)\\, \\) with respect to \\( x\\, \\) : \\( f(x)\u003dx^{x}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e We have derivative formulas for functions such as \\( e^{x}\\, \\) and \\( x^{3}\\, \\) but not for a function involving \\( x\\, \\) both in the base and the exponent. However, any problem with \\( x\\, \\) of some form in the base and exponent can be solved by \u003cb\u003elogarithmic differentiation\u003c/b\u003e. The process is simple. Take the logarithm of both sides and the exponent drops down by the laws of logarithms. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\ln f(x)\u003dx\\ln x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This is a function we can derive \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {1}{f(x)}}f\u0027(x)\u003d\\ln x+x{\\frac {1}{x}}\u003d\\ln x+1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now solve for \\( f\u0027(x)\\, \\) and then replace \\( f(x)\\, \\) with its given value, \\( x^{x}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(x)\u003df(x)(\\ln x+1)\u003dx^{x}(\\ln x+1)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",
      "uuid": "f787ae39-6de7-47b5-a4af-0c611e3b2e5f",
      "contentType": "practiceProblem",
      "creatorUserId": "11481431651082296168",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the derivative of \\( f(x)\\, \\) with respect to \\( x\\, \\) : \\( f(x)\u003d\\int _{{0}}^{{x}}e^{t}\\,dt\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Here we have an integral as our function. To take the derivative of an integral, we use the Second Fundamental Theorem of Calculus. It says that the derivative of an integral from a constant to \\( x\\, \\) of a function \\( f(t)\\, \\) is simply \\( f(x)\\, \\) . This makes complete sense because the integral and derivative functions are inverses of each other. Taking an integral first and then taking the derivative should give us the same thing we started with. And, the interval \\( [a,x]\\, \\) , where \\( a\\, \\) is just some constant, is an arbitrary interval based on the value of the variable \\( x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(x)\u003de^{x}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

To find the answer to this problem, find the derivative of \\( f(x) \\) and plug in \\( x\u003d3 \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(x)\u003d6\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The derivative of this function is constant, it is always 6.       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the slope of the tangent line to the graph \\( f(x)\u003dx^{2} \\) when \\( x\u003d0,1,2,3,4,5,6 \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This problem is just like past problems except that we are finding the slope of the tangent line at multiple points. First, find the derivative of \\( f(x) \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(x)\u003d2x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Plugging in our values, we get \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(0)\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(1)\u003d2\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(2)\u003d4\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(3)\u003d6\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(4)\u003d8\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(5)\u003d10\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(6)\u003d12\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Our original graph is that of a parabola. One half of a parabola is increasing. Notice that it not only increases but increases at an increasing rate. You can see that by looking at the graph and now we can see that by looking at the derivative because the derivative gives us the slope of the tangent line or rate of change. Since the derivative is increasing, this indicates that the rate of change is increasing. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the slope of the tangent line to the graph \\( x^{2}+y^{2}\u003d9 \\) at the point \\( (0,-3) \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Here, use \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eimplicit differentiation\u003c/a\u003e to find \\( y\u0027 \\) . Then plug in our point to find the slope of the tangent line at that specific point. By taking the derivative of both sides we get \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( 2x+2yy\u0027\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Some students are tempted to plug in the point before taking the derivative. However, \\( x \\) , for example, is a variable and \\( 0 \\) is a constant. Thus, plugging in \\( 0 \\) before taking the derivative will give us a totally different derivative. After taking the derivative, it is okay to plug in the point. We have two options. We can solve for \\( y\u0027 \\) and then plug in our point or we can plug our point and then solve for \\( y\u0027 \\) . Usually, it is simpler to simply plug in the point. Here, this gives \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( 0+2(-3)y\u0027\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e or \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y\u0027\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e So, if we were to draw the tangent line to this graph, a circle, we would get a horizontal line through the point \\( (0,-3) \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the absolute minimum and maximum on \\( [-1,5] \\) of the function \\( f(x)\u003d(1-x)e^{x} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e It is known that the only place an absolute minimum or maximum can occur on an interval is at one of the endpoints of the interval or at a \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003ecritical point\u003c/a\u003e inside the interval. A critical point is a point where the function is defined and its derivative is either 0 or undefined. So start by finding the derivative. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(x)\u003d-e^{x}+(1-x)e^{x}\u003d-xe^{x}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This derivative is defined everywhere so the only possible critical numbers will be where the derivative is equal to 0. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( -xe^{x}\u003d0 \\) can only be true if \\( x\u003d0 \\) or \\( e^{x}\u003d0 \\) but \\( e^{x} \\) is always positive so it is never equal to \\( 0 \\) . Thus the only critical point comes when \\( x\u003d0 \\) . As stated before, the absolute max and min can only occur at an endpoint or at a critical number. So our only choices for \\( x \\) here are \\( -1 \\) , \\( 0 \\) , or \\( 5 \\) . If these are our only choices, our easiest plan is to just plug in the three values and see which gives the highest value and which gives the lowest value. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f(-1)\u003d{\\frac {2}{e}}\\,\u0026lt;1 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f(0)\u003d1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f(5)\u003d-4e^{5}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, the absolute minimum comes at the point \\( (5,-4e^{5}) \\) and the absolute maximum comes at the point \\( (0,1) \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the absolute minimum and maximum on \\( \\left[-{\\frac {\\pi }{2}},{\\frac {\\pi }{2}}\\right] \\) of the function \\( f(x)\u003d\\sin(x^{2}) \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Again, any absolute minimum or maximum of this function on the indicated interval can only occur at a critical point of the function or at one of the endpoints of the interval. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(x)\u003d(2x)\\cos(x^{2})\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This derivative is never undefined. It is equal to 0 at infinitely many values of \\( x \\) since the \\( \\cos u \\) function is periodic but on our given interval, it is equal to \\( 0 \\) only at a finite number of points. This derivative is equal to \\( 0 \\) either when \\( x\u003d0 \\) or when \\( \\cos(x^{2})\u003d0 \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The cosine function is equal to \\( 0 \\) at any point in the set \\( \\{...,-{\\frac {3\\pi }{2}},-{\\frac {\\pi }{2}},{\\frac {\\pi }{2}},{\\frac {3\\pi }{2}},...\\} \\) . So, the derivative will be equal to \\( 0 \\) whenever \\( x^{2} \\) is equal to one of these values. The only values of \\( x \\) inside of our interval for which this is true are \\( -{\\sqrt {{\\frac {\\pi }{2}}}} \\) and \\( {\\sqrt {{\\frac {\\pi }{2}}}} \\) . Thus, we have five values as candidates for our absolute max and the same five are candidates for our absolute min. Plug in all five values into the original function. The highest will be our absolute max and the lowest will be our absolute min. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f(-{\\frac {\\pi }{2}})\u003d\\sin {\\frac {\\pi ^{2}}{4}}\\approx 0.624\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f(-{\\sqrt {{\\frac {\\pi }{2}}}})\u003d1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f(0)\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f({\\sqrt {{\\frac {\\pi }{2}}}})\u003d1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f({\\frac {\\pi }{2}})\u003d\\sin {\\frac {\\pi ^{2}}{4}}\\approx 0.624\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, we have an absolute minimum on the interval at the point \\( (0,0) \\) and an absolute maximum on the interval at two points, both of which have the same height, \\( \\left(-{\\sqrt {{\\frac {\\pi }{2}}}},1\\right) \\) and \\( \\left({\\sqrt {{\\frac {\\pi }{2}}}},1\\right) \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind all local minimums and maximums of the function \\( f(x)\u003dx^{2} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Local minimums and maximums may occur never, once, or many times depending on the function. However, they occur only at critical points, that is only at points where the function is defined and the derivative is 0 or undefined. The derivative of our function is \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(x)\u003d2x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This derivative is always defined and is equal to \\( 0 \\) only when \\( x\u003d0 \\) . So our only critical point is \\( x\u003d0 \\) . To decide if this is a local maximum or minimum let us look at the behavior of the derivative to the left and to the right of it. Since this is the only point where the derivative is ever equal to \\( 0 \\) it must be true that to the left of \\( x\u003d0 \\) the derivative is always negative or always positive and the same can be said to the right of \\( x\u003d0 \\) . If the derivative is positive that tells us that the function is increasing in that region and if the derivative is negative that tells us that the function is decreasing in that region. This information will tell us if the critical point is a local max, a local min, or neither. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Since the behavior is the same for any point left of \\( x\u003d0 \\) and also always the same for any point right of \\( x\u003d0 \\) , just pick one point on each side and find the value of the derivative at that x-value. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(-1)\u003d-2\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(1)\u003d2\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Since the derivative to the left of \\( x\u003d0 \\) is negative, that tells us that the function is decreasing up to that point and since the derivative is positive to the right, we know the function is increasing on the interval \\( (0,\\infty ) \\) . If the function goes from decreasing to increasing, this must be a local minimum at the point \\( (0,0) \\) which is easily verified by looking at a graph. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",
      "uuid": "bd0e5914-2ddf-419c-94cb-9454d90bfda9",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind all local minimums and maximums of the function \\( f(x)\u003d{\\frac {x^{2}-1}{x}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e All local minimums and maximums will be at critical points. A critical point is a point where the function is defined and the derivative is either \\( 0 \\) or undefined. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(x)\u003d{\\frac {x(2x)-1(x^{2}-1)}{x^{2}}}\u003d{\\frac {x^{2}+1}{x^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e A fraction is equal to \\( 0 \\) only when the numerator is equal to \\( 0 \\) . However, \\( x^{2}+1 \\) is always positive so the derivative is never equal to \\( 0 \\) . It is undefined when \\( x\u003d0 \\) but so is the original function. Therefore there are no critical points and no local minimums or maximums. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eIf a farmer wants to make a rectangular pen along a river, so that only 3 sides need to be fenced in, what is the largest area he can fence with 100 feet of fence? \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This problem is equivalent to asking us to find the absolute max of the area on an interval, though the interval is not given explicitly. We know that an absolute max can only occur at a critical point or at the endpoint of an interval. The information in this problem gives us one equation relating the length and width of this rectangle. The total length of fence must be 100 feet. Since we have three sides, two of which are equal, we have \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( 100\u003d2x+y\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e If the total fence to be used is 100 feet, it makes sense that \\( 0\\leq x\\leq 50 \\) . Thus, our interval for the problem is \\( [0,50] \\) . Now, the problem asks us to maximize the area. The derivative of a function can help us find the maximum, if one exists, so we need an equation for the area of this rectangle. That is simply \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( A\u003dxy\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This is all the information we need to solve this problem. Take the first equation and solve it for \\( y \\) . We can then plug this into our second equation so that the area is in terms of only one variable. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( A\u003dx(100-2x)\u003d100x-2x^{2}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Remember, a critical point is a point where the original function is defined and the derivate is \\( 0 \\) or undefined. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( A\u0027\u003d100-4x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This derivative is always defined so no critical points will be found that way. The derivative is equal to \\( 0 \\) when \\( x\u003d25 \\) so we have one critical point. Thus are absolute maximum area will be found at \\( x\u003d0 \\) , \\( x\u003d25 \\) , or \\( x\u003d50 \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( A(0)\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( A(25)\u003d1250\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( A(50)\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, the greatest area the fence can enclose in the prescribed manner is 1250 square feet when the side adjacent to the river is 50 feet long and the side perpendicular is 25 feet long. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the local minimums and maximums of the function \\( f(x)\u003d{\\sqrt {x}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e To find the local minimums and maximums of a function, find the critical points by finding the derivative and finding the points where it is equal to 0 or undefined. If the original function is defined at these points, then these are critical points. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027(x)\u003d{\\frac {1}{2{\\sqrt {x}}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This function is never equal to 0 as the numerator is never equal to 0. It is undefined at \\( x\u003d0 \\) . This is our only critical point. However, the square root function is only defined for nonnegative real numbers so \\( f(x) \\) is not defined to the left of \\( x\u003d0 \\) . Thus, it can not have a local minimum or maximum at \\( x\u003d0 \\) . \\( x\u003d0 \\) does give us the lowest point on the entire square root function as it starts at \\( 0 \\) and increases thereafter. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",
      "uuid": "ce6ddb31-0126-47be-a5bb-c7e1fbbc3180",

    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eA clock face has a 12 inch diameter, a 5.5-inch second hand, a 5 inch minute hand and a 3 inch hour hand. When it is exactly 3:30, calculate the rate at which the distance between the tip of any one of these hands and the 9 o\u0027clock position is changing.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e First consider the distance between the tip of the second hand and the 9 o\u0027clock position; let us call this \\( r \\) . Further, let \\( \\theta \\) be the angle between the 9 o\u0027clock position and the second hand, and let \\( t \\) be the time, in seconds. Then we have \\( {\\frac {d\\theta }{dt}}\u003d{\\frac {2\\pi \\ {{\\rm {radians}}}}{60\\ {{\\rm {seconds}}}}}\u003d{\\frac {\\pi }{30}}{{\\rm {rad/sec}}} \\) . If we use the Law of Cosines, we can get a formula for \\( r \\) in terms of \\( \\theta \\) . That is, \\( r^{2}\u003d6^{2}+5.5^{2}-2\\cdot 6\\cdot 5.5\\cos \\theta \\) . (Draw a picture to help visualize this if you need to. The two smaller legs of the triangle will always be 6 and 5.5 inches, for the 9 o\u0027clock position and second-hand tip, respectively. As \\( \\theta \\) changes, so does \\( r \\) .) Using implicit differentiation, we get \\( {\\frac {dr}{d\\theta }}\u003d{\\frac {6\\cdot 5.5\\sin \\theta }{r}} \\) . Thus, the desired related rate is calculated using the chain rule: \\( {\\frac {dr}{dt}}\u003d{\\frac {dr}{d\\theta }}\\cdot {\\frac {d\\theta }{dt}}\u003d{\\frac {11\\pi \\sin \\theta }{10r}} \\) . At 3:30, we have \\( \\theta \u003d{\\frac {\\pi }{2}} \\) and \\( r\u003d{\\sqrt {6^{2}+5.5^{2}}}\\approx 8.1394 \\) . Then \\( {\\frac {dr}{dt}}\\approx 1.39\\,{{\\rm {in/sec}}} \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe desired rate for the minute and hour hands is calculated in a nearly identical fashion. For the minute hand, we have \\( {\\frac {d\\theta }{dt}}\u003d{\\frac {2\\pi \\ {{\\rm {radians}}}}{3600\\ {{\\rm {seconds}}}}}\u003d{\\frac {\\pi }{1800}}{{\\rm {rad/sec}}} \\) and \\( {\\frac {dr}{d\\theta }}\u003d{\\frac {6\\cdot 5\\sin \\theta }{r}} \\) , so \\( {\\frac {dr}{dt}}\u003d{\\frac {\\pi \\sin \\theta }{60r}} \\) . At 3:30, \\( \\theta \u003d-{\\frac {\\pi }{2}} \\) and \\( r\u003d{\\sqrt {6^{2}+5^{2}}}\\approx 7.8102 \\) , so \\( {\\frac {dr}{dt}}\\approx -0.0067\\,{{\\rm {in/sec}}} \\) , or \\( \\approx -0.4022\\,{{\\rm {in/min}}} \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor the hour hand, we get \\( {\\frac {d\\theta }{dt}}\u003d{\\frac {\\pi }{21600}}{{\\rm {rad/sec}}} \\) and \\( {\\frac {dr}{d\\theta }}\u003d{\\frac {6\\cdot 3\\sin \\theta }{r}} \\) . Then \\( {\\frac {dr}{dt}}\u003d{\\frac {\\pi \\sin \\theta }{1200r}} \\) . At 3:30, if we assume that \\( \\theta \u003d\\pi \\) , we see that this rate is 0. This is rather intuitional, as we may think of this as the peak in midair when we throw a ball up into the air; at this peak, the ball\u0027s velocity is 0. We can get a bit fancier though, as at 3:30 we could assume that the hour hand is halfway between the 3 and 4 o\u0027clock positions. That is, at 3:30, \\( \\theta \u003d-{\\frac {11\\pi }{12}} \\) , so \\( r\u003d{\\sqrt {6^{2}+3^{2}-2\\cdot 6\\cdot 3\\cos(-11\\pi /12)}}\\approx 8.9316 \\) . Then, \\( {\\frac {dr}{dt}}\\approx -7.5864e-4\\,{{\\rm {in/sec}}} \\) , or \\( \\approx -0.0046\\,{{\\rm {in/min}}} \\) , or \\( \\approx -0.2731\\,{{\\rm {in/hr}}} \\) . \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eA spherical container of \\( r \\) meters is being filled with a liquid at a rate of \\( \\rho \\,{{\\rm {m}}}^{3}/{{\\rm {min}}} \\) . At what rate is the height of the liquid in the container changing with respect to time?\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( V \\) be the volume already in the container, \\( h \\) be the height of the liquid in the container and \\( t \\) be the time since some initial starting point. We are given that \\( {\\frac {dV}{dt}}\u003d\\rho \\,{{\\rm {m}}}^{3}/{{\\rm {min}}} \\) and we are asked for the related rate \\( {\\frac {dh}{dt}} \\) . The other rate needed for this problem is the rate at which the height is changing with respect to the volume, namely \\( {\\frac {dh}{dV}} \\) . In order to calculate this, we need a relation between the height and the volume of the liquid at any particular point in time.\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe will use a trick from integral calculus to get the volume in terms of the height. Let a silhouette of our container be described by the implicit equation \\( x^{2}+(y-r)^{2}\u003dr^{2} \\) , a circle of radius \\( r \\) whose bottom is on the \\( x \\) -axis. Using the slicing method for finding a volume of revolution, we get that \\( V\u003d\\int _{0}^{h}\\pi x^{2}\\,dy\u003d\\int _{0}^{h}\\pi (r^{2}-(y-r)^{2})\\,dy\u003d\\left.\\pi \\left(r^{2}y-{\\frac {1}{3}}(y-r)^{3}\\right)\\right|_{{y\u003d0}}^{h} \\) . This simplifies into the formula \\( V\u003d\\pi \\left(r^{2}h-{\\frac {1}{3}}(h-r)^{3}-{\\frac {1}{3}}r^{3}\\right) \\) . Then \\( {\\frac {dV}{dh}}\u003d\\pi \\left(r^{2}-(h-r)^{2}\\right)\u003d\\pi h(2r-h) \\) , so \\( {\\frac {dh}{dV}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{\\pi h(2r-h)}} \\) .\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThen we get the general forumla for the desired rate: \\( {\\frac {dh}{dt}}\u003d{\\frac {dh}{dV}}\\cdot {\\frac {dV}{dt}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{\\pi h(2r-h)}}\\cdot \\rho \u003d{\\frac {\\rho }{\\pi h(2r-h)}}\\,{{\\rm {m/min}}} \\) . This is a general formula which will give us the rate at which the height is changing at any given height (assumed to be between 0 and 2r). \u003c/p\u003e",

Plug \\( x^{2}+1\\, \\) back in wherever there is a \\( u\\, \\) . Also, note the absolute value bars can be dropped because \\( x^{2}+1\\, \\) is always positive. First, start out by finding a suitable \\( u\\, \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( u\u003dx^{2}+x+7\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( du\u003d(2x+1)dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Here is where you need to be careful.       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eerrodom \\( \\int \\ln {x}dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e In order to compute this integral, one must do integration by parts.\u003cbr\u003e Recall that the formula for this method is \\( \\int u\\,dv\u003duv-\\int v\\,du\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( u\\, \\) be \\( \\ln x\\, \\) and let \\( dv\\, \\) be \\( dx\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e \\( du\\, \\) is then \\( {\\frac {1}{x}}dx\\, \\) , and \\( v\\, \\) is \\( x\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Substituting all of this into the integration by parts formula, we arrive at this expression\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int {\\ln {x}\\,dx}\\ \u003dx\\ln x-\\int {(x)\\left({\\frac {1}{x}}\\right)\\,dx} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \u003dx\\ln x-x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \u003dx(\\ln x-1)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNote that this technique works for many integrals in a similar form. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eCalculus\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int e^{x}\\sin x\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e To do this integral, we will use the method of \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eintegration by parts\u003c/a\u003e which tells us \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int u\\,dv\u003duv-\\int v\\,du\\, \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e For this specific integral, the technique is to create an equation by using \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eintegration by parts\u003c/a\u003e twice and then solve for the value of the integral. The exact same integral will pop up after we do our second \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eintegration by parts\u003c/a\u003e at which time we can move it to the other side of the equation. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( u\u003d\\sin x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( du\u003d\\cos x\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( dv\u003de^{x}\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( v\u003de^{x}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e So, our integral becomes \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int e^{x}\\sin x\\,dx\u003de^{x}\\sin x-\\int e^{x}\\cos x\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Do integration by parts again with this new integral. Technically, \\( u\\, \\) , \\( du\\, \\) , \\( v\\, \\) , and \\( dv\\, \\) all are already assigned values but it is common practice to use these same variables again for this new integral. However, keep in mind that they have nothing to do with the previous \\( u\\, \\) , \\( du\\, \\) , \\( v\\, \\) , and \\( dv\\, \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( u\u003d\\cos x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( du\u003d-\\sin x\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( dv\u003de^{x}\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( v\u003de^{x}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This gives us \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int e^{x}\\sin x\\,dx\u003de^{x}\\sin x-\\left[e^{x}\\cos x+\\int e^{x}\\sin x\\,dx\\right]\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Simplifying the equation gives us \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int e^{x}\\sin x\\,dx\u003de^{x}\\sin x-e^{x}\\cos x-\\int e^{x}\\sin x\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now, we can add \\( \\int e^{x}\\sin x\\,dx\\, \\) to both sides of the equation and divide by \\( 2\\, \\) to get the value of the integral. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int e^{x}\\sin x\\,dx\u003d{\\frac {e^{x}}{2}}(\\sin x-\\cos x)+C\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int x^{4}\\sin x\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Here, we have \\( x^{4} \\) , which tells us we will need to use the method of \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eintegration by parts\u003c/a\u003e 4 times. Luckily, there is a quicker way for integrals involving powers of \\( x \\) multiplied by a function such as \\( \\cos x \\) or \\( \\sin x \\) or \\( e^{x} \\) . The method is called the tabular method. Make a chart with three columns. The first column will contain alternating +, -, +, ... starting with +. The second column will start out with \\( u\u003dx^{4} \\) and each row below will contain the derivative of the function above. Keep going until you reach 0 as a derivative. The third column contains \\( dv\u003d\\sin x \\) and every subsequent row contains the integral of the function below. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\begin{matrix}+\\ \\longrightarrow \u0026amp;x^{4}\u0026amp;\\ \u0026amp;\\sin x\\\\\\ \u0026amp;\\ \u0026amp;\\searrow \u0026amp;\\ \\\\-\\ \\longrightarrow \u0026amp;4x^{3}\u0026amp;\\ \u0026amp;-\\cos x\\\\\\ \u0026amp;\\ \u0026amp;\\searrow \u0026amp;\\ \\\\+\\ \\longrightarrow \u0026amp;12x^{2}\u0026amp;\\ \u0026amp;-\\sin x\\\\\\ \u0026amp;\\ \u0026amp;\\searrow \u0026amp;\\ \\\\-\\ \\longrightarrow \u0026amp;24x\u0026amp;\\ \u0026amp;\\cos x\\\\\\ \u0026amp;\\ \u0026amp;\\searrow \u0026amp;\\ \\\\+\\ \\longrightarrow \u0026amp;24\u0026amp;\\ \u0026amp;\\sin x\\\\\\ \u0026amp;\\ \u0026amp;\\searrow \u0026amp;\\\\\\ \u0026amp;0\u0026amp;\\ \u0026amp;-\\cos x\\\\\\end{matrix}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e So we have the answer already. When multiplying in the first row, as you can see by the arrows, multiply the \\( + \\) by the \\( x^{4} \\) in the same row and by the \\( -\\cos x \\) in the row below. Do all of these multiplications and add them together to get the answer. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int x^{4}\\sin x\\,dx\u003d-x^{4}\\cos x+4x^{3}\\sin x+12x^{2}\\cos x-24x\\sin x-24\\cos x+C\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",
      "uuid": "041fa9fc-a756-41d4-8634-347a749c2424",
      "contentType": "practiceProblem",
      "creatorUserId": "11481431651082296168",
      "createdAt": 1434556152398,
      "anonymous": true,
      "submitted": true,

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int {\\frac {\\ln {x}}{x}}dx\\,\u003d? \\) \u003cbr\u003e In order to compute this integral, are going to integrate it by parts. Recall that the formula for this method is \\( \\int u\\,du\u003duv-\\int v\\,du\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e Let \u003cbr\u003e \\( u\\,\u003d\\ln x\\, \\) and \\( dv\\,\u003d{\\frac {1}{x}}dx\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e Then\u003cbr\u003e \\( du\\,\u003d{\\frac {1}{x}}dx\\, \\) and \\( v\\,\u003d\\ln x\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e Substituting that into the formula above, we get the following:\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int {{\\frac {\\ln {x}}{x}}\\,dx}\\ \u003d\\ln ^{2}x-\\int {{\\frac {\\ln x}{x}}\\,dx} \\) \u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy simplifying the equation above, we get that \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int {\\frac {\\ln {x}}{x}}dx\u003d{\\frac {\\ln ^{2}x}{2}}+c \\) .\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int \\sin ^{2}{x}\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e To compute this integral, we must first use trig identities: \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sin ^{2}{x}+\\cos ^{2}{x}\u003d1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sin ^{2}{x}-\\cos ^{2}{x}\u003d-\\cos 2x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAdd the second equation to the first.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 2\\sin ^{2}{x}\u003d1-\\cos 2x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOr \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\sin ^{2}{x}\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}-{\\frac {\\cos 2x}{2}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubstitute this identity into the integral \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int {{\\frac {1}{2}}-{\\frac {\\cos 2x}{2}}dx} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This can be split into two pieces and evaluated separately\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int {{\\frac {1}{2}}dx}-\\int {{\\frac {\\cos 2x}{2}}dx} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The first is trivial \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int {{\\frac {1}{2}}dx}\u003d{\\frac {x}{2}}+C_{1} \\) The second can be computed by simple substitution \\( 2x\u003du;dx\u003d{\\frac {du}{2}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int {{\\frac {\\cos u}{4}}du}\u003d{\\frac {\\sin u}{4}}+C_{2} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Finally, we complete our substitution and combine our solutions\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {x}{2}}-{\\frac {\\sin 2x}{4}}+C \\) , where \\( C\u003dC_{1}-C_{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int \\sin ^{5}x\\cos ^{5}x\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Trigonometric integrals are split up into a few cases. This problem is the case where either the \\( \\sin x \\) or \\( \\cos x \\) is to an odd power. Both are odd, in fact, for this problem but the procedure is the same if only one is odd. First, pick the one that has an odd power, either will work here. For this specific example, let\u0027s turn 4 of those \\( \\cos x \\) into \\( \\sin x \\) and what we\u0027ll have left is a whole bunch of \\( \\sin x \\) and 1 \\( \\cos x \\) , which is the derivative of \\( \\sin x \\) . This sets up a nice integral by substitution. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( I\u003d\\int \\sin ^{5}x\\cos ^{5}x\\,dx\u003d\\int \\sin ^{5}x(1-\\sin ^{2}x)^{2}\\cos x\\,dx\u003d\\int (\\sin ^{9}x-2\\sin ^{7}x+\\sin ^{5}x)\\cos x\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let \\( u\u003d\\sin x\\, \\) and \\( du\u003d\\cos x\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( I\u003d\\int (u^{9}-2u^{7}+u^{5})\\,du\u003d{\\frac {1}{10}}u^{{10}}-{\\frac {1}{4}}u^{8}+{\\frac {1}{6}}u^{6}+C\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e And substitution back in gives us \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int \\sin ^{5}x\\cos ^{5}x\\,dx\u003d{\\frac {1}{10}}\\sin ^{{10}}x-{\\frac {1}{4}}\\sin ^{8}x+{\\frac {1}{6}}\\sin ^{6}x+C\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The procedure for many integrals is the same with the main difference being which of the trigonometric substitutions are used and in which way they are used. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int \\sin ^{2}x\\cos ^{2}x\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e When both \\( \\sin x \\) and \\( \\cos x \\) have even powers, turn both into \\( \\cos(2x) \\) by using the power reducing formulas \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sin ^{2}u\u003d{\\frac {1-\\cos(2u)}{2}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\cos ^{2}u\u003d{\\frac {1+\\cos(2u)}{2}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int \\sin ^{2}x\\cos ^{2}x\\,dx\u003d\\int {\\frac {1-\\cos(2x)}{2}}{\\frac {1+\\cos(2x)}{2}}\u003d{\\frac {1-\\cos ^{2}(2x)}{4}}\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now, if there is an odd number of \\( \\cos x \\) , simply turn all but one into \\( \\sin x \\) and we know the procedure. If there is still an even number of \\( \\cos x \\) (and there is always an even number of \\( \\sin x \\) , that is 0), continue to reduce them until you get to an odd power of \\( \\cos x \\) .       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int \\operatorname{arcsec} x\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Use integration by parts with \\( u\u003d\\operatorname{arcsec} x\\, \\) and \\( dv\u003ddx\\, \\) . Then, for \\( x\u0026gt;1\\, \\) , \\( du\u003d{\\frac {dx}{x{\\sqrt {x^{2}-1}}}}\\, \\) and \\( v\u003dx\\, \\) . So \u003c/p\u003e    \\( \\int \\operatorname{arcsec} x\\,dx \\)   \\( \u003d\\int u\\,dv\u003duv-\\int v\\,du \\)      \\( \u003dx\\operatorname{arcsec} x-\\int {\\frac {x\\,dx}{x{\\sqrt {x^{2}-1}}}} \\)      \\( \u003dx\\operatorname{arcsec} x-\\int {\\frac {dx}{{\\sqrt {x^{2}-1}}}} \\) .  \n\u003cp\u003eNow use the trigonometric substitution \\( x\u003d\\sec \\theta \\, \\) on the latter integral, with \\( dx\u003d\\sec \\theta \\,\\tan \\theta \\,d\\theta \\) . Then \u003c/p\u003e    \\( \\int {\\frac {dx}{{\\sqrt {x^{2}-1}}}} \\)   \\( \u003d\\int {\\frac {\\sec \\theta \\,\\tan \\theta \\,d\\theta }{{\\sqrt {\\sec ^{2}\\theta -1}}}} \\)      \\( \u003d\\int {\\frac {\\sec \\theta \\,\\tan \\theta \\,d\\theta }{{\\sqrt {\\tan ^{2}\\theta }}}} \\)      \\( \u003d\\int \\sec \\theta \\,d\\theta \u003d\\ln \\left|\\sec \\theta +\\tan \\theta \\right|+C \\) .  \n\u003cp\u003eAs \\( \\sec \\theta \u003dx\\, \\) , drawing a right triangle with hypotenuse of length \\( x \\) and adjacent side of length 1 yields \\( \\tan \\theta \u003d{\\sqrt {x^{2}-1}} \\) . Putting all of this together then gives the solution \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int \\operatorname{arcsec} x\\,dx\u003dx\\operatorname{arcsec} x-\\ln \\left(x+{\\sqrt {x^{2}-1}}\\right)+C \\) , where the absolute value in the logarithm may be dropped due to the restriction \\( x\u0026gt;1.\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int x\\arcsin x\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e First, we must do an integration by parts. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( u\u003d\\arcsin x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( du\u003d{\\frac {1}{{\\sqrt {1-x^{2}}}}}dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( dv\u003dx\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( v\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}x^{2}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int x\\arcsin x\\,dx\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}x^{2}\\arcsin x-{\\frac {1}{2}}\\int {\\frac {x^{2}}{{\\sqrt {1-x^{2}}}}}dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now, we are at an integral which can be computed using trigonometric substitution. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( x\u003d\\sin \\theta \\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( dx\u003d\\cos \\theta \\,d\\theta \\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int x\\arcsin x\\,dx\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}x^{2}\\arcsin x-{\\frac {1}{2}}\\int {\\frac {\\sin ^{2}\\theta \\cos \\theta }{{\\sqrt {1-\\sin ^{2}\\theta }}}}d\\theta \u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}x^{2}\\arcsin x-{\\frac {1}{2}}\\int \\sin ^{2}\\theta \\,d\\theta \\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now, let us use the power reduction formula on \\( \\sin ^{2}x \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int x\\arcsin x\\,dx\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}x^{2}\\arcsin x-{\\frac {1}{2}}\\int {\\frac {1-\\cos 2\\theta }{2}}d\\theta \u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}x^{2}\\arcsin x-{\\frac {1}{4}}\\arcsin x+{\\frac {1}{4}}x+C\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e For the back substitution, remember that \\( x\u003d\\sin \\theta \\) and therefore \\( \\theta \u003d\\arcsin x \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int {\\frac {1}{x^{2}-1}}\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The key to this problem is realizing that we can split up \\( {\\frac {1}{x^{2}-1}}\\, \\) into two fractions. This method is the method of \u003cb\u003ePartial Fractions\u003c/b\u003e. We know \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {1}{x^{2}-1}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{(x+1)(x-1)}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now, it is known that we can split this up into two fractions, one with a base of \\( x+1\\, \\) and the other with base \\( x-1\\, \\) . Let \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {1}{(x+1)(x-1)}}\u003d{\\frac {A}{x+1}}+{\\frac {B}{x-1}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Multiplying to get a common denominator and equating numerators gives us \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( 1\u003dA(x-1)+B(x+1)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Here, notice that this decomposition must be true for all \\( x\\, \\) so we can solve for \\( A\\, \\) and \\( B\\, \\) easily by picking values for \\( x\\, \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let \\( x\u003d1\\, \\) , then \\( 1\u003dA(0)+B(2)\\, \\) which gives \\( B\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e Let \\( x\u003d-1\\, \\) , then \\( 1\u003dA(-2)+B(0)\\, \\) which gives \\( A\u003d-{\\frac {1}{2}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e So our integral becomes \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int {\\frac {1}{x^{2}-1}}\\,dx\u003d\\int \\left[{\\frac {-{\\frac {1}{2}}}{x+1}}+{\\frac {{\\frac {1}{2}}}{x-1}}\\right]\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This is now an integral for which we have a formula. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int \\left[{\\frac {-{\\frac {1}{2}}}{x+1}}+{\\frac {{\\frac {1}{2}}}{x-1}}\\right]\\,dx\u003d-{\\frac {1}{2}}\\ln |x+1|+{\\frac {1}{2}}\\ln |x-1|+C\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int {\\frac {1}{(x+1)(x+2)(x+3)}}\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Again, this problem is a \u003cb\u003ePartial Fractions\u003c/b\u003e problem. Let \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {1}{(x+1)(x+2)(x+3)}}\u003d{\\frac {A}{x+1}}+{\\frac {B}{x+2}}+{\\frac {C}{x+3}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now, multiply through to get common denominators and equate the numerators. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( 1\u003dA(x+2)(x+3)+B(x+1)(x+3)+C(x+1)(x+2)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Pick values of \\( x\\, \\) to cancel out all but one term. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let \\( x\u003d-1\\, \\) , then \\( 1\u003d2A\\, \\) or \\( A\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e Let \\( x\u003d-2\\, \\) , then \\( 1\u003d-B\\, \\) or \\( B\u003d-1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e Let \\( x\u003d-3\\, \\) , then \\( 1\u003d2C\\, \\) or \\( C\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus our integral becomes \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int {\\frac {1}{(x+1)(x+2)(x+3)}}\\,dx\u003d\\int \\left({\\frac {0.5}{x+1}}-{\\frac {1}{x+2}}+{\\frac {0.5}{x+3}}\\right)\\,dx\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}\\ln |x+1|-\\ln |x+2|+{\\frac {1}{2}}\\ln |x+3|+C\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {x!}{(x+n)!}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d{\\frac {1}{(x+1)(x+2)(x+3)...(x+n)}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d{\\frac {A_{1}}{x+1}}+{\\frac {A_{2}}{x+2}}+{\\frac {A_{3}}{x+3}}+...+{\\frac {A_{n}}{x+n}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMultiplying through to create a common denominator then equating the numerators: \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( 1\u003d{A_{1}}(x+2)(x+3)...(x+n)+{A_{2}}(x+1)(x+3)+...+(x+n)+{A_{3}}(x+1)(x+2)...(x+n)+...+{A_{n}}(x+1)(x+2)+...+(x+n-1)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePick values of \\( x\\, \\) to cancel out all but one term: \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\mbox{ Let }}x\u003d-1,{\\mbox{ then }}1\u003d{A_{1}}(1)(2)(3)...(n-1)\\Rightarrow A_{1}\u003d{\\frac {1}{(n-1)!}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\mbox{ Let }}x\u003d-2,{\\mbox{ then }}1\u003d{A_{2}}(-1)(1)(2)...(n-2)\\Rightarrow A_{2}\u003d{\\frac {1}{(-1)(n-2)!}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\mbox{ Let }}x\u003d-3,{\\mbox{ then }}1\u003d{A_{3}}(-2)(-1)(1)...(n-3)\\Rightarrow A_{3}\u003d{\\frac {1}{(-2)(-1)(n-3)!}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e \n\u003cdl\u003e \n \u003cdd\u003e\n  \u003cdl\u003e \n   \u003cdd\u003e\n     \\( \\vdots \\) \n    \u003cbr\u003e \n   \u003c/dd\u003e \n  \u003c/dl\u003e \n \u003c/dd\u003e \n\u003c/dl\u003e \n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\mbox{ Let }}x\u003d-n,{\\mbox{ then }}1\u003d{A_{n}}(1-n)(2-n)(3-n)...(-1)\\Rightarrow A_{n}\u003d{\\frac {\\pm 1}{(n-1)!}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThus the general term for \\( A_{r} \\) can be deduced: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( A_{r}\u003d{\\frac {(-1)^{{r-1}}}{(n-r)!(r-1)!}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence \\( \\int {\\frac {x!}{(x+n)!}}\\,dx\u003d\\int \\sum _{{r\u003d1}}^{n}{\\frac {A_{r}}{x+r}}\\,dx\u003d\\sum _{{r\u003d1}}^{n}A_{r}\\ln |x+r|\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\(       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int {\\frac {x}{1-x^{2}}}\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Since \\( 1-x^{2}\u003d(1-x)(1+x) \\) , we can use the method of partial fractions to compute this integral. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {x}{1-x^{2}}}\u003d{\\frac {A}{1-x}}+{\\frac {B}{1+x}}\\Rightarrow x\u003dA(1+x)+B(1-x)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Since this is true for all values of \\( x \\) , pick values which will cause one of \\( A \\) or \\( B \\) to cancel out to find the other. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let \\( x\u003d1\\, \\) , then \\( A\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let \\( x\u003d-1\\, \\) , then \\( B\u003d-{\\frac {1}{2}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, the integral is split up into two integrals \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int {\\frac {x}{1-x^{2}}}\\,dx\u003d\\int {\\frac {{\\frac {1}{2}}}{1-x}}\\,dx+\\int {\\frac {-{\\frac {1}{2}}}{1+x}}\\,dx\u003d-{\\frac {1}{2}}\\ln |1-x|-{\\frac {1}{2}}\\ln |1+x|+C\u003d-{\\frac {1}{2}}\\ln |1-x^{2}|+C\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eClick here\u003c/a\u003e to see this integral done by substitution. \u003cbr\u003e \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eClick here\u003c/a\u003e to see this integral done by trigonometric substition. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eA ball is thrown straight up from the ground. How high will it go?\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe height of the ball at time \\( t\\, \\) is \\( x(t)\\, \\) , and the force acting on the ball is \\( -mg\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNewton\u0027s second law gives the relation\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( m{\\frac {d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}}+mg\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( m\u003d1\\, \\) for convenience.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}}+g\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIntegrate the last equation.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {dx(t)}{dt}}+gt+C\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo get \\( C\\, \\) , start with an initial velocity \\( v_{0}\\, \\) and set \\( t\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( v_{0}+C\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo now,\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {dx}{dt}}+gt-v_{0}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIntegrate again.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x(t)+{\\frac {1}{2}}gt^{2}-v_{0}t+D\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSince we have set \\( x(0)\u003d0\\, \\) , \\( D\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe equation of position is \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x(t)\u003d-{\\frac {1}{2}}gt^{2}+v_{0}t\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo find the maximum, set the first derivative equal to 0.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -gt+v_{0}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( t_{{max}}\u003d{\\frac {v_{0}}{g}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCheck that the second derivative at this point is negative.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x\u0027\u0027\\left({\\frac {v_{0}}{g}}\\right)\u003d-g\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo the answer is this point \\( t_{{max}}\\, \\) evaluated in the position function.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\(       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the area under the curve \\( f(x)\u003dx^{2} \\) on the interval \\( [-1,1] \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The main definition given for an integral in many undergraduate calculus textbooks today is one using a type of Riemann sums, that is summing up rectangles while making them smaller and smaller while adding in more and more of them until you have filled in all of the space and get the exact area under the curve. Really, all that is saying is an integral gives you the area between a function and the x-axis on a given interval. So, to find the area between this curve and the x-axis, all we need to do is take the integral on the interval. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( A\u003d\\int _{{-1}}^{{1}}x^{2}\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The first step you can use to simplify this integral a tiny bit is to recognize that \\( x^{2} \\) is an \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eeven function\u003c/a\u003e. An even function is one for which it is true that \\( f(-x)\u003df(x) \\) for all x. Since this is true, it has a symmetry about \\( x\u003d0 \\) . Thus, the value of this integral on \\( [-1,1] \\) is simply twice that of the integral on \\( [0,1] \\) . In some cases, this is a great help; in others, not so much. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( A\u003d\\int _{{-1}}^{{1}}x^{2}\\,dx\u003d2\\int _{{0}}^{{1}}x^{2}\\,dx\u003d{\\frac {2}{3}}x^{3}{\\bigg |}_{{0}}^{{1}}\u003d{\\frac {2}{3}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, the area between the function and the x-axis, on the interval \\( [-1,1] \\) is \\( {\\frac {2}{3}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the total area between the curve f(x)\u003dcosx and the x-axis on the interval[0,2pi]. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Here, we have to be very careful. The question asks for the total area between the function and the x-axis but if we simply take the integral, \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}\\cos x\\,dx\u003d\\sin x{\\bigg |}_{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e notice that we get an answer of 0. This is because the integral counts area above the x-axis as positive and that below the x-axis as negative. This problem contains an equal amount of area above and below the graph. So, we need to split this up into a few integrals \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( A\u003d\\int _{{0}}^{{{\\frac {\\pi }{2}}}}\\cos x\\,dx-\\int _{{{\\frac {\\pi }{2}}}}^{{{\\frac {3\\pi }{2}}}}\\cos x\\,dx+\\int _{{{\\frac {3\\pi }{2}}}}^{{2\\pi }}\\cos x\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Notice the middle integral has a negative sign out in front. This is because the graph is beneath the x-axis on that interval. Since the integral counts it as negative area, a negative sign in front makes it positive. The two integrals without negative signs in front represent regions where the function is above the x-axis. So, the area is \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( A\u003d\\sin x{\\bigg |}_{{0}}^{{{\\frac {\\pi }{2}}}}-\\sin x{\\bigg |}_{{{\\frac {\\pi }{2}}}}^{{{\\frac {3\\pi }{2}}}}+\\sin x{\\bigg |}_{{{\\frac {3\\pi }{2}}}}^{{2\\pi }}\u003d(1-0)-(-1-1)+(0--1)\u003d4\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus the total area between the curve \\( f(x)\u003d\\cos x \\) and the x-axis on the interval \\( [0,2\\pi ] \\) is 4 square units. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eUsing calculus, find the formula for the area of a rectangle. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Say we have a rectangle of length \\( a \\) and height \\( b \\) . We know that the area is given by the simple formula \\( A\u003dab \\) but now that we know calculus we can derive this formula and many others. Set up the rectangle so that it is completely in the first quadrant but has one edge against the x-axis and another up against the y-axis. Then the area can be found by an integral \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( A\u003d\\int _{{0}}^{{a}}b\\,dx\u003dbx{\\bigg |}_{{0}}^{{a}}\u003db(a)-b(0)\u003dab\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, by calculus we can find the equation which gives the area of a rectangle. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDerive the formula for the area of a circle with arbitrary radius r. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Moving a cirlce does not change its area so let us position this circle so that its center is at the point \\( (0,0) \\) . Then the equation for this circle is \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}\u003dr^{2}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e In finding the area of this circle, we will use symmetry. If we find the area of the portion in the first quadrant and multiply this by 4, we have the area of the whole circle. The equation of the upper half of the circle is given by solving for y and taking only the positive square root, \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y\u003d{\\sqrt {r^{2}-x^{2}}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, the area of this circle is given by 4 times the integral of this function while integrating over the x-values for the first quadrant. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( A\u003d4\\int _{{0}}^{{r}}{\\sqrt {r^{2}-x^{2}}}\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This integral can be done by trig substitution. Let \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( x\u003dr\\sin \\theta \\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( dx\u003dr\\cos \\theta \\,d\\theta \\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Substituting gives \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( A\u003d4\\int _{{x\u003d0}}^{{x\u003dr}}{\\sqrt {r^{2}-r^{2}\\sin ^{2}\\theta }}(r\\cos \\theta )\\,d\\theta \u003d4\\int _{{x\u003d0}}^{{x\u003dr}}r^{2}\\cos ^{2}\\theta \\,d\\theta \u003d4r^{2}\\int _{{x\u003d0}}^{{x\u003dr}}{\\frac {1+\\cos(2\\theta )}{2}}\\,d\\theta \u003d2r^{2}{\\bigg [}\\theta +{\\frac {1}{2}}\\sin(2\\theta ){\\bigg ]}_{{x\u003d0}}^{{x\u003dr}}\u003d2r^{2}{\\bigg [}\\theta +\\sin \\theta \\cos \\theta {\\bigg ]}_{{x\u003d0}}^{{x\u003dr}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now, substituting back in to get the expression in terms of x gives \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( A\u003d2r^{2}{\\bigg [}\\arcsin {\\frac {x}{r}}+{\\frac {x}{r}}{\\frac {{\\sqrt {r^{2}-x^{2}}}}{r}}{\\bigg ]}_{{0}}^{{r}}\u003d2r^{2}\\left[{\\frac {\\pi }{2}}+0-(0+0)\\right]\u003d\\pi r^{2}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This, of course is the formula we expected to get. For an arbitrary circle with radius r, the area is given by \\( \\pi r^{2} \\) . The formula for this shape and many others can be found using calculus. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

Our axis of revolution is the x-axis so our radius function is a function of x. Moreover, it is \\( r(x)\u003dx \\) since the distance from our axis of revolution to the function is always x.       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the volume of the solid generated by revolving the region bounded by \\( y\u003dx^{2} \\) and \\( y\u003d4x-x^{2} \\) around the x-axis. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e To do this problem, we first need to figure out what the region looks like. The intersection of the two graphs comes when \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}\u003d4x-x^{2}\\Rightarrow 2x^{2}-4x\u003d0\\Rightarrow 2x(x-2)\u003d0\\Rightarrow x\u003d0,2 \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe function \\( y\u003d4x-x^{2} \\) is the outermost function since we are revolving about the x-axis. Thus, we can find the volume by finding the volume of the solid generated by revolving \\( 4x-x^{2} \\) about the x-axis and subtracting the volume of the solid generated by revolving \\( y\u003dx^{2} \\) about the x-axis. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( V\u003d\\pi \\int _{{0}}^{{2}}(4x-x^{2})^{2}\\,dx-\\pi \\int _{{0}}^{{2}}(x^{2})^{2}\\,dx\u003d\\pi \\int _{{0}}^{{2}}(-8x^{3}+16x^{2})\\,dx \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d\\pi \\left[-2x^{4}+{\\frac {16}{3}}x^{3}\\right]_{{0}}^{{2}}\u003d\\pi \\left[-32+{\\frac {128}{3}}\\right]\u003d{\\frac {32\\pi }{3}} \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the volume of the solid generated by revolving the region bounded by \\( y\u003dx^{2} \\) and \\( y\u003dx^{3} \\) around the x-axis. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e First, we need to find the intersection points of the two graphs. These are easy to find with these particular points. The intersections come at \\( x\u003d0,1 \\) . Since \\( x^{2} \\) is greater than \\( x^{3} \\) between 0 and 1, and because we are revolving this region about the x-axis, our outer function is \\( y\u003dx^{2} \\) . So, we will find the volume of the solid of revolution using \\( y\u003dx^{2} \\) and subtract from this the volume of the solid of revolution using \\( y\u003dx^{3} \\) . That is, \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( V\u003d\\pi \\int _{{0}}^{{1}}\\left[(x^{2})^{2}-(x^{3})^{2}\\right]\\,dx\u003d\\pi \\int _{{0}}^{{1}}(x^{4}-x^{6})\\,dx\u003d\\pi \\left[{\\frac {1}{5}}x^{5}-{\\frac {1}{7}}x^{7}\\right]_{{0}}^{{1}}\u003d{\\frac {2\\pi }{35}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the volume, on the interval \\( 0\\leq x\\leq 3 \\) , of a 3-D object whose cross-section at any given point is a square with side length \\( x^{2}-9x \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e First, think about finding the area under a curve. We integrate the function to do this but essentially what we are doing is adding up an infinite amount of infinitely skinny lines and these lines (1-D objects) add up to give us the area. The function we integrate gives us the length of the line. It is a generalization of the formula A\u003dl\\times h for a rectangle. We get the infinitely many heights and we add them up over the length, the difference being that they vary. This problem is very similar though it might seem very different. Here, we are adding up an infinite amount of infinitely thin squares (2-D objects) and we will end up with the volume of the object. The function we integrate will give us the area, which we then add up to get a volume. Thus, the formula for finding a volume by cross-sectional areas is \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( V\u003d\\int _{{a}}^{{b}}A(x)\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e where we are finding the volume on the interval \\( [a,b] \\) and where A(x) gives a formula for the area of a general cross-section. Here, we have \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( V\u003d\\int _{{0}}^{{3}}(x^{2}-9x)^{2}\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e because the area of a square is equal to the square of its side length. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( V\u003d\\int _{{0}}^{{3}}(x^{2}-9x)^{2}\\,dx\u003d\\int _{{0}}^{{3}}(x^{4}-18x^{3}+81x^{2})\\,dx\u003d\\left[{\\frac {1}{5}}x^{5}-{\\frac {9}{2}}x^{4}+27x^{3}\\right]_{{0}}^{{3}}\u003d{\\frac {4131}{10}}\u003d413.1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e So, the volume of this shape, whose cross-section is always a square with varying side length, is 413.1 cubic units. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",
      "uuid": "8c84d21c-e925-4cc9-83c8-630748511ffc",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the volume, on the interval \\( 0\\leq x\\leq \\pi \\) , of a 3-D object whose cross-section at any given point is an equilateral triangle with side length \\( \\sin {\\frac {x}{2}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e In an equilateral triangle, taking one side as the base, the height is the length of the perpendicular bisector to that side. If \\( y \\) is the side length in an equilateral triangle, the length of a perpendicular bisector is given by \\( {\\frac {{\\sqrt {3}}}{2}}y \\) . So the area of a given equilateral triangle in this problem is given by \\( {\\frac {1}{2}}{\\frac {{\\sqrt {3}}}{2}}\\sin ^{2}\\left({\\frac {x}{2}}\\right) \\) . To find the volume, we integrate the area over the interval. Thus \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( V\u003d\\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}{\\frac {{\\sqrt {3}}}{4}}\\sin ^{2}\\left({\\frac {x}{2}}\\right)\\,dx\u003d{\\frac {{\\sqrt {3}}}{4}}\\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}{\\frac {1-\\cos x}{2}}dx\u003d{\\frac {{\\sqrt {3}}}{8}}{\\bigg [}x-\\sin x{\\bigg ]}_{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}\u003d{\\frac {{\\sqrt {3}}}{8}}[2\\pi ]\u003d{\\frac {{\\sqrt {3}}\\pi }{4}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, the volume of this shape is \\( {\\frac {{\\sqrt {3}}\\pi }{4}} \\) units. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the volume of a cylinder with radius 3 and height 10. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Here, we are finding the volume of an object with circles for cross-sections. It is quite simple since, in a cylinder, the circles are all the same size. So, the cross-sectional area at any point is just \\( A\u003d\\pi (3)^{2} \\) . Since the area does not depend on x, it does not matter which interval we integrate over so long as it has a length of 10. So the volume is \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int _{{0}}^{{10}}9\\pi \\,dx\u003d9\\pi x{\\big |}_{{0}}^{{10}}\u003d90\\pi \\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, the volume is \\( 90\\pi \\) cubic units. This is the same answer we would get if we used the formula for the volume of a cylinder, \\( V\u003d\\pi r^{2}h \\) . This example shows that you can get the volumes of already known shapes but you can also get volumes for shapes with varying cross-sectional areas for which there is on specific formula. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the average value of the function \\( f(x)\u003de^{{2x}} \\) on the interval \\( [0,4] \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e An integral gives us the total value of a function over an interval. If we then take this and divide it by the length of the interval, then we attain the average value of the function on the interval. Thus the average value of a function on an interval [a,b] is given by \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {1}{b-a}}\\int _{{a}}^{{b}}f(x)\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e For this specific function, we have \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {1}{4-0}}\\int _{{0}}^{{4}}e^{{2x}}\\,dx\u003d{\\frac {1}{4}}\\left[{\\frac {1}{2}}e^{{2x}}\\right]_{{0}}^{{4}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{8}}\\left[e^{8}-1\\right]\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, the average value of \\( f(x) \\) on the interval \\( [0,4] \\) is \\( {\\frac {1}{8}}\\left[e^{8}-1\\right] \\) .       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the average value of the function \\( \\sin ^{6}(t)\\cos ^{3}(t) \\) on the interval \\( \\left[0,{\\frac {\\pi }{2}}\\right] \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e For the method to do this integral see the section on Substitution and the section on Trigonometric Integrals.       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence or divergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n}} \\) and \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n^{2}}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e The terms go to \\( 0 \\) for both of these series so the nth term test tells us nothing. The first series, \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n}} \\) , diverges by the integral test (which we have not learned at this point) and the second series, \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n^{2}}} \\) , converges also by the integral test.       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence or divergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}\\sin n \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The sine function is a periodic function with period length of \\( 2\\pi \\) . So, as \\( n \\) approaches \\( \\infty \\) , the terms of this series just move around inside the interval \\( [-1,1] \\) . They don?t go anywhere. For example, \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sin 1\\approx 0.8415 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sin 2\\approx 0.9093 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sin 3\\approx 0.1411 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sin 4\\approx -0.7568 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sin 100\\approx -0.5064 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sin 1000\\approx 0.8269 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sin 10000\\approx -0.3056 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sin 100000\\approx 0.0358 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Since the terms do not converge to 0 as \\( n\\rightarrow \\infty \\) , this series diverges by the nth term test. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence or divergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d3}}^{{\\infty }}\\left({\\frac {2}{3}}\\right)^{n} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This converges because it is a geometric series with common ratio \\( {\\frac {2}{3}} \\) . Be careful when computing the sum. Our formula is for a sum starting at \\( n\u003d0 \\) and here we start with \\( n\u003d3 \\) . Thus \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d3}}^{{\\infty }}\\left({\\frac {2}{3}}\\right)^{n}\u003d{\\frac {1}{1-{\\frac {2}{3}}}}-\\left({\\frac {2}{3}}\\right)^{0}-\\left({\\frac {2}{3}}\\right)^{1}-\\left({\\frac {2}{3}}\\right)^{2}\u003d3-1-{\\frac {2}{3}}-{\\frac {4}{9}}\u003d{\\frac {8}{9}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e So, this geometric series converges to the sum \\( {\\frac {8}{9}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence of \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}e^{{-3n}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Again, use the integral test. Notice that the integral test states the series starts at \\( n\u003d1 \\) and this series starts at \\( n\u003d0 \\) . This does not change the fact that the integral test works. One extra term, or a million for that matter, will not change the convergence or divergence of a series. The one thing you must test is to make sure the function is continuous on the entire interval. For example, \\( {\\frac {1}{n}} \\) is undefined when \\( n\u003d0 \\) so starting such a series at 0 would not work. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int _{{0}}^{{\\infty }}e^{{-3x}}\\,dx\u003d-{\\frac {1}{3}}e^{{-3x}}{\\bigg |}_{{0}}^{{\\infty }}\u003d0-\\left(-{\\frac {1}{3}}e^{{-3\\times 0}}\\right)\u003d{\\frac {1}{3}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This integral converges to a real number. Since this function is continuous, positive, and decreasing, by the integral test, our series also converges. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence of \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {n}{e^{n}}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e We can use the integral test on this one because the function is continuous, positive, and decreasing. To do the integral, we will use integration by parts. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int _{{1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {x}{e^{x}}}\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( u\u003dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( du\u003ddx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( dv\u003de^{{-x}}\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( v\u003d-e^{{-x}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int _{{1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {x}{e^{x}}}\\,dx\u003d-xe^{{-x}}+\\int _{{1}}^{{\\infty }}e^{{-x}}\\,dx\u003d\\left[-xe^{{-x}}-e^{{-x}}\\right]_{{1}}^{{\\infty }}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Taking the limit as \\( x\\rightarrow \\infty \\) and plugging in 1 gives \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int _{{1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {x}{e^{x}}}\\,dx\u003d{\\frac {-2}{e}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, by the integral test, since this converges, the series also converges. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eExplain why the integral test is or is not applicable to \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}n^{2} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The function \\( f(x)\u003dx^{2} \\) is positive and continuous on the interval \\( [1,\\infty ] \\) . However, it is increasing whereas the integral test only works on functions which are decreasing. The divergence of this series, though, is easily established. Any continuous function which is positive and increasing can not go to 0. If the terms of a series do not go to 0, then the series diverges by the nth term test. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eExplain why the integral test is or is not applicable to \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}-{\\frac {1}{n^{2}}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The integral test states a function must be continuous, positive, and decreasing. This function is continuous but it is negative and increasing. However, we can easily use the integral test. Instead, look at the function \\( f(x)\u003d{\\frac {1}{x^{2}}} \\) . This function is continuous, positive, and decreasing on the interval \\( [1,\\infty ] \\) so the integral test applies. In fact, the integral test confirms that its series converges. Thus, since this series converges, multiplying every term by -1 will simply change the sign of the sum but will not affect convergence at all and this is all we need to show to know that the given series converges. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

 ,"topic": "NONE"    },
    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eExplain why the integral test is or is not applicable to \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {|\\sin n|+1}{\\ln(n+1)}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This series contains terms which are all positive since the numerator and denominator are always positive. This function is also always continuous, though it has many sharp turns. However, this function is never decreasing. The sine function causes this series to continually increase for a short while and then decrease for a short while, increase for a short while and then decrease for a short while, and so on. Thus, we can not use the integral test on this series. However, the direct comparison test shows us that this series diverges. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",
      "uuid": "96dc916d-c32c-4c56-837c-f44b9d9e4547",

      "creatorUserId": "11481431651082296168",

    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence of \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n^{p}}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This type of series is called a p-series. The idea of this problem is to find which values of p give us a convergent series and which values of p give us a divergent series. When we have that info, we can find the convergence or divergence of any p-series without having to calculate hundreds of different integrals separately, simply by knowing the value of p. Use the integral test to determine convergence and divergence. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int _{{1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{x^{p}}}\u003d{\\frac {x^{{-p+1}}}{-p+1}}{\\bigg |}_{{1}}^{{\\infty }}\u003d{\\frac {1}{1-p}}{\\frac {1}{x^{{p-1}}}}{\\bigg |}_{{1}}^{{\\infty }} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e First, if \\( p\u003d1 \\) the integral yields \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\ln |x|{\\bigg |}_{{1}}^{{\\infty }}\u003d\\lim _{{b\\to \\infty }}\\lim _{{a\\to 1^{+}}}\\left(\\ln b-\\ln a\\right)\u003d\\lim _{{b\\to \\infty }}\\lim _{{a\\to 1^{+}}}\\ln {\\frac {b}{a}}\u003d\\infty \\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e So, when \\( p\u003d1 \\) the integral diverges. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e If \\( p\u0026gt;1 \\) the integral converges because as \\( x\\rightarrow \\infty \\) the integral goes to \\( 0 \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e If \\( p\u0026lt;1 \\) the integral diverges because as \\( x\\rightarrow \\infty \\) the integral goes to \\( \\infty \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e So, by the integral test, the series \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n^{p}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e converges when \\( p\u0026gt;1 \\) and diverges otherwise, for any real p. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence or divergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n^{3}+4}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The series \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n^{3}}} \\) converges because it is a p-series with \\( p\u003d3\u0026gt;1 \\) and our series looks a lot like this series so we would think that is also converges. Thankfully we have the direct comparison test so that we can test our series with other series with known convergence or divergence. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( 0\u0026lt;{\\frac {1}{n^{3}+4}}\u0026lt;{\\frac {1}{n^{3}}} \\) for all \\( n\u0026gt;0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e We have a known convergent series with positive terms, \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n^{3}}} \\) , and its terms are all larger, term by term, than our series which also has positive terms. Thus, by the direct comparison test, our series \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n^{3}+4}} \\) converges. This makes complete sense. If we have an infinite sum of positive numbers which converges to a finite number, then it makes perfect sense that another infinite sum of smaller positive numbers would not only converge, but converge to a smaller positive number. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

If \u003cspan\u003e\u003ci\u003er\u003c/i\u003e \u0026gt; 1,\u003c/span\u003e then the series diverges. If \u003cspan\u003e\u003ci\u003er\u003c/i\u003e \u003d 1,\u003c/span\u003e the ratio test is inconclusive, and the series may converge or diverge. Since in our case, \u003ci\u003er\u003c/i\u003e is equal to 1/3, the geometric series must converge. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac {{\\frac {1}{3^{n}}}}{{\\frac {n+1}{n3^{{n+1}}}}}}\u003d\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac {3n}{n+1}}\u003d3\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, since this limit is finite and positive, both series converge or diverge.       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence or divergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {\\sin {\\frac {k\\pi }{2}}}{k}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e To show convergence for this series we will use Dirichlet?s test. The terms of this sequence are the product of \\( {\\frac {1}{k}} \\) and \\( \\sin {\\frac {k\\pi }{2}} \\) . The first sequence of numbers decreases toward 0 as \\( k\\rightarrow \\infty \\) . For the second sequence of numbers, \\( \\sin {\\frac {k\\pi }{2}} \\) , let us look at the partial sums \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( s_{n}\u003d\\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{n}}\\sin {\\frac {k\\pi }{2}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The terms of the sequence are {1, 1, 0, 0, 1, 1, 0, 0, ...}. Thus, this second sequence of numbers has bounded partial sums. Since our series has terms which are a product of the terms of one sequence which decreases to 0 and another which has bounded partial sums, by Dirichlet?s test, this series converges. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence or divergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d7}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(-{\\frac {1}{2}}\\right)^{k} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e We can see that this series converges since it is a geometric series with common ratio \\( {\\frac {-1}{2}} \\) and also because it is an alternating series with terms decreasing in magnitude. But, to give another example for Dirichlet\u0027s test, we will show this series converges by it. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d7}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(-{\\frac {1}{2}}\\right)^{k}\u003d\\sum _{{k\u003d7}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(-1\\right)^{k}\\left({\\frac {1}{2}}\\right)^{k} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This is in just the form to use Dirichlet\u0027s test. The sequence of partial sums \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\{s_{n}\\}\u003d\\left\\{\\sum _{{k\u003d7}}^{{n}}\\left(-1\\right)^{k}\\right\\} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e is bounded since it alternates between -1 and 0. Also, \\( \\left({\\frac {1}{2}}\\right)^{k} \\) decreases to 0 as \\( k\\rightarrow \\infty \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, by Dirichlet\u0027s test, this series converges. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",
