      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence or divergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d3}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{\\ln(\\ln k)}}\\cos \\left({\\frac {k\\pi }{3}}\\right) \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e We know \\( {\\frac {1}{\\ln(\\ln k)}}\\rightarrow 0 \\) as \\( k\\rightarrow \\infty \\) , though at an extremely slow rate. So, if we can show that the sequence of partial sums \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\{s_{n}\\}\u003d\\left\\{\\sum _{{k\u003d3}}^{{n}}\\cos \\left({\\frac {k\\pi }{3}}\\right)\\right\\} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e is bounded, then we can conclude by Dirichlet\u0027s test that our given series converges. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\cos 0\u003d1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\cos {\\frac {\\pi }{3}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\cos {\\frac {2\\pi }{3}}\u003d-{\\frac {1}{2}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\cos \\pi \u003d-1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\cos {\\frac {4\\pi }{3}}\u003d-{\\frac {1}{2}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\cos {\\frac {5\\pi }{3}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e And, at this point, we get repeat since \\( \\cos(2\\pi )\u003d\\cos 0 \\) . Thus, our sequence of partial sums is (notice k starts at 3) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\{s_{n}\\}\u003d\\{-{\\frac {1}{2}},-{\\frac {3}{2}},-2,-{\\frac {3}{2}},-{\\frac {1}{2}},0,-{\\frac {1}{2}},-{\\frac {3}{2}},-2,-{\\frac {3}{2}},-{\\frac {1}{2}},0,...\\} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, this sequence is bounded and, by Dirichlet\u0027s test, this series converges. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence or divergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}a_{k}{\\frac {1}{k^{3}}} \\) where \\( a_{k}\u003d\\{7,4,6,3,-10,-10,7,4,6,3,-10,-10,...\\} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This series is not like any series you normally see in calculus books. However, it is easily shown to converge by Dirichlet\u0027s test. First, we have the sequence of partial sums \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\{s_{n}\\}\u003d\\left\\{\\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{n}}a_{k}\\right\\}\u003d\\{7,11,17,20,10,0,7,11,17,20,10,0,...\\} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, this sequence ranges from 0 to 20 but never gets outside of this range. That is, it is bounded. Further, \\( {\\frac {1}{k^{3}}} \\) decreases to 0 as \\( k\\rightarrow \\infty \\) . Thus, this series converges by Dirichlet\u0027s test. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence or divergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}\\sin {\\frac {2k\\pi }{n}}{\\frac {1}{\\ln(\\ln(\\ln k))}} \\) for any integer \\( n\\geq 1 \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let us first look at the sequence of partial sums \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\{s_{n}\\}\u003d\\left\\{\\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{n}}\\sin {\\frac {2k\\pi }{n}}\\right\\} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This sequence is bounded, though by a different number for each n. If n is even, the first n values of k will be split up with two values of k that give a 0 for the sine function, \\( k\u003d{\\frac {n}{2}} \\) and \\( k\u003dn \\) . Of the remaining n-2 values, the first half, a total of \\( {\\frac {n}{2}}-1 \\) , will give a positive value for sine and the second half will cancel those all out. Thus, an easy to calculate bound (we just need to show that there is one, not find the least upper bound) is \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( 0\\leq \\{s_{n}\\}\\leq {\\frac {n}{2}}-1 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e since sine can be at most 1. If n is odd, this is only slightly different. Now, the nth value of k will give a 0 sine, where as the first \\( {\\frac {n-1}{2}} \\) will give a positive sine and the next \\( {\\frac {n-1}{2}} \\) will give exactly opposite negative sines, canceling out the first. Thus, for any n, the sequence of partial sums is bounded by \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( 0\\leq \\{s_{n}\\}\\leq {\\frac {n-1}{2}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now, since \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {1}{\\ln(\\ln(\\ln k))}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e goes to 0 as \\( k\\rightarrow \\infty \\) , by Dirichlet\u0027s test, this series converges. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence or divergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d3}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {\\ln(\\ln k)}{\\ln k}}a_{k} \\) where \\( \\{a_{k}\\}\u003d\\{1,-1,1,2,-3,1,2,4,-7,1,-1,1,2,-3,1,2,4,-7,...\\} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e It is well known that \\( \\ln k\\rightarrow \\infty \\) as \\( k\\rightarrow \\infty \\) , though it travels very slowly. So, we know that \\( \\ln(\\ln k) \\) also goes to \\( \\infty \\) , though much more slowly. Taking the ratio of the two, \\( {\\frac {\\ln(\\ln k)}{\\ln k}} \\) decreases to 0 as \\( k\\rightarrow \\infty \\) because the bottom increases much more quickly than the top. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now, looking at the sequence of partial sums of \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\{s_{n}\\}\u003d\\left\\{\\sum _{{k\u003d3}}^{{\\infty }}a_{k}\\right\\} \\) where \\( \\{a_{k}\\}\u003d\\{1,-1,1,2,-3,1,2,4,-7,1,-1,1,2,-3,1,2,4,-7,...\\} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e we get the sequence of numbers \\( \\{1,3,0,1,3,7,0,1,0,1,3,0,1,3,7,0,...\\} \\) (notice that k starts at 3). Since this sequence is always between 0 and 7, inclusive, it is bounded. Thus, our series converges by Dirichlet\u0027s test. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {(-1)^{{n+1}}n^{2}}{e^{n}}}\\, \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The absolute value of the terms of this sequence is decreasing and goes to 0 as \\( n\\rightarrow \\infty \\) . If you can not see this, use \\( L\u0027H{\\hat {o}}pital\u0027s \\) Rule. First, in taking the limit as \\( n\\rightarrow \\infty \\) , we get \\( {\\frac {\\infty }{\\infty }} \\) . Since this is an indeterminate form, it is likely that \\( L\u0027H{\\hat {o}}pital\u0027s \\) Rule might be the way to find the limit of the terms. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\lim _{{n\\to \\infty }}{\\frac {n^{2}}{e^{n}}}\u003d\\lim _{{n\\to \\infty }}{\\frac {2n}{e^{n}}}\u003d\\lim _{{n\\to \\infty }}{\\frac {2}{e^{n}}}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, by \\( L\u0027H{\\hat {o}}pital\u0027s \\) Rule, since the limit exists, this method gives us the correct limit. The terms of this series go to 0 because the exponential function increases much more quickly than the power function. This also indicates that the absolute value of the terms is decreasing. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Therefore, by the alternate series test, we know that this series converges. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

 ,"topic": "NONE"    },
    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence of \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d2}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {(-1)^{n}}{\\ln n}} \\) including whether the sum converges absolutely or conditionally. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This series converges by the alternating series test. The terms alternate and go to \\( 0 \\) and the absolute value of the terms decreases. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e By definition a series converges absolutely if the series with terms that are the absolute values of the terms of the original series also converges. In this case, the series we need to consider is \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d2}}^{{\\infty }}\\left|{\\frac {(-1)^{n}}{\\ln n}}\\right|\u003d\\sum _{{n\u003d2}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{\\ln n}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e One way to determine the convergence of this new series is the direct comparison test. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {1}{\\ln n}}\u0026gt;{\\frac {1}{n}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e We know that the series \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d2}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n}} \\) diverges. Thus, by the direct comparison test, since the terms of our series are all even greater than a series which diverges, our series must also diverge. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e We say \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d2}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {(-1)^{n}}{\\ln n}} \\) converges conditionally because the series itself converges but the series \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d2}}^{{\\infty }}\\left|{\\frac {(-1)^{n}}{\\ln n}}\\right| \\) diverges. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",
      "uuid": "95cdb329-d3b1-4b23-8782-b74e673cb9ad",
      "contentType": "practiceProblem",
      "creatorUserId": "11481431651082296168",
      "createdAt": 1434556153878,
      "anonymous": true,
      "submitted": true,
      "viewable": true,
      "karma": 1,

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence of \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {(-1)^{{n+1}}}{n^{2}+3n+4}} \\) including whether the sum converges absolutely or conditionally. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e We can use the alternating series test here to determine that the series converges since the terms go to 0 and the absolute value of the terms decreases. However, this series converges absolutely and any series that converges absolutely simply converges so let us just prove that this series is absolutely convergent. To do this, examine the series \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}\\left|{\\frac {(-1)^{{n+1}}}{n^{2}+3n+4}}\\right|\u003d\\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n^{2}+3n+4}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Comparing this series to another, we see that \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {1}{n^{2}+3n+4}}\u0026lt;{\\frac {1}{n^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e and we know that the series \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n^{2}}} \\) converges. Thus, by the direct comparison test, the series \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}\\left|{\\frac {(-1)^{{n+1}}}{n^{2}+3n+4}}\\right|\u003d\\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n^{2}+3n+4}} \\) converges and thus our original series \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {(-1)^{{n+1}}}{n^{2}+3n+4}} \\) not only converges but converges absolutely. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence of \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {(-1)^{n}}{n!}} \\) including whether the sum converges absolutely or conditionally. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The terms of the factorial function get very big very quickly. So we would think this sequence would converge. Let?s look at the series which contains the absolute value of the terms of this sequence. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}\\left|{\\frac {(-1)^{n}}{n!}}\\right|\u003d\\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n!}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e For \\( n\u0026gt;3 \\) , we have \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {1}{n^{2}}}\u0026gt;{\\frac {1}{n!}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e and we know that \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n^{2}}} \\) converges because it is a p-series with \\( p\u0026gt;1 \\) . Thus, the series \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n!}} \\) also converges by the direct comparison test. The first three terms do not change the convergence of a series. Adding a finite number to a convergent series does not change it to a divergent series. Finally, since this converges, we know that \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {(-1)^{n}}{n!}} \\) converges absolutely. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence or divergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {n4^{n}}{n!}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e It might not be obvious which grows faster, our numerator or our denominator. The numerator is a linear function multiplied by an exponential whereas the denominator of our fraction is a factorial faction.       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence or divergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {n^{k}a^{n}}{n!}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e So here we have a power function of any order, k could be any number, 1, 100, 1,000,000, or even higher, and we also have an exponential function where \\( a \\) can also be any number as high as you want. Yet, by the ratio test, we will show that a simple factorial function will eventually grow to be much greater than even the product of these two. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac {{\\frac {(n+1)^{k}a^{{n+1}}}{(n+1)!}}}{{\\frac {n^{k}a^{n}}{n!}}}}\\right|\u003d\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac {(n+1)^{k}a}{n^{k}(n+1)}}\\right|\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The degree of the denominator is one greater than the degree of the numerator so this limit does go to 0.       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence or divergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {n}{3^{n}}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{{\\frac {n}{3^{n}}}}}\u003d\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac {{\\sqrt[ {n}]{n}}}{3}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{3}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Since the limit is less than 1, by the root test, this series converges absolutely. It is true that \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{n}}\u003d1 \\) , \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e which we just used for this problem. I will show this is true. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let \\( y\u003d\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{n}} \\) . From here, we can take the natural log of both sides, and in fact, on the right side, we can put the natural log on the inside of the limit. This is the trick for finding this limit analytically. So, we have \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\ln y\u003d\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\ln {\\sqrt[ {n}]{n}}\u003d\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n}}\\ln n\u003d\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac {\\ln n}{n}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Here, plugging in infinity gives an indeterminate form so we can use L\u0027Hopitals rule, provided the limit exists. This gives us \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\ln y\u003d\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac {\\ln n}{n}}\u003d\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac {{\\frac {1}{n}}}{1}}\u003d\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac {1}{n}}\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e So, we have \\( \\ln y\u003d0 \\) . Thus, \\( y\u003d1 \\) as claimed. Thus \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence or divergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {n!}{(n+1)^{n}}}\\left({\\frac {237}{50}}\\right)^{n} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This series looks tricky. Instinctively, since we have \\( (n+1)^{n} \\) on the bottom, we should think this series is going to converge, even with the \\( n! \\) in the numerator. But, let us use the root test to find out for sure. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{{\\frac {n!}{(n+1)^{n}}}\\left({\\frac {237}{50}}\\right)^{n}}}\u003d{\\frac {237}{50}}\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{{\\frac {n!}{(n+1)^{n}}}}}\u003d{\\frac {237}{50}}\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{{\\frac {1}{n+1}}\\times {\\frac {2}{n+1}}\\times {\\frac {3}{n+1}}\\times \\ldots \\times {\\frac {n}{n+1}}}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This limit looks to be 0, and in fact it is, but how can we show that. The trick is that as n goes to infinity, it can be arbitrarily large. We know that \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {237}{50}}\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{{\\frac {1}{n+1}}\\times {\\frac {2}{n+1}}\\times {\\frac {3}{n+1}}\\times \\ldots \\times {\\frac {n}{n+1}}}}\u0026lt;{\\frac {237}{50}}K\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{{\\frac {n}{n+1}}\\times {\\frac {n}{n+1}}\\times {\\frac {n}{n+1}}\\times \\cdots \\times {\\frac {n}{n+1}}}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The thing here is that I can make K as small as I want. For here, making it \\( {\\frac {1}{100}} \\) suffices. Since we are taking the limit as n goes to infinity, we can assume \\( n\u0026gt;10,000 \\) . If this is true, then in changing \\( {\\sqrt {{\\frac {1}{n+1}}}} \\) to \\( {\\sqrt {{\\frac {n}{n+1}}}} \\) , we multiplied by at least \\( {\\sqrt {10,000}} \\) . So, we can bring a \\( {\\frac {1}{{\\sqrt {10,000}}}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{100}} \\) outside of the square root, though we can bring out an arbitrarily small number by assuming n is as big as we choose. Thus, we have \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {237}{50}}\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{{\\frac {1}{n+1}}\\times {\\frac {2}{n+1}}\\times {\\frac {3}{n+1}}\\times \\ldots \\times {\\frac {n}{n+1}}}}\u0026lt;{\\frac {237}{50}}\\times {\\frac {1}{100}}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{\\left({\\frac {n}{n+1}}\\right)^{n}}}\u003d{\\frac {237}{5000}}\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac {n}{n+1}}\u003d{\\frac {237}{5000}}\u0026lt;1 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, this series converges by the root test. Also, note that the series \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {n!}{(n+1)^{n}}}\\left({\\frac {a}{b}}\\right)^{n} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e converges which we can prove easily by assuming n is even bigger and pulling out an even smaller constant to make up for any \\( {\\frac {a}{b}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",
      "uuid": "e6bc2bfd-39a9-43fc-b84f-33236e72f00e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence or divergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{k}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e By the Cauchy condensation test, we know that this series and the series \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}2^{k}{\\frac {1}{2^{k}}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e either both converge or both diverge. Looking at this new series, it is clear to see that it diverges. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}2^{k}{\\frac {1}{2^{k}}}\u003d\\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}1 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The terms do not even go to 0 in this series, so by the nth term test, it diverges. Thus, by the Cauchy condensation test, it is also true that our series diverges. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence or divergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{\\ln k}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The terms of this series go to 0, but does it converge? Using the Cauchy condensation test, it is true that this series and \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}2^{k}{\\frac {1}{\\ln 2^{k}}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{\\ln 2}}\\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {2^{k}}{k}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e converge or diverge together. It is well known that the terms of \\( 2^{k} \\) increase much more quickly than the terms of \\( k \\) so we know that these terms do not go to 0, but instead increase to \\( \\infty \\) and thus this series diverges. We can prove this using the ratio test: \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\lim _{{k\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac {{\\frac {2^{{k+1}}}{k+1}}}{{\\frac {2^{k}}{k}}}}\\right|\u003d\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac {2k}{k+1}}\u003d2\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Since this number is greater than 1, by the ratio test, this series diverges. Since this series diverges, by the Cauchy condensation test, our original series also diverges. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence or divergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{k^{2}}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e By now, you probably know that this series converges since it is a p-series with p\u003d2. However, let us look at this series again using the Cauchy condensation test. By this test, we know that our series and the series \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}2^{k}{\\frac {1}{(2^{k})^{2}}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e converge or diverge together. It is easy to show that this series converges by simplifying it. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}2^{k}{\\frac {1}{(2^{k})^{2}}}\u003d\\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{2^{k}}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This is just a geometric series with common ratio \\( {\\frac {1}{2}} \\) and first term \\( {\\frac {1}{2}} \\) which is well known to converge to 1. Thus, this series converges and therefore the original series converges by the Cauchy condensation test. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

This series is already in the form \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}2^{k}a_{{2^{k}}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e which we get by a bit of simplification, or perhaps complication. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{{\\sqrt {2^{k}}}}}\u003d\\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}2^{k}{\\frac {1}{(2^{k})^{{{\\frac {3}{2}}}}}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus, this series converges or diverges with the series \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{k^{{{\\frac {3}{2}}}}}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This series converges because it is a p-series with p\u0026gt;1.       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDiscuss the convergence or divergence of the series \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{(2^{k})^{n}}} \\) , where n is some real number. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let us multiply the numerator and denominator of this by \\( 2^{k} \\) . This gives us \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}2^{k}{\\frac {1}{(2^{k})^{{n+1}}}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This is the form \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}2^{k}a_{{2^{k}}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e and thus converges or diverges together with the series \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac {1}{k^{{n+1}}}} \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e This, we know converges if \\( n\u0026gt;0 \\) and diverges for any other value of n ( \\( n\\leq 0 \\) ) by the n-series test. Thus, our original series converges if \\( n\u0026gt;0 \\) and diverges if \\( n\\leq 0 \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the infinite series expansion of \\( f(x)\u003d{\\frac {1}{(1+x)^{a}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ca href\u003d\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taylor_series\" rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eMaclaurin series\u003c/a\u003e is \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac {f^{{(n)}}(0)}{n!}}x^{n}\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFind the first few derivatives of \\( f(x) \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( f\u0027(x)\u003d-a(1+x)^{{-(a+1)}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027\u0027(x)\u003da(a+1)(1+x)^{{-(a+2)}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( f\u0027\u0027\u0027(x)\u003d-a(a+1)(a+2)(1+x)^{{-(a+3)}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGuess the general \\( n^{{th}} \\) derivative.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( f^{{(n)}}(x)\u003d(-1)^{n}(a)_{n}(1+x)^{{-(a+n)}}\\, \\) where \\( (a)_{n}\u003da(a+1)(a+2)\\cdot \\cdot \\cdot (a+n-1)\\, \\) is the \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003ePochhammer symbol\u003c/a\u003e.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePlug in \\( x\u003d0 \\) and use the Maclaurin series formula.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {1}{(1+x)^{a}}}\u003d\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac {(-1)^{n}(a)_{n}}{n!}}x^{n}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eCalculus\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDetermine whether this series converges: \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac {1}{k(k+1)}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUse partial fraction decompostition to write the first \\( n \\) terms of this sum as:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{n}\\left({\\frac {1}{k}}-{\\frac {1}{k+1}}\\right)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d(1-{\\frac {1}{2}})+({\\frac {1}{2}}-{\\frac {1}{3}})+({\\frac {1}{3}}-{\\frac {1}{4}})+...+({\\frac {1}{n-1}}-{\\frac {1}{n}})+({\\frac {1}{n}}-{\\frac {1}{n+1}})\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNotice that all of the middle terms cancel out.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d1-{\\frac {1}{n+1}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTake the limit as \\( n \\) goes to infinity of this sum.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac {1}{k(k+1)}}\u003d\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\sum _{{k\u003d1}}^{n}{\\frac {1}{k(k+1)}}\u003d\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left(1-{\\frac {1}{1+n}}\\right)\u003d1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo the series converges to 1. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eCalculus\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eEvaluate \\( \\sum _{{m\u003d1}}^{\\infty }\\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac {m^{2}\\,n}{3^{m}\\left(m\\,3^{n}+n\\,3^{m}\\right)}} \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolution: First rewrite the summand as \\( {\\frac {m}{3^{m}}}{\\frac {m\\,n}{m\\,3^{n}+n\\,3^{m}}} \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThen make the substitution \\( a_{j}\u003d{\\frac {3^{j}}{j}} \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow call the sum \\( S \\) , for notational purposes.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003eWith this notation it follows \\( S\u003d\\sum _{{m\u003d1}}^{\\infty }\\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac {1}{a_{m}}}{\\frac {1}{a_{m}+a_{n}}} \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThen recognize \\( S\u003d\\sum _{{m\u003d1}}^{\\infty }\\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac {1}{a_{n}}}{\\frac {1}{a_{m}+a_{n}}} \\) . Only here the indices have been reversed, first in name and then in order.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAdding the two previous expressions for \\( S \\) gives \\( 2S\u003d\\sum _{{m\u003d1}}^{\\infty }\\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{\\infty }\\left({\\frac {1}{a_{m}}}+{\\frac {1}{a_{n}}}\\right)\\left({\\frac {1}{a_{m}+a_{n}}}\\right) \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut \\( {\\frac {1}{a_{m}}}+{\\frac {1}{a_{n}}}\u003d{\\frac {a_{m}+a_{n}}{a_{m}\\,a_{n}}} \\) . So it follows that \\( 2S\u003d\\sum _{{m\u003d1}}^{\\infty }\\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac {1}{a_{m}\\,a_{n}}} \\) which is equivalent to \\( \\left(\\sum _{{m\u003d1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac {1}{a_{m}}}\\right)^{2} \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo now all that is left is to evaluate \\( \\sum _{{m\u003d1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac {1}{a_{m}}}\u003d\\sum _{{m\u003d1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac {m}{3^{m}}} \\) , and call this \\( A\\, \\) . So \\( A\u003d{\\frac {3}{4}} \\) , and since \\( 2S\u003dA^{2}\\, \\) it follows that \\( S\u003d{\\frac {9}{32}} \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eCalculus\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDetermine the interval of convergence for the power series \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac {n(3x-4)^{n}}{{\\sqrt[ {3}]{n^{4}}}(2x)^{{n-1}}}}. \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNote \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac {n(3x-4)^{n}}{{\\sqrt[ {3}]{n^{4}}}(2x)^{{n-1}}}}\u003d2x\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{\\infty }\\left({\\frac {3x-4}{2x}}\\right)^{n}n^{{-{\\frac {1}{3}}}} \\) . Use the Ratio Test to check for absolute convergence: \u003c/p\u003e    \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac {a_{{n+1}}}{a_{n}}}\\right| \\)   \\( \u003d\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac {3x-4}{2x}}\\cdot {\\sqrt[ {3}]{{\\frac {n}{n+1}}}}\\right| \\)      \\( \u003d\\left|{\\frac {3x-4}{2x}}\\right|\u003d\\left|{\\frac {3}{2}}-{\\frac {2}{x}}\\right|\u0026lt;1 \\)     \\( \\Rightarrow -1\u0026lt;{\\frac {3}{2}}-{\\frac {2}{x}}\u0026lt;1 \\)   \\( \\Rightarrow -{\\frac {5}{2}}\u0026lt;-{\\frac {2}{x}}\u0026lt;-{\\frac {1}{2}} \\)      \\( \\Rightarrow {\\frac {1}{4}}\u0026lt;{\\frac {1}{x}}\u0026lt;{\\frac {5}{4}} \\)      \\( \\Rightarrow {\\frac {4}{5}}\u0026lt;x\u0026lt;4 \\) .  \n\u003cp\u003eWe need to check both endpoints for convergence as well. If \\( x\u003d4\\, \\) , then the power series becomes \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac {8}{n^{{\\frac {1}{3}}}}} \\) . Note this is a \\( p \\) -series with \\( p\u0026lt;1 \\) , implying divergence. If \\( x\u003d{\\frac {4}{5}} \\) , the power series becomes \\( \\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac {8}{5}}(-1)^{n}{\\frac {1}{n^{{\\frac {1}{3}}}}} \\) . This is an alternating \\( p \\) -series, implying conditional convergence. Thus, the interval of convergence is \\( x\\in \\left[{\\frac {4}{5}},4\\right) \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eBack to Calculus\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFormulate an integral equation from the BVP: \\( u\u0027\u0027+p(x)u\u0027+q(x)u\u003df(x),\\,\\,x\u0026gt;a,\\,\\,u(a)\u003du_{0},\\,\\,u\u0027(a)\u003du_{1} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolve for \\( u\u0027\u0027\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u\u0027\u0027\u003d-p(x)u\u0027-q(x)u+f(x)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIntegrate both sides from \\( a \\) to \\( x \\) with respect to a new dummy variable \\( y \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int _{a}^{x}u\u0027\u0027(y)\\,dy\u003d-\\int _{a}^{x}p(y)u\u0027(y)\\,dy-\\int _{a}^{x}\\left[q(y)u(y)-f(y)\\right]\\,dy\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u\u0027(x)-u\u0027(a)\u003d-\\left[p(y)u(y){\\big |}_{{y\u003da}}^{x}-\\int _{a}^{x}p\u0027(y)u(y)dy\\right]-\\int _{a}^{x}\\left[q(y)u(y)-f(y)\\right]\\,dy\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u\u0027(x)\u003du_{1}-\\left[p(x)u(x)-p(a)u(a)\\right]+\\int _{a}^{x}u(y)\\left[p\u0027(y)-q(y)\\right]+f(y)\\,dy\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIntegrate again.       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eApproximate \\( y(x)\u003dx^{2}+\\int _{0}^{1}\\sin(xz)y(z)dz\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e One method: Expand both \\( \\,y(x) \\) and \\( \\,\\sin(xz) \\) in Taylor series; \\( \\,y \\) in powers of \\( \\,x \\) , and \\( \\,\\sin(xz) \\) in powers of \\( \\,xz \\) . We can save ourselves some effort if we note from the integral equation that \\( \\,y(0)\u003d0 \\) ; and from repeatedly differentiating the integral equation, that \\( \\,y\u0027\u0027(0)\u003d2\\, \\) (so the coefficient of the \\( x^{2} \\) term in the \\( y \\) expansion is 1), and that \\( \\,y^{{(2n)}}(0)\u003d0 \\) for \\( n\u003d2,3,\\dots \\, \\) (because we get the sine in the integrand for those terms). Thus, the Taylor series expansion for \\( \\,y(x) \\) (about \\( \\,x\u003d0 \\) ) has the form \\( \\,y(x)\u003dc_{1}\\,x+x^{2}+c_{2}\\,x^{3}+c_{3}\\,x^{5}+\\dots \\) . \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The expansion for \\( \\,\\sin(xz) \\) is \\( \\sin(xz)\u003dxz-(xz)^{3}/3!+(xz)^{5}/5!+\\dots \\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Inserting these in the integral equation, we get \\( \\,c_{1}x+x^{2}+c_{2}x^{3}+c_{3}x^{5}+\\dots \u003dx^{2}+\\int _{0}^{1}(xz-{\\frac {x^{3}z^{3}}{6}}+{\\frac {x^{5}z^{5}}{120}}+\\dots )(c_{1}z+z^{2}+c_{2}z^{3}+c_{3}z^{5}+\\dots )\\,dz \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e or after some expanding and rearrangement (and subtracting the \\( \\,x^{2} \\) term from both sides)\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\,c_{1}x+c_{2}x^{3}+c_{3}x^{5}+\\dots \u003dx\\int _{0}^{1}(c_{1}z^{2}+z^{3}+c_{2}z^{4}+c_{3}z^{6}+\\dots )\\,dz\\,-{\\frac {x^{3}}{6}}\\int _{0}^{1}(c_{1}z^{4}+z^{5}+c_{2}z^{6}+c_{3}z^{8}+\\dots )\\,dz \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( +{\\frac {x^{5}}{120}}\\int _{0}^{1}(c_{1}z^{6}+z^{7}+c_{2}z^{8}+c_{3}z^{{10}}+\\dots )\\,dz-+\\dots \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e All of the integrals on the right side are readily evaluated. For example, retaining only terms through \\( \\,x^{5} \\) , we get\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\,c_{1}x+c_{2}x^{3}+c_{3}x^{5}\u003dx({\\frac {c_{1}}{3}}+{\\frac {1}{4}}+{\\frac {c_{2}}{5}}+{\\frac {c_{3}}{7}})\\,-x^{3}({\\frac {c_{1}}{30}}+{\\frac {1}{36}}+{\\frac {c_{2}}{42}}+{\\frac {c_{3}}{54}})+x^{5}({\\frac {c_{1}}{840}}+{\\frac {1}{960}}+{\\frac {c_{2}}{1080}}+{\\frac {c_{3}}{1320}}) \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Equating coefficients for each power of \\( \\,x \\) on the left and right sides gives a system of equations for the coefficients \\( \\,c_{1},c_{2},c_{3}. \\) Upon solving that system, we get \\( y(x)\\approx 0.36361\\,x+x^{2}-0.038996\\,x^{3}+0.0014395\\,x^{5} \\) . Repeating the calculation, this time including terms through \\( \\,x^{7} \\) , gives \\( c_{4}\u003d-2.7175\\times 10^{{-5}}\\, \\) and leaves the lower-order coefficients essentially unchanged, evidence that the above approximation for \\( \\,y(x) \\) is quite good for \\( x\\in [0,1] \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the value of lambda for which the homogeneous Fredholm integral equation \\( y(x)\u003d\\lambda \\int _{0}^{1}e^{x}e^{t}y(t)dt\\, \\) has a nontrivial solution, and find all the solutions.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirst, divide both sides by \\( \\,e^{x} \\) :\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {y(x)}{e^{x}}}\u003d\\lambda \\int _{0}^{1}e^{t}y(t)dt\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e The right side is a constant; therefore, the left side must also be a constant. Thus \\( {\\frac {y(x)}{e^{x}}}\u003dC \\) , so \\( \\,y(x)\u003dCe^{x} \\) .\u003cbr\u003e Insert this in the integral equation: \\( Ce^{x}\u003d\\lambda \\int _{0}^{1}e^{x}e^{t}Ce^{t}\\,dt \\) \u003cbr\u003e Since we want a nontrivial solution, we may assume that \\( C\\neq 0 \\) , so divide both sides by \\( \\,Ce^{x} \\) ; this yields \\( 1\u003d\\lambda \\int _{0}^{1}e^{{2t}}\\,dt \\) \u003cbr\u003e Evaluate the integral; this gives \\( 1\u003d\\lambda {\\frac {e^{2}-1}{2}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e Thus, a nontrivial solution exists only for \\( \\lambda \u003d{\\frac {2}{e^{2}-1}} \\) and the general solution in this case is \\( \\,y(x)\u003dCe^{x} \\) where \\( \\,C \\) is an arbitrary constant. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eCalculus\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;: \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eIntegral Equations\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eBecause of symmetry,we need to compute the volume in the first octant only.Hence,if V is the total volume,then \\( V\u003d8\\iint _{R}\\int _{{0}}^{{c{\\sqrt {1-({\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}-{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{2}}})}}}}dzdydx\\, \\) where R is the region bounded by the ellipse \\( {\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}\u003d1\\, \\) in the first quadrant.Therefore, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( V\u003d8\\int _{0}^{a}\\int _{{0}}^{{b{\\sqrt {1-{\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}}}}}c{\\sqrt {1-{\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}-{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}}}dydx\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003d \\( 8c\\int _{0}^{a}\\int _{{0}}^{{b{\\sqrt {1-{\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}}}}}{\\sqrt {1-{\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}-{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}}}dydx\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe shall first evaluate the inner integral,let \\( I_{1}\u003d\\int _{{0}}^{{b{\\sqrt {p}}}}{\\sqrt {p-{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}}}dy\\, \\) where \\( p\u003d1-{\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSetting \\( {\\frac {y}{b}}\u003d{\\sqrt {p}}\\sin \\theta \\, \\) ,we obtain \\( dyb{\\sqrt {p}}\\cos \\theta d\\theta \\, \\) ,then \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( I_{1}\u003d\\int _{{0}}^{{{\\frac {\\pi }{2}}}}({\\sqrt {p}}\\cos \\theta )b{\\sqrt {p}}\\cos \\theta d\\theta \\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003d \\( bp\\int _{{0}}^{{{\\frac {\\pi }{2}}}}\\cos ^{2}\\theta d\\theta \\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003d \\( bp\\int _{{0}}^{{{\\frac {\\pi }{2}}}}{\\frac {1+\\cos 2\\theta }{2}}d\\theta \\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003d \\( {\\frac {bp}{2}}[\\theta +{\\frac {\\sin 2\\theta }{2}}]_{{0}}^{{{\\frac {\\pi }{2}}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003d \\( {\\frac {bp}{2}}{\\frac ,-y^{2}-z^{2}\u003d-r^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eand for the limits of integration r \u003d 1 and the intersection is the unit circle on the y-z plane so: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}\\int _{{0}}^{{1}}r^{2}\\cos ^{2}\\theta {r^{2}}\\sin ^{2}\\theta (1-r^{2})rdrd\\theta \\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}\\int {1}{24}}\\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}\\cos ^{2}\\theta \\sin ^{2}\\theta d\\theta \\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNOTE THAT: \\( \\sin ^{2}\\theta \\cos ^{2}\\theta \u003d(\\sin \\theta \\cos \\theta )^{2}\\, \\) and \\( \\sin(2\\theta )\u003d2\\sin \\theta \\cos \\theta \\, \\) by double-angle formula.     {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( \\iint _{{R}}(x+y)e^{{x^{2}-y^{2}}}dA\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ewhere \\( _{{R}}\\, \\) is the rectangle enclosed by the lines \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x-y\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x-y\u003d2\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x+y\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x+y\u003d3\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor change of variables, Let \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u\u003dx-y\\, \\) and \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( v\u003dx+y\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo then by solving for x and y we get... \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}(u+v)\\, \\) and \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}(v-u)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 0\\leq u\\leq 2\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 0\\leq v\\leq 3\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int _{{0}}^{{3}}\\int _{{0}}^{{2}}(v)e^{{uv}}\\cdot |J|dudv\\, \\) Where |J| is the Jacobian determinant \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {\\partial (x,y)}{\\partial (u,v)}}\u003d\\left[{\\begin{matrix}{\\frac {1}{2}}\u0026amp;{\\frac {1}{2}}\\\\[6pt]-{\\frac {1}{2}}\u0026amp;{\\frac {1}{2}}\\end{matrix}}\\right]\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}\\, \\)       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the path that minimizes the arclength of the curve between \\( (x_{0},y_{0})\u003d(0,0)\\, \\) and \\( (x_{1},y_{1})\u003d(1,1)\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe goal is to minimize arclength as \\( x\\, \\) goes from \\( 0 \\) to \\( 1 \\) . This quantity is described in this integral:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int _{0}^{1}(1+y\u0027^{2})^{{1/2}}dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eEuler-Lagrange equation\u003c/a\u003e is defined as:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( EL:{\\frac {d}{dx}}{\\frac {\\partial f}{\\partial y\u0027}}-{\\frac {\\partial f}{\\partial y}}\u003d0\\, \\) where \\( f\\, \\) is the integrand in the integral above.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompute the derivatives for the given problem.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {\\partial f}{\\partial y}}\u003d0\\, \\) since \\( f\\, \\) is independent of \\( y\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {\\partial f}{\\partial y\u0027}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}(1+y\u0027^{2})^{{-1/2}}2y\u0027\u003d(1+y\u0027^{2})^{{-1/2}}y\u0027\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {d}{dx}}{\\frac {\\partial f}{\\partial y\u0027}}\u003d(1+y\u0027^{2})^{{-1/2}}y\u0027\u0027-(1+y\u0027^{2})^{{-3/2}}y\u0027^{2}y\u0027\u0027\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimplify the expression by factoring out \\( y\u0027\u0027\\, \\) and putting the common denominator \\( (1+y\u0027^{2})^{{3/2}}\\, \\) on the bottom.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( EL:{\\frac {y\u0027\u0027(1+y\u0027^{2}-y\u0027^{2})}{(1+y\u0027^{2})^{{3/2}}}}\u003d{\\frac {y\u0027\u0027}{(1+y\u0027^{2})^{{3/2}}}}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis equation will hold only if \\( y\u0027\\, \\) is constant so that \\( y\u0027\u0027\u003d0\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn that case, \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y(x)\u003dc_{1}x+c_{2}\\, \\) and since \\( y(0)\u003d0,y(1)\u003d1\\, \\) ,\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( c_{2}\u003d0\\, \\) and \\( 1\u003dc_{1}+c_{2}\\, \\) so that \\( c_{1}\u003d1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore, \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y(x)\u003dx\\, \\) _{a}^{b}L(y,y\u0027,x)\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( h\\, \\) be a function such that \\( h(a)\u003d0,h(b)\u003d0\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConsider a small change in the function \\( y\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( T(y+\\epsilon h)\u003d\\int _{a}^{b}L(y+\\epsilon h,y\u0027+\\epsilon h\u0027,x)\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn general, the Taylor expansion for a function \\( g\\, \\) of three variables is\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( g(x+\\epsilon _{1},y+\\epsilon _{2},z+\\epsilon _{3})\u003dg(x,y,z)+\\left(\\epsilon _{1}{\\frac {\\partial g}{\\partial x}}+\\epsilon _{2}{\\frac {\\partial g}{\\partial y}}+\\epsilon _{3}{\\frac {\\partial g}{\\partial z}}\\right){\\bigg |}_{{(x,y,z)}}+... \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( T(y+\\epsilon h)\u003d\\int _{a}^{b}\\left[L(y,y\u0027,x)+{\\frac {\\partial L}{\\partial y}}\\epsilon h(x)+{\\frac {\\partial L}{\\partial y\u0027}}\\epsilon h\u0027(x)+...\\right]\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003dT(y)+\\epsilon \\int _{a}^{b}\\left(h(x){\\frac {\\partial L}{\\partial y}}+h\u0027(x){\\frac {\\partial L}{\\partial y\u0027}}\\right)\\,dx+...\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int _{a}^{b}h(x){\\frac {\\partial L}{\\partial y}}\\,dx+\\int _{a}^{b}h\u0027(x){\\frac {\\partial L}{\\partial y\u0027}}{\\bigg |}_{a}^{b}-\\int _{a}^{b}h(x){\\frac {d}{dx}}{\\frac {\\partial L}{\\partial y\u0027}}\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe evaluated       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eMinimize \\( J(y)\u003d\\int _{0}^{\\infty }\\left(y^{2}+y\u0027^{2}+(y\u0027\u0027+y\u0027)^{2}\\right)dx,y(0)\u003d1,y\u0027(0)\u003d2,y(\\infty )\u003d0,y\u0027(\\infty )\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let \\( F(x,y,y\u0027,y\u0027\u0027)\\, \\) denote the integrand in the above. The Euler equation (see \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eCoV4\u003c/a\u003e) for this problem is\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {d^{2}}{dx^{2}}}\\left({\\frac {\\partial F}{\\partial y\u0027\u0027}}\\right)-{\\frac {d}{dx}}\\left({\\frac {\\partial F}{\\partial y\u0027}}\\right)+{\\frac {\\partial F}{\\partial y}}\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\implies {\\frac {d^{2}}{dx^{2}}}2(y\u0027\u0027+y\u0027)-{\\frac {d}{dx}}[2y\u0027+2(y\u0027\u0027+y\u0027)]+2y\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\implies y^{{(iv)}}-2y\u0027\u0027+y\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The characteristic equation for this differential equation is \\( m^{4}-2m^{2}+1\u003d0 \\) which factors to \\( (m-1)^{2}(m+1)^{2}\u003d0 \\) ; so the roots are \\( m\u003d1,1,-1,-1 \\) . Thus, the general solution of the differential equation is \\( y\u003d(c_{1}+c_{2}x)e^{x}+(c_{3}+c_{4}x)e^{{-x}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The conditions at infinity require that \\( c_{1}\u003dc_{2}\u003d0\\, \\) . Thus, \\( y\u003d(c_{3}+c_{4}x)e^{{-x}},\\quad y\u0027\u003d\\left((c_{4}-c_{3})-c_{4}x\\right)e^{{-x}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Applying the remaining conditions,\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( c_{3}\u003d1,\\quad c_{4}-c_{3}\u003d2\\, \\) so \\( c_{3}\u003d1,c_{4}\u003d3\\, \\) and so the desired solution is \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y\u003d(1+3x)e^{{-x}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Satisfying the Euler equation is a \u003ci\u003enecessary\u003c/i\u003e condition for the given solution to minimize \\( J(y)\\, \\) ; proving that it actually does minimize \\( J(y)\\, \\) is a lot more difficult (and will not be dealt with here). \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eCalculus of Variations\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eMain page\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eMinimize \\( J(y)\u003d\\int 2\\pi y{\\sqrt {1+y\u0027^{2}}}dx\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur functional does not depend explicitly on x, so we can use the first integral \\( F-y\u0027F_{{y\u0027}}\u003dc_{1}\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y{\\sqrt {1+y\u0027^{2}}}-{\\frac {yy\u0027^{2}}{{\\sqrt {1+y\u0027^{2}}}}}\u003dc_{1} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {y}{{\\sqrt {1+y\u0027^{2}}}}}\u003dc_{1} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y\u0027\u003d{\\frac {{\\sqrt {y^{2}-c_{2}^{2}}}}{c_{2}^{2}}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( dx\u003d\\int {\\frac {c_{2}dy}{{\\sqrt {y^{2}-c_{1}^{2}}}}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLetting \\( y\u003dc_{1}\\cosh t,dy\u003dc_{1}\\sinh tdt\\, \\) , we get:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( dx\u003d\\int {\\frac {c_{1}^{2}\\sinh tdt}{c_{1}\\sinh t}}\u003d\\int c_{1}dt \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( x\u003dc_{1}t+c_{2}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y\u003dc_{1}\\operatorname {arccos}{\\frac {x-c_{2}}{c_{1}}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis problem is equivalent to finding the equation of a hanging cable of uniform density with fixed endpoints.       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the extremals of the functional \\( J(y)\u003d\\int _{0}^{\\pi }\\left[y\u0027(x)\\right]^{2}dx\\, \\) subject to the constraint \\( \\int _{0}^{\\pi }\\left[y(x)\\right]^{2}dx\u003d1,y(0)\u003dy(\\pi )\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( H(y,\\lambda )\u003d\\int _{0}^{\\pi }([y\u0027(x)]^{2}+\\lambda [y(x)]^{2})\\,dx \\) where \\( \\lambda \\, \\) is a \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eLagrange multiplier\u003c/a\u003e. The Euler equation is\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {d}{dx}}{\\frac {\\partial (y\u0027^{2}+\\lambda y^{2})}{\\partial y\u0027}}-{\\frac {\\partial (y\u0027^{2}+\\lambda y^{2})}{\\partial y}}\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\implies y\u0027\u0027-\\lambda y\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e (i) Try \\( \\lambda \u0026gt;0\\, \\) ; let \\( \\lambda \u003d\\alpha ^{2}\\, \\) . Then\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y\u0027\u0027-\\alpha ^{2}y\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( \\implies y\u003dae^{{\\alpha x}}+be^{{-\\alpha x}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y(0)\u003d0\\implies a+b\u003d0;\\quad y(\\pi )\u003d0\\implies ae^{{\\alpha \\pi }}+be^{{-\\alpha \\pi }}\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e But the solution for this is \\( a\u003db\u003d0\\, \\) , i.e., \\( y\\equiv 0\\, \\) which does not satisfy the constraint \\( \\int _{0}^{\\pi }y^{2}\\,dx\u003d1 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e (ii) Try \\( \\lambda \u003d0\\, \\) Then\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y\u0027\u0027\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( \\implies y\u003dax+b\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y(0)\u003d0\\implies b\u003d0\\, \\) so \\( y\u003dax\\, \\) ; then \\( y(\\pi )\u003d0\\implies a\u003d0\\implies y\\equiv 0 \\) which, again, does not satisfy the constraint.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e (iii) \\( \\lambda \u0026lt;0\\, \\) ; let \\( \\lambda \u003d-\\alpha ^{2}\\, \\) . Then\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y\u0027\u0027+\\alpha ^{2}y\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( \\implies y\u003da\\cos(\\alpha x)+b\\sin(\\alpha x) \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y(0)\u003d0\\implies a\u003d0 \\) ; \\( y(\\pi )\u003d0\\implies b\u003d0 \\) or \\( \\sin(\\alpha \\pi )\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( b\u003d0\\implies y\\equiv 0 \\) , so we reject this and take \\( \\sin(\\alpha \\pi )\u003d0\\, \\) , which implies \\( \\alpha \u003d\\pm 1,\\pm 2,\\dots \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Thus \\( y\u003db\\sin(nx)\\, \\) where \\( n\\, \\) is any nonzero integer.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( b\\, \\) is found by imposing the constraint:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int _{0}^{\\pi }b^{2}\\sin ^{2}(nx)\\,dx\u003d1\\implies \\int _{0}^{\\pi }b^{2}\\,{\\frac {1-\\cos(2nx)}{2}}\\,dx\u003d1\\implies {\\frac {b^{2}}{2}}\\left[x-{\\frac {\\sin(2nx)}{2n}}\\right]_{0}^{\\pi }\u003d1 \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( \\implies b\u003d\\pm {\\sqrt {2/\\pi }} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Hence, the extremals of \\( J\\, \\) subject to the given constraint are\u003cbr\u003e \\( y\u003d\\pm {\\sqrt {2/\\pi }}\\sin(nx),n\u003d\\pm 1,\\pm 2,\\dots \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eCalculus of Variations\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eMain page\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDetermine the function \\( {\\hat {y}}\\in C^{2}[0,1]\\, \\) that minimizes the functional \\( J(y)\u003d\\int _{0}^{1}\\left[y\u0027(x)\\right]^{2}dx+[y(1)]^{2},y(0)\u003d1,h(0)\u003d0\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirst, compute the first variation so that it can be set to zero: \u003c/p\u003e     \\( \\delta J(y,h)\\, \\)   \\( \u003d{\\frac {d}{d\\varepsilon }}J(y+\\varepsilon h)\\left.\\right|_{{\\varepsilon \u003d0}} \\)      \\( \u003d{\\frac {d}{d\\varepsilon }}\\left[\\int _{0}^{1}(y^{\\prime }(x)+\\varepsilon h^{\\prime }(x))^{2}\\ dx+(y(1)+\\varepsilon h(1))^{2}\\right]\\left.\\right|_{{\\varepsilon \u003d0}} \\)      \\( \u003d\\left[\\int _{0}^{1}2(y^{\\prime }(x)+\\varepsilon h^{\\prime }(x))h^{\\prime }(x)\\ dx+2(y(1)+\\varepsilon h(1))h(1)\\right]\\left.\\right|_{{\\varepsilon \u003d0}} \\)      \\( \u003d\\int _{0}^{1}2y^{\\prime }(x)h^{\\prime }(x)\\ dx+2y(1)h(1) \\)   \n\u003cp\u003eTo get this only in terms of \\( h\\, \\) , integrate by parts. Let \u003c/p\u003e    \\( u\u003d2y^{\\prime }(x) \\)     \\( du\u003d2y^{{\\prime \\prime }}(x)\\ dx \\)    \\( dv\u003dh^{\\prime }(x)\\ dx \\)     \\( v\u003dh(x)\\, \\)  \n\u003cp\u003eThus, setting the first variation to zero \u003c/p\u003e     \\( 2y^{\\prime }(x)h(x)\\left.\\right|_{0}^{1}-\\int _{0}^{1}2y^{{\\prime \\prime }}(x)h(x)\\ dx+2y(1)h(1) \\)   \\( \u003d0\\, \\)    \\( 2y^{\\prime }(1)h(1)-\\int _{0}^{1}2y^{{\\prime \\prime }}(x)h(x)\\ dx+2y(1)h(1) \\)   \\( \u003d0\\, \\)   \n\u003cp\u003eSince \\( h(1)\\, \\) is unspecified, suppose \\( h(1)\u003d0\\, \\) .       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eThe sum of a two-digit number and the number obtained by interchanging the digits of the number is 110.The digits of the number differ by 6.How many such numbers are there? Find all of them \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet the ten\u0027s and unit\u0027s digit in the number be \\( x,y\\, \\) respectively. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThus,the number in the expanded notation is \\( 10x+y\\, \\) (Original number) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen the digits are reversed, \\( x\\, \\) becomes \\( y\\, \\) and \\( y\\, \\) becomes \\( x\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the number is \\( x+10y\\, \\) (Reversed number) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven that \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (10x+y)+(x+10y)\u003d110\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x+y\u003d10\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe are given that the numbers differ by 6 \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore \\( x-y\u003d6\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolving these two equations, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (x+y-10)+(x-y-6)\u003d0,2x-16\u003d0,2x\u003d16,x\u003d8\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubstituting this value in the first equation \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 8+y\u003d10,y\u003d2\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this case, we get the number \\( 82\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf \\( y-x\u003d6\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x\u003d2,y\u003d8\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this case, the number is \\( 28\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ewe may verify that both numbers satisfy the given condition in the problem. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eAlgebra\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cpre\u003eThe area of a rectangle gets reduced by 9 square units,if its length is reduced by 5 units and breadth is increased by  3 units.If we increase the length by 3 units  and breadth by 2 units, then the area is increased by 67 square units. Find the length and breadth of the rectangle.\n\u003c/pre\u003e \n\u003cp\u003eLet the length and breadth of the rectangle are \\( x,y\\, \\) respectively. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven that \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (x-5)(y+3)\u003dxy-9\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( xy+3x-5y-15\u003dxy-9,3x-5y\u003d6\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe other condition is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (x+3)(y+2)\u003dxy+67\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( xy+2x+3y+6\u003d67+xy,2x+3y\u003d61\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolving the two, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 2(3x-5y-6)-3(2x+3y-61)\u003d0,-10y-12-9y+183\u003d0,-19y+171\u003d0,-19y\u003d171,y\u003d9\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe value of x is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 3x-5(9)\u003d6,3x\u003d51,x\u003d17\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore, the length and breadth of the rectangle are 17 and 9 units respectively. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eAlgebra\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eIf in a rectangle the length is increased and breadth is reduced by 2 units each, the area is reduced by 28 square units.If the length is reduced by 1 unit and breadth is increased by 2 units, the area increases by 33 square units. Find the dimensions of the rectangle. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet the length and breadth of the rectangle be \\( x,y\\, \\) respectively. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs per the first condition \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (x+2)(y-2)\u003dxy-28\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( xy-2x+2y-4\u003dxy-28,-2x+2y\u003d-24\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x-y\u003d12\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimilarly,the second condition is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (x-1)(y+2)\u003dxy+33\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( xy+2x-y-2\u003dxy+33,2x-y\u003d35\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolving the two equations, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (x-y-12)-(2x-y-35)\u003d0,x-2x-12+35\u003d0,-x+23\u003d0,x\u003d23\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the value of y is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 23-y\u003d12,y\u003d11\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the length and breadth of the rectangle are 23 and 11 units respectively. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eAlgebra\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {1}{x+2}}\u003d{\\frac {5x}{9}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirst, notice that \\( x\\neq -2\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSecond, multiply both sides by \\( x+2\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 1\u003d{\\frac {5x(x+2)}{9}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMultiply both sides by \\( 9\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 9\u003d5x(x+2)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExpand the right hand side.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 9\u003d5x^{2}+10x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubtract \\( 5x^{2}+10x\\, \\) from both sides so that the equation can be factored. Since \\( x\\, \\) is raised to the second power, expect 2 answers.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -5x^{2}-10x+9\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUse the quadratic formula to factor:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( ax^{2}+bx+c\u003d0\\, \\) gives \\( x\u003d{\\frac {-b\\pm {\\sqrt {b^{2}-4ac}}}{2a}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo in the given problem,\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x\u003d{\\frac {10\\pm {\\sqrt {100-4*(-45)}}}{-10}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Simplifying under the radical,\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( x\u003d{\\frac {10\\pm {\\sqrt {280}}}{-10}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e To furthur simplify the radical, factor \\( 280 \\) as \\( 2^{3}*5*7 \\) . So \\( 2^{2} \\) can be taken out of it as \\( 2 \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( x\u003d{\\frac {10\\pm 2{\\sqrt {70}}}{-10}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Seperate this fraction by dividing both parts of the numerator by the denominator.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( x\u003d-1\\pm {\\frac {2}{-10}}{\\sqrt {70}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimplify the fraction on the right to get the final answer.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x\u003d-1\\pm {\\frac {1}{-5}}{\\sqrt {70}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOr, absorb the negative sign in front of the fraction into the \\( \\pm \\) symbol to get an alternate answer.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x\u003d-1\\mp {\\frac {1}{5}}{\\sqrt {70}},x\\neq -2\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eAlgebra\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eThis problem is a problem that is really tough to solve by standard methods, but if you notice a few things, then take a guess, then check the guess, it\u0027s not that bad. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe first thing to notice is that \\( 8x^{3} \\) and \\( -125 \\) are both cubes. That puts me in the disposition to look to see if this whole monster is a perfect cube. If it is a cube, then it would be \\( (2x-5)^{3} \\) , since \\( (2x)^{3}\u003d8x^{3} \\) and \\( (-5)^{3}\u003d-125 \\) . That\u0027s our guess, and so let\u0027s expand it using the binomial theorem, and see if if works. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExpanding, we get \\( (2x-5)^{3}\u003d(2x)^{3}+(2x)^{2}(-5)(3)+(2x)(-5)^{2}(3)+(-5)^{3} \\) , which simplifies to what we want, \\( 8x^{3}-60x^{2}+150x-125 \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e--\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eSpudbeach\u003c/a\u003e 23:53, 23 September 2007 (MDT) \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}\u0026lt;10-3x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMove everything to one side. It\u0027s good to keep the coefficient of \\( x^{2} \\) positive. It\u0027s better to have it be equal to one.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+3x-10\u0026lt;0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFactor the polynomial. To do so, find a pair of numbers that will multiply together to give the constant term \\( -10 \\) . \\( (1,-10),(-1,10),(2,-5),(-2,5)\\, \\) . But the pair \\( (-2,5)\\, \\) will also sum to \\( 3 \\) , which is the coefficient of \\( x \\) . So the factors are\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+3x-10\u003d(x-2)(x+5)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eVerify this by taking the product of the right hand side in your head. Take as long as you need but don\u0027t resort to pencil and paper.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow, set up the equation (with the \u0027equals\u0027 sign)\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (x-2)(x+5)\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe roots (critical points) are \\( x\u003d2,-5\\, \\) since these values of \\( x \\) will make one of the factors equal zero.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese critical points split up all the numbers into intervals, and the answer will be some combination of these intervals of all numbers below \\( -5 \\) , between \\( -5 \\) and \\( 2 \\) , and all numbers above \\( 2 \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAccording to the original problem, the answer should be the intervals that have values that can be plugged in to \\( x \\) to get numbers less than \\( 0 \\) . Testing one point in the interval will determine whether all the numbers belong or not. Pick easy numbers to test.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the interval \\( (-\\infty ,-5)\\, \\) , choose (for example) \\( -10 \\) . \\( (-10-2)(-10+5)\\, \\) gives a negative number times a negative number, so all these numbers will be positive. They won\u0027t be included.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor the number \\( x\u003d-5\\, \\) the equation equals zero, so it is not included. (We only want less than zero).\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the interval \\( (-5,2)\\, \\) , the easiest point is usually \\( 0 \\) . Setting \\( x\u003d0\\, \\) gives a negative number, so all these numbers should be included.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor the number \\( x\u003d2\\, \\) the equation equals zero, so it is not included.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the interval \\( (2,\\infty )\\, \\) choose \\( x\u003d10\\, \\) and the equation gives a positive number, so all these numbers are not included.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo the the answer is\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInterval notation: \\( x\\in (-5,2)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInequality notation: \\( -5\u0026lt;x\u0026lt;2\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eAlgebra\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {x+4}{1-x}}\\leq 0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirst, find the critical points. These are the numbers that make the top or bottom of the fraction equal zero.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe top equals zero if \\( x\u003d-4\\, \\) . In this case the value of the left hand side is zero.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe bottom equals zero if \\( x\u003d1\\, \\) . It is against the rules to let the bottom of a fraction equal zero. So at this point the function is undefined.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTest easy points in the intervals \\( (-\\infty ,-4),(-4,1),(1,\\infty )\\, \\) as well as the critical points themselves to see if they give an answer less than or equal to zero. One point in an interval gives the same sign as any other point in the same interval.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x\u003d-10\\in (-\\infty ,-4)\\, \\) gives a negative number, so all these numbers \u003cu\u003eare\u003c/u\u003e included.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x\u003d-4\\, \\) gives 0 so it \u003cu\u003eis\u003c/u\u003e included.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x\u003d0\\in (-4,1)\\, \\) gives a positive number, so these numbers are \u003cu\u003enot\u003c/u\u003e included.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x\u003d1\\, \\) gives an undefined fraction, so it is \u003cu\u003enot\u003c/u\u003e included.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x\u003d10\\in (1,\\infty )\\, \\) gives a negative number, so all these points \u003cu\u003eare\u003c/u\u003e included.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe answer is\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInterval notation: \\( (-\\infty ,-4]\\cup \\,(1,\\infty )\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInequality notation: \\( -\\infty \u0026lt;x\\leq 4,\\,\\,\\,\\,1\u0026lt;x\u0026lt;\\infty \\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eAlgebra\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}\\leq 4x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTwo easy to see answers are \\( x\u003d0\\, \\) and \\( x\u003d4\\, \\) . Save \\( x\u003d0\\, \\) as one solution and assume that \\( x\\neq 0\\, \\) . You can\u0027t divide by \\( x\\, \\) because you don\u0027t know if it is positive or negative. Assume \\( x\u0026lt;0\\, \\) . Now dividing by \\( x\\, \\) gives\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x\\geq 4\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo two numbers greater than and equal to 4 should be tried in place of \\( x\\, \\) in the original problem.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLetting \\( x\u003d4\\, \\) gives \\( 16\\leq 16\\, \\) which is true, but letting \\( x\u003d5\\, \\) gives \\( 25\\leq 20\\, \\) which is false, so only the number 4 will be kept as a possible answer.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow assume \\( x\u0026gt;0\\, \\) . Dividing by \\( x\\, \\) gives\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x\\leq 4\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo two numbers in \\( (-\\infty ,0)\\, \\) and \\( (0,4)\\, \\) should be tried in place of \\( x\\, \\) in the original problem.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLetting \\( x\u003d1\\, \\) gives \\( 1\\leq 4\\, \\) but letting \\( x\u003d-1\\, \\) gives \\( 1\\leq -4\\, \\) which is false, so only the range \\( (0,4)\\, \\) will be kept as a possible answer.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCombining all the answers \\( 0,(0,4),4\\, \\) into one interval the solution is:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInterval notation: \\( x\\in [0,4]\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInequality notation: \\( 0\\leq x\\leq 4\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eAlgebra\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eResolve the expressions into partial fractions \\( {\\frac {1-x+6x^{2}}{x-x^{3}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Readjusting the denominator \\( {\\frac {1-x+6x^{2}}{x-x^{3}}}\u003d{\\frac {1-x+6x^{2}}{(x)(1-x^{2})}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Splitting the denominators into factors, \\( {\\frac {1-x+6x^{2}}{x(1-x^{2})}}\u003d{\\frac {1-x+6x^{2}}{x(1+x)(1-x)}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let \\( {\\frac {1-x+6x^{2}}{x(1+x)(1-x)}}\u003d{\\frac {A}{x}}+{\\frac {B}{1+x}}+{\\frac {C}{1-x}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eWrite \\( {\\frac {x^{3}}{(2x-1)(x+2)(x-3)}}\\, \\) as the sum of partial fractions. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSince the given fraction is an improper fraction,first do the division to change it into a proper fraction. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNote that the quotient is \\( {\\frac {1}{2}}\\, \\) (See the greatest degree terms in the numerator and denominator). \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore the given fraction can be written as \\( {\\frac {1}{2}}+{\\frac {A}{2x-1}}+{\\frac {B}{x+2}}+{\\frac {C}{x-3}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimplifying the equations we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{3}\u003d(2x-1)(x+2)(x-3)+2A(x+2)(x-3)+2B(2x-1)(x-3)+2C(2x-1)(x+2)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo find A,B,C substitute \\( x\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe get \\( {\\frac {1}{4}}\u003d2A({\\frac {1}{2}}+2)({\\frac {1}{2}}-3)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {1}{4}}\u003d2A(-{\\frac {25}{4}})\u003dA({\\frac {-25}{2}}),A\u003d-{\\frac {1}{50}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubstituting \\( x\u003d-2\\, \\) we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -16\u003d2B(2(-2)-1)(-2-3)\u003d50B,B\u003d-{\\frac {8}{25}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubstituting \\( x\u003d3\\, \\) we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 54\u003d2C(2(3)-1)(3+2)\u003d50C,C\u003d{\\frac {27}{25}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore \\( {\\frac {x^{3}}{(2x-1)(x+2)(x-3)}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}-{\\frac {1}{50(2x-1)}}-{\\frac {8}{25(x+2)}}+{\\frac {27}{25(x-3)}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eWrite \\( {\\frac {3x^{3}-2x^{2}-1}{x^{4}+x^{2}+1}}\\, \\) as sum of partial fractions. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{4}+x^{2}+1\u003d(x^{2}+1)^{2}-x^{2}\u003d(x^{2}+x+1)(x^{2}-x+1)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore \\( {\\frac {3x^{3}-2x^{2}-1}{x^{4}+x^{2}+1}}\u003d{\\frac {Ax+B}{x^{2}+x+1}}+{\\frac {Cx+D}{x^{2}-x+1}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEquating the numerators on both sides, we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 3x^{3}-2x^{2}-1\u003d(Ax+B)(x^{2}-x+1)+(Cx+D)(x^{2}+x+1)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eComparing the coefficients of \\( x^{3},x^{2},x\\, \\) on both sides, we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 3\u003dA+C,-2\u003d-A+B+C+D,0\u003dA-B+C+D,-1\u003dB+D\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( C\u003d3-A,D\u003d-1-B\\, \\) Substituting these values in the other two equations,we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -2\u003d-A+B+3-A-1-B,A\u003d2\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 0\u003dA-B+3-A-1-B,B\u003d1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 3\u003d2+C,C\u003d1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -1\u003d1+D,D\u003d-2\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore,Given fraction is \\( {\\frac {2x+1}{x^{2}+x+1}}+{\\frac {x-2}{x^{2}-x+1}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

Prove that \\( {{\\rm {rank}}}(A)+{{\\rm {rank}}}(A-I)\u003dn\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let \\( x\\in {{\\rm {Col}}}(A) \\) , so there exists a vector \\( y\\in {\\mathbb {R}}^{n} \\) such that \\( Ay\u003dx\\, \\) , or \\( A^{2}y\u003dAx\u003dx\\, \\) , so \\( (A-I)x\u003d0\\, \\) ; that is, \\( {{\\rm {Col}}}(A)\\subseteq {{\\rm {Null}}}(A-I) \\) . Further, if \\( x\\in {{\\rm {Null}}}(A-I) \\) , \\( (A-I)x\u003d0\\, \\) implies \\( Ax\u003dx\\in {{\\rm {Col}}}(A) \\) , so \\( {{\\rm {Col}}}(A)\u003d{{\\rm {Null}}}(A-I)\\, \\) . Then, by the Rank Theorem, \\( n\u003d{{\\rm {rank}}}(A-I)+{{\\rm {dim\\ Null}}}(A-I)\u003d{{\\rm {rank}}}(A-I)+{{\\rm {dim\\ Col}}}A\u003d{{\\rm {rank}}}(A)+{{\\rm {rank}}}(A-I) \\) . \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cpre\u003eIf  \\( {\\bar  {a}},{\\bar  {b}},{\\bar  {c}}\\, \\)  are mutually perpendicular vectors of equal magnitude,show that  \\( {\\bar  {a}}+{\\bar  {b}}+{\\bar  {c}}\\, \\)  is equally inclined to  \\( {\\bar  {a}},{\\bar  {b}},{\\bar  {c}}\\, \\) \n\u003c/pre\u003e \n\u003cp\u003eGiven that the vectors a,b,c are mutually perpendicular to each other. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence \\( {\\bar {a}}\\cdot {\\bar {b}}\u003d{\\bar {b}}\\cdot {\\bar {c}}\u003d{\\bar {c}}\\cdot {\\bar {a}}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso given the three of equal magnitude \\( |a|\u003d|b|\u003d|c|\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow \\( |a+b+c|^{2}\u003d({\\bar {a}}+{\\bar {b}}+{\\bar {c}})^{2}\u003d({\\bar {a}})^{2}+({\\bar {b}})^{2}+({\\bar {c}})^{2}+2({\\bar {a}}\\cdot {\\bar {b}}+{\\bar {b}}\\cdot {\\bar {c}}+{\\bar {c}}\\cdot {\\bar {a}})\u003d|a|^{2}+|b|^{2}+|c|^{2}+2(0)\u003d3|a|^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence \\( |{\\bar {a}}+{\\bar {b}}+{\\bar {c}}|\u003d3{\\sqrt {{\\bar {a}}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( {\\bar {a}}+{\\bar {b}}+{\\bar {c}}\\, \\) make angles \\( \\alpha ,\\beta ,\\gamma \\, \\) respectively. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore \\( \\cos \\alpha \u003d{\\frac {({\\bar {a}}+{\\bar {b}}+{\\bar {c}})\\cdot {\\bar {a}}}{|a+b+c||a|}}\u003d{\\frac {|a|^{2}}{{\\sqrt {3}}|a|^{2}}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{{\\sqrt {3}}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimilarly \\( \\cos \\beta \u003d{\\frac {1}{{\\sqrt {3}}}},\\cos \\gamma \u003d{\\frac {1}{{\\sqrt {3}}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Therefore \\( \\cos \\alpha \u003d\\cos \\beta \u003d\\cos \\gamma \\, \\) implies that \\( \\alpha \u003d\\beta \u003d\\gamma \\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the sum of the three vectors is equally inclined to the three individual vectors. \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eIf \\( {\\begin{vmatrix}a\u0026amp;a^{2}\u0026amp;1+a^{3}\\\\b\u0026amp;b^{2}\u0026amp;1+b^{3}\\\\c\u0026amp;c^{2}\u0026amp;1+c^{3}\\end{vmatrix}}\u003d0\\, \\) and the vectors \\( {\\bar {A}}\u003d(1,a,a^{2}),{\\bar {B}}\u003d(1,b,b^{2}),{\\bar {C}}\u003d(1,c,c^{2})\\, \\) are non-coplanar,then prove that \\( abc\u003d-1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven \\( {\\bar {A}}\u003d(1,a,a^{2}),{\\bar {B}}\u003d(1,b,b^{2}),{\\bar {C}}\u003d(1,c,c^{2})\\, \\) are non-coplanar \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( [ABC]\\not \\equiv 0\\, \\) implies \\( {\\begin{vmatrix}1\u0026amp;a\u0026amp;a^{2}\\\\1\u0026amp;b\u0026amp;b^{2}\\\\1\u0026amp;c\u0026amp;c\\end{vmatrix}}\\not \\equiv 0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso given that \\( {\\begin{vmatrix}a\u0026amp;a^{2}\u0026amp;1+a^{3}\\\\b\u0026amp;b^{2}\u0026amp;1+b^{3}\\\\c\u0026amp;c^{2}\u0026amp;1+c^{3}\\end{vmatrix}}\u003d0\\, \\) implies \\( {\\begin{vmatrix}a\u0026amp;a^{2}\u0026amp;1\\\\b\u0026amp;b^{2}\u0026amp;1\\\\c\u0026amp;c^{2}\u0026amp;1\\end{vmatrix}}+{\\begin{vmatrix}a\u0026amp;a^{2}\u0026amp;a^{3}\\\\b\u0026amp;b^{2}\u0026amp;b^{3}\\\\c\u0026amp;c^{2}\u0026amp;c^{3}\\end{vmatrix}}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy applying \\( C_{1}\\leftrightarrow \\ C_{2},C_{2}\\leftrightarrow \\ C_{3}\\, \\) in the first,also taking out a,b,c common from rows one,two and three respectively in the second determinant,we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( given,the determinant in this is equal to zero). \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence \\( abc\u003d-1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFor these pairs of points, find the midpoint, distance, slope, and equation of the line.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (-2,10),(4,9)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo find the midpoint, average the x coordinates and y coordinates. The midpoint is\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\left({\\frac {-2+4}{2}},{\\frac {10+9}{2}}\\right)\u003d\\left({\\frac {2}{2}},{\\frac {19}{2}}\\right)\u003d\\left(1,{\\frac {19}{2}}\\right)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo find the (always zero or positive) distance, use the formula \\( d\u003d+{\\sqrt {(x_{1}-x_{2})^{2}+(y_{1}-y_{2})^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( d\u003d{\\sqrt {(-2-4)^{2}+(10-9)^{2}}}\u003d{\\sqrt {(-6)^{2}+1^{2}}}\u003d{\\sqrt {36+1}}\u003d{\\sqrt {37}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo find the slope, use the formula \\( m\u003d{\\frac {y_{2}-y_{1}}{x_{2}-x_{1}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( m\u003d{\\frac {9-10}{4-(-2)}}\u003d{\\frac {-1}{6}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe equations of the line are\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eForm 1:\u003c/b\u003e \\( y\u003dmx+b\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePlug in one known point (say, \\( (4,9)\\, \\) ) and the calculated slope.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 9\u003d{\\frac {-1}{6}}\\cdot 4+b\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( b\u003d9+{\\frac {2}{3}}\u003d{\\frac {29}{3}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the relation between x and y,if the point (x,y)is equidistant from \\( (7,-6),(-3,4)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe distance between (x,y) and the first point is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\sqrt {(x-7)^{2}+(y+6)^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\sqrt {x^{2}+49-14x+y^{2}+36+12y}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\sqrt {x^{2}+y^{2}-14x+12y+85}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this expression be 1. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe distance between (x,y) and the second point is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\sqrt {(x+3)^{2}+(y-4)^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\sqrt {x^{2}+9+6x+y^{2}+16-8y}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\sqrt {x^{2}+y^{2}+6x-8y+25}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this expression be 2. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs per the given condition,equating both the expressions, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\sqrt {x^{2}+y^{2}-14x-12y+85}}\u003d{\\sqrt {x^{2}+y^{2}+6x-8y+25}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSquaring on both sides,we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}-14x+12y+22\u003dx^{2}+y^{2}+6x-8y+25\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ecancelling the terms which are common on both sides, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -14x-6x+12y+8y\u003d-60\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -20x+20y\u003d-60\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x-y\u003d3\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",
