      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eShow that the equation of the straight line passing through \\( (x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\) and making an angle of \\( \\theta \\, \\) with the X-axis in positive direction is \\( {\\frac {x-x_{1}}{\\cos \\theta }}\u003d{\\frac {y-y_{1}}{\\sin \\theta }}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs the straight line makes an angle \u0027theta\u0027 with X-axis,the slope of the line is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( m\u003d\\tan \\theta \\, \\) since the slope is defined by \\( {\\frac {y_{2}-y_{1}}{x_{2}-x_{1}}} \\) and this also gives \\( {\\frac {opp}{adj}} \\) , i.e. \\( \\tan \\theta \\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore the equation of the straight line is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y-y_{1}\u003d\\tan \\theta (x-x_{1})\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ethat is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y-y_{1}\u003d{\\frac {\\sin \\theta }{\\cos \\theta }}(x-x_{1})\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRearranging the variables,we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {x-x_{1}}{\\cos \\theta }}\u003d{\\frac {y-y_{1}}{\\sin \\theta }}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven equation is \\( x^{2}+16xy-11y^{2}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (x+8y)^{2}-75y^{2}\u003d0,(x+8y)^{2}-(5{\\sqrt {3}})^{2}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( [x+8y+5{\\sqrt {3}}y][x+8y-5{\\sqrt {3}}y]\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( [x+(8+5{\\sqrt {3}})y][x+(8-5{\\sqrt {3}})y]\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet these two lines be \\( L_{1}\\equiv 0,L_{2}\\equiv 0\\, \\) respectively. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( L_{3}\\equiv 2x+y+1\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAngle between L1,L2 is \\( \\cos \\alpha \u003d{\\frac {a+b}{{\\sqrt {(a-b)^{2}+4h^{2}}}}}\u003d{\\frac {1-11}{{\\sqrt {(1+11)^{2}+4(8)^{2}}}}}\u003d{\\frac {-1}{2}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow \\( \\alpha \u003d60^{\\circ }\\, \\) or \\( 120^{\\circ }\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimilarly,the angle between L1,L3 is \\( \\cos \\beta \u003d{\\frac {a_{1}a_{2}+b_{1}b_{2}}{{\\sqrt {(a_{1}^{{2}}+b_{1}^{{2}})(a_{2}^{{2}}+b_{2}^{{2}})}}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\cos \\beta \u003d{\\frac {10+5{\\sqrt {3}}}{2(10+5{\\sqrt {3}}}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\beta \u003d60^{\\circ }\\, \\) or \\( 120^{\\circ }\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore the three lines \\( L_{1},L_{2},L_{3}\\, \\) form a triangle. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSince the sum of the angles in any triangle is \\( 180^{\\circ }\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSince the angles that we found are \\( 60^{\\circ },60^{\\circ }\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the three lines form an equilateral triangle. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet p be the perpendicular distance from the vertex(0,0) to the line \\( 2x+y+1\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore, \\( p\u003d{\\frac {|0+0+1|}{{\\sqrt {4+1}}}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{{\\sqrt {5}}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eArea of the triangle is \\( {\\frac {p^{2}}{{\\sqrt {3}}}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{5{\\sqrt {3}}}}\\, \\) units. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the equation to the circle passing through (0,0) and concentric with \\( x^{2}+y^{2}-2x-3y-4\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConcentric means that the both the circles will have the same centre. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the centre of the circle is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\left({\\frac {-(-2)}{2}},{\\frac {-(-3)}{2}}\\right)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\left(1,{\\frac {3}{2}}\\right)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe radius of the circle with the centre above and passing through (0,0) is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\sqrt {1+{\\frac {9}{4}}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\sqrt {{\\frac {13}{4}}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow the equation of the circle is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (x-1)^{2}+(y-{\\frac {3}{2}})^{2}\u003d{\\frac {13}{4}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+1-2x+y^{2}+{\\frac {9}{4}}-3y\u003d{\\frac {13}{4}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 4x^{2}+4y^{2}-2x-3y+10\u003d13\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the equation of the circle is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 4x^{2}+4y^{2}-2x-3y-3\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the equation to the circle passing through the points \\( (1,3),(0,-2),(-3,1)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let the equation of the circle be \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+2gx+2fy+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe point (1,3) lies on the circle,then \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 1^{2}+3^{2}+2g(1)+2f(3)+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 2g+6f+c\u003d-8\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this equation be 1. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe point (0,-2) lies on the circle,then \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 0^{2}+(-2)^{2}+2g(0)+2f(-2)+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -4f+c\u003d-4\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this equation be 2. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe point (-3,1) lies on the circle,then \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (-3)^{2}+(1)^{2}+2g(-3)+2f(1)+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -6g+2f+c\u003d-10\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this equation be 3. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolving 1 and 3 we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 20f+4c\u003d-34\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolving this and equation 3, we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 9c\u003d-54\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( c\u003d-6\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( f\u003d{\\frac {-1}{2}},-6g-1-6\u003d-10\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( g\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}},f\u003d{\\frac {-1}{2}},c\u003d-6\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow the equation of the circle is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+x-y-6\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eMain page\u003c/a\u003e:\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eGeometry\u003c/a\u003e:\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eCircles\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the equation to the circle passing through the points \\( (a,0),(0,b),(a,b)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let the equation of the circle be \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+2gx+2fy+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe point (a,0) lies on the circle,then \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( a^{2}+0^{2}+2g(a)+2f(0)+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 2ga+c\u003d-a^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this equation be 1. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe point (0,b) lies on the circle,then \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 0^{2}+(b)^{2}+2g(0)+2f(b)+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 2fb+c\u003d-b^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this equation be 2. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe point (a,b) lies on the circle,then \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (a)^{2}+(b)^{2}+2ga+2fb+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 2ga+2fb+c\u003d-a^{2}-b^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this equation be 3. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolving 1 and 3 we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 2fb\u003d-a^{2}+a^{2}-b^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( f\u003d{\\frac {-b}{2}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubstituting this value in 2, we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 2\\cdot {\\frac {-b}{2}}b+c\u003d-b^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 2ga\u003d-a^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( g\u003d{\\frac {-a}{2}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow the equation of the circle is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}-ax-by\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eMain page\u003c/a\u003e:\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eGeometry\u003c/a\u003e:\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eCircles\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eShow that the points \\( (-6,0),(-2,2),(-2,-8),(1,1)\\, \\) are concyclic \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let the equation of the circle be \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+2gx+2fy+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe point (-6,0) lies on the circle,then \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 36-12g+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -12g+c\u003d-36\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this equation be 1. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe point (-2,2) lies on the circle,then \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 4+4-4g+4f+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -4g+4f+c\u003d-8\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this equation be 2. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe point (-2,-8) lies on the circle,then \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 4+64-4g-16f+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -4g-16f+c\u003d-68\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this equation be 3. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolving 1 and 3 we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( g-2f\u003d-4\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolving this and equation 2, we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( c\u003d-12\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( g\u003d2\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( f\u003d3,g\u003d2,c\u003d-12\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow the equation of the circle is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+4x+6y-12\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf the fourth point (1,1)lies on this circle,then the four points are concyclic. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 1+1+4+6-12\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eMain page\u003c/a\u003e:\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eGeometry\u003c/a\u003e:\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eCircles\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the circle which passes through (-1,2),(3,-2) and has its centre on the line \\( x-2y\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet the equation of the circle be \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+2gx+2fy+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe point (-1,2) lies on the circle,hence \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 1+4-2g+4f+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -2g+4f+c\u003d-5\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePoint (3,-2) lies on the circle \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 9+4+6g-4f+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 6g-4f+c\u003d-13\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso the centre lies on \\( x-2y\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -g+2f\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( g\u003d2f\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubstituting this in the first equation we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -2(2f)+4f+c\u003d-5\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( c\u003d-5\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 6(2f)-4f-5\u003d-13\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 8f\u003d-8\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence f\u003d-1, Now g\u003d-2 \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEquation of the circle is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}-4x-2y-5\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eMain page\u003c/a\u003e:\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eGeometry\u003c/a\u003e:\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eCircles\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the equation to the circle passing through the points (1,-2),(4,-3) and having the centre on the line \\( 3x+4y\u003d7\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet the equation of the circle be \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+2gx+2fy+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe circle passes through (1.-2) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 1^{2}+(-2)^{2}+2g(1)+2f(-2)+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 2g-4f+c\u003d-5\\, \\) (-g,-f)lies on 3x+4y\u003d7. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -3g-4f\u003d7\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 3g+4f\u003d-7\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this equation be 3. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolving 1 and 3 we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 5g+c\u003d-12\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this be 4. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow solving 2 and 3 we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 50g+4c\u003d-142\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this be 5. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolving 4 and 5 we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -30g\u003d94,g\u003d{\\frac {-94}{30}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 5\\cdot {\\frac {-94}{30}}+c\u003d-12\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( c\u003d{\\frac {110}{30}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe value of f is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 3({\\frac {-94}{30}}+4f\u003d-7\\, \\)       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the equation of the circle which passes through (1,1),(2,2) and whose radius is unity. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet the equation be \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+2gx+2fy+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe circle passes through (1,1) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 2g+2f+c+2\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this be 2 \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt passes through (2,2) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 4g+4f+c+8\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this be 3 \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRadius is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( g^{2}+f^{2}-c\u003d1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this be 4. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubtracting 2 from 3, we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( g+f+3\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis is equation 5. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAdding 2 and 4 equations we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( g^{2}+f^{2}+2g+2f+1\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubstituting f\u003d-g-3 from 4, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( g^{2}+(g+3)^{2}+2g-2(g+3)+1\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026lt;amth\u0026gt;g^2+3g+2\u003d0,g\u003d-1,-2\\,\u0026lt;/math\u0026gt; \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( f\u003d-2,-1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe value of c is 4,4 \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the equation is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}-2x-4y+4\u003d0,x^{2}+y^{2}-4x-2y+4\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the equation to the circle on AB as diameter and hence find the circle passing through \\( A(1,1),B(2,-1),C(3,2)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEquation of the circle with AB as diameter is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (x-1)(x-2)+(y-1)(y+1)\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}-3x+2+y^{2}-1\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}-3x+1\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEquation of the circle passing through A,B,C is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet the equation be \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+2gx+2fy+c\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt passes thro\u0027(1,1) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 2g+2f+c\u003d-2\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt passes thro\u0027(2,-1) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 4g-2f+c\u003d-5\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt passes thro\u0027(3,2) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 6g+4f+c\u003d-13\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolving first two \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 6g+2c\u003d-7\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolving second two, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 14g+3c\u003d-23\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSoving these two equations we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -10g\u003d25,g\u003d{\\frac {-5}{2}},6\\cdot {\\frac {-5}{2}}+2c\u003d-7,c\u003d4\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow the value of f is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 4\\cdot {\\frac {-5}{2}}-2f+4\u003d-5,f\u003d{\\frac {-1}{2}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the equation is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}-5x-y+4\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the locus of the point from which the lenghts of the tangents to the circles \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+4x+3\u003d0\\, \\) and \\( x^{2}+y^{2}-6x+5\u003d0\\, \\) are in the ratio 2:3. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven circles are \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+4x+3\u003d0,x^{2}+y^{2}-6x+5\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet P(x1,y1) be a given point on locus.The lenghths of the tangents from P to the given circles are \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( t_{1}\u003d{\\sqrt {x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}+4x_{1}+3}},t_{2}\u003d{\\sqrt {x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}-6x_{1}+5}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven t1:t2\u003d2:3, 3t1\u003d2t2 \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 3t_{1}\u003d2t_{2},9t_{1}^{{2}}\u003d4t_{2}^{{2}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 9(x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}+4x_{1}+3)\u003d4(x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}-6x_{1}+5)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimplifying \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( a5x_{1}^{{2}}+5y_{1}^{{2}}+60x_{1}+7\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the locus of P is the circle \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+60x+7\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eShow that the line x+y+1\u003d0 touches the circle \\( x^{2}+y^{2}-3x+7y+14\u003d0\\, \\) and find the point of contact. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe centre of the given circle is (3/2,-7/2) and radius is \\( {\\sqrt {{\\frac {9}{4}}+{\\frac {49}{4}}-14}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRadius is \\( {\\frac {1}{{\\sqrt {2}}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe distance from the centre of the circle to the given line is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( |{\\frac {{\\frac {3}{2}}-{\\frac {7}{2}}+1}{{\\sqrt {2}}}}|\u003d{\\frac {1}{{\\sqrt {2}}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow the perpendicular distance from the centre of the circle to the given line is equal to the radius of the circle.       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eShow that the line 3x\u003dy+13 touches the circle \\( x^{2}+y^{2}-4x-6y+3\u003d0\\, \\) and find the point of contact. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe centre of the given circle is (2,3) and radius is \\( {\\sqrt {4+9-3}}\u003d{\\sqrt {10}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe distance from the centre of the circle to the given line is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( |{\\frac {3(2)-3-13}{{\\sqrt {10}}}}|\u003d{\\sqrt {10}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow the perpendicular distance from the centre of the circle to the given line is equal to the radius of the circle.       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eProve that the tangent to the circle \\( x^{2}+y^{2}\u003d5\\, \\) at (1,-2) also touches the circle \\( x^{2}+y^{2}-8x+6y+20\u003d0\\, \\) and find the point of contact. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCentre of the given first circle is (0,0) and radius is \\( {\\sqrt {5}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSlope of the line joining the centre and (1,-2) is \\( {\\frac {-2-0}{1-0}}\u003d-2\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow the slope of the tangent is 1/2. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe equation of the tangent which has a point (1,2) and slope of -1/2 is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y+2\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}(x-1)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 2y+4\u003dx-1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the equation of the tangent is x-2y-5\u003d0\\,\u0026lt;/math\u0026gt; \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow the centre of the second circle is (4,-3) and radius is \\( {\\sqrt {16+9-20}}\u003d{\\sqrt {5}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe distance from the centre to the line x-2y-5\u003d0 is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {4+6-5}{{\\sqrt {5}}}}\u003d{\\sqrt {5}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the distance from the centre to the line is equal to the radius,hence it touches the second circle. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet(x1,y1) be the point of contact. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe distance between centre and the point is equal to radius, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\sqrt {(x_{1}-4)^{2}+(y_{1}+3)^{2}}}\u003d{\\sqrt {5}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (x_{1}-4)^{2}+(y_{1}+3)^{2}\u003d5\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe point lies on the tangent, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x_{1}-2y_{1}-5\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x_{1}\u003d2y_{1}+5\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (2y_{1}+1)^{2}+(y_{1}+3)^{2}\u003d5\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 4y_{1}^{{2}}+1+4y_{1}+y_{1}^{{2}}+9+6y_{1}\u003d5\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 5y_{1}^{{2}}+10y_{1}+5\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y_{1}^{{2}}+2y_{1}+1\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (y_{1}+1)^{2}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y_{1}\u003d-1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the value of x1\u003d3. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow the point of contact is (3,-1). \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the equation of the tangent at(1,2) to the circle \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+2x-2y-3\u003d0\\, \\) .Find also the equation of the tangent parallel to the above tangent. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe equation of the tangent is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x(1)+y(2)+1(x+1)-1(y+2)-3\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 2x+y-4\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEquation of the line parallel to the tangent is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 2x+y+k\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCentre of the circle is (1,-1) and radius is \\( {\\sqrt {1+1+3}}\u003d{\\sqrt {5}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe distance from the centre to the line is radius \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ehence \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( |{\\frac {2(1)-1+k}{{\\sqrt {5}}}}|\u003d{\\sqrt {5}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( k+1\u003d\\pm 5\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( k\u003d4,-6\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the equation parallel to the above tangent is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 2x+y-6\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eTangents are drawn to the circle \\( x^{2}+y^{2}\u003da^{2}\\, \\) from a point which always lies on the line \\( lx+my\u003d1\\, \\) .Prove that the locus of the mid-point of the chords of contact is \\( x^{2}+y^{2}-a^{2}(lx+my)\u003d0\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven circle is \\( x^{2}+y^{2}\u003da^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this be 1. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven line is \\( lx+my\u003d1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this equation be 2. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet (h,k) be a point on the line 2, hence \\( lh+mk\u003d1\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis is equation 3 \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe equation of the chord of contact of tangents from (h,k)to the circle is \\( hx+ky\u003da^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this be equation 4 \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet (x1,y1) be the mid point of the chord, then teh equation of the chord is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( xx_{1}+yy_{1}\u003dx_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLe this be 5. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe equations 4 and 5 represent the same. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {h}{x_{1}}}\u003d{\\frac {k}{y_{1}}}\u003d{\\frac {a^{2}}{x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore \\( h\u003d{\\frac {a^{2}x_{1}}{x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}}},k\u003d{\\frac {a^{2}y_{1}}{x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubstituting these values in the equation 3, we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {la^{2}x_{1}}{x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}}}+{\\frac {ma^{2}y_{1}}{x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}}}\u003d1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( a^{2}(lx_{1}+my_{1})\u003dx_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the locus of (x1,y1) is \\( x^{2}+y^{2}-a^{2}(lx+my)\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the locus of the poles of the line \\( {\\frac {x}{a}}+{\\frac {y}{b}}\u003d1\\, \\) w.r.t the circles which touch the coordinate axes and whose centre lies in the first quadrant. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven line is \\( {\\frac {x}{a}}+{\\frac {y}{b}}\u003d1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eor \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( bx+ay\u003dab\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEquation of any circle which touches the coordinate axes and whose centre lies in the first quadrant is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (x-\\lambda )^{2}+(y-\\lambda )^{2}\u003d[\\lambda ]^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}-2\\lambda x-2\\lambda y+\\lambda ^{2}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet P(x1,y1) be the pole of the line w.r.t the above circle, hence polar w.r.t. circle is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( xx_{1}+yy_{1}-\\lambda (x+x_{1})-\\lambda (y+y_{1})+\\lambda ^{2}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (x_{1}-\\lambda )x+(y_{1}-\\lambda )y\u003d\\lambda (x_{1}+y_{1}-\\lambda )\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet this equation be 3. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003esince the first one and the 3 both represent polar of P w.r.t the circle \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {x_{1}-\\lambda }{b}}\u003d{\\frac {y_{1}-\\lambda }{a}}\u003d{\\frac {\\lambda (x_{1}+y_{1}-\\lambda )}{ab}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFrom two of the above, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( ax_{1}-a\\lambda \u003dby_{1}-b\\lambda \\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( ax_{1}-by_{1}\u003d\\lambda (a-b)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\lambda \u003d{\\frac {ax_{1}-by_{1}}{a-b}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTaking the second two equalities, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {ax_{1}-by_{1}}{a-b}}]\u003d{\\frac {ax_{1}-by_{1}}{a-b}}[x_{1}+y_{1}-{\\frac {ax_{1}-by_{1}}{a-b}}]\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( b(ay_{1}-ax_{1})\u003d(ax_{1}-by_{1})[{\\frac {ay_{1}-bx_{1}}{a-b}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (ax_{1}-by_{1})(ay_{1}-bx_{1})\u003db(a-b)(y_{1}-x_{1})\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore, the required locus of P is       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eShow that the locus of the poles of the chords of the parabola \\( y^{2}\u003d4ax\\, \\) which subtend a constant angle alpha at the vertex is the curve \\( (x+4a)^{2}\\tan ^{2}\\alpha \u003d4(y^{2}-4ax)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( P(x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\) be the midpoint of the chord BC of the parabola \\( y^{2}\u003d4ax\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEquation of BC is \\( yy_{1}-2a(x+x_{1})\u003dy_{1}^{{2}}-4ax_{1}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( yy_{1}-2ax\u003dy_{1}^{{2}}-2ax_{1}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJoin AB,AC.Given \\( \\angle BAC\u003d\\alpha \\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHomogenising \\( y^{2}\u003d4ax\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y^{2}-4ax{\\frac {yy_{1}-2ax}{y_{1}^{{2}}-2ax}}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y^{2}(y_{1}^{{2}}-2ax_{1})-4ay_{1}xy+8a^{2}x^{2}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\tan \\alpha \u003d|{\\frac {2{\\sqrt {4a^{2}y_{1}^{{2}}-8a^{2}(y_{1}^{{2}}-2ax_{1})}}}{y_{1}^{{2}}-2ax_{1}+8a^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubstituting \\( y_{1}^{{2}}\u003d4ax_{1}\\, \\) in the denominator above and crossmultiplying and \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003esquaring both sides,we have \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\tan ^{{2}}\\alpha (2ax_{1}+8a^{2})^{2}\u003d|4(16a^{3}x_{1}-4a^{2}y_{1}^{{2}})|\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\tan ^{{2}}\\alpha (2ax_{1}+8a^{2})^{2}\u003d16a^{2}(4ax_{1}-y_{1}^{{2}})\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimplifying further, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (x_{1}+4a)^{2}\\tan ^{{2}}\\alpha \u003d4(y_{1}^{{2}}-4ax_{1})\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore,the locus of P is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (x+4a)^{2}\\tan ^{{2}}\\alpha \u003d4(y^{2}-4ax)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the locus of the point of intersection of the two tangents to the ellipse \\( b^{2}x^{2}+a^{2}y^{2}\u003da^{2}b^{2}\\, \\) ,which include an angle theta. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven the ellipse \\( {\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}\u003d1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( y\u003dmx+{\\sqrt {a^{2}m^{2}+b^{2}}}\\, \\) be a tangent passing through a point \\( P(x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eReadjusting the variables,we have \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( m^{2}(x_{1}^{{2}}-a^{2})-2mx_{1}y_{1}+y_{1}^{{2}}-b^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet the roots of the quadratic equation be \\( m_{1},m_{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTwo tangents pass thro\u0027P.If their inclinations are \\( \\alpha ,\\beta \\, \\) then \\( \\tan \\alpha \u003dm_{1},\\tan \\beta \u003dm_{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven \\( \\theta \u003d\\alpha -\\beta \\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\tan \\theta \u003d\\tan(\\alpha -\\beta )\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\tan \\theta \u003d{\\frac {\\tan \\alpha -\\tan \\beta }{1+\\tan \\alpha \\tan \\beta }}\u003d{\\frac {m_{1}-m_{2}}{1+m_{1}m_{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimplifying, we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (1+m_{1}m_{2})^{2}\\tan ^{2}\\theta \u003d(m_{1}-m_{2})^{2}\u003d(m_{1}+m_{2})^{2}-4m_{1}m_{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( [1+{\\frac {y_{1}^{{2}}-b^{2}}{x_{1}^{{2}}-a^{2}}}]\\tan ^{2}\\theta \u003d[{\\frac {2x_{1}y_{1}}{x_{1}^{{2}}-a^{2}}}]^{2}-4({\\frac {y_{1}^{{2}}-b^{2}}{x_{1}^{{2}}-a^{2}}})\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}-a^{2}-b^{2})^{2}\\tan ^{2}\\theta \u003d4x_{1}^{{2}}y_{1}^{{2}}-4(y_{1}^{{2}}-b^{2})(x_{1}^{{2}}-a^{2})\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore,the locus of P is \\( (x^{2}+y^{2}-a^{2}-b^{2})^{2}\\tan ^{2}\\theta \u003d4x^{2}y^{2}-4(y^{2}-b^{2})(x^{2}-a^{2})\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eShow that the poles of the tangents of \\( y^{2}\u003d4kx(k\u0026gt;0)\\, \\) w.r.t the ellipse \\( {\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}\u003d1\\, \\) lie on a parabola. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( P(x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\) be the pole of a tangent \\( l\u003d0\\, \\) of \\( y^{2}\u003d4kx\\, \\) w.r.t the ellipse \\( S\u003d0\\, \\) where \\( l\u003dy-(mx+{\\frac {k}{m}})\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThen the polar of P w.r.t S\u003d0 is \\( {\\frac {xx_{1}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {yy_{1}}{b^{2}}}-1\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSince \\( S_{1}\u003d0,l\u003d0\\, \\) represents the same line,comparing coefficients we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {x_{1}}{a^{2}m}}\u003d{\\frac {y_{1}}{-b^{2}}}\u003d{\\frac {-m}{k}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {x_{1}}{a^{2}m}}\u003d{\\frac {y_{1}}{-b^{2}}},m\u003d{\\frac {-b^{2}x_{1}}{a^{2}y_{1}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {y_{1}}{-b^{2}}}\u003d{\\frac {-m}{k}},m\u003d{\\frac {ky_{1}}{b^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {-b^{2}x_{1}}{a^{2}y_{1}}}\u003d{\\frac {ky_{1}}{b^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y_{1}^{{2}}\u003d{\\frac {-b^{4}x_{1}}{ka^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the pole \\( P(x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\) lies on the parabola \\( y^{2}\u003d{\\frac {-b^{4}}{ka^{2}}}(x_{1})\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eShow that the poles of normal chords of the ellipse \\( {\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}\u003d1\\, \\) lie on the curve \\( {\\frac {a^{6}}{x^{2}}}+{\\frac {b^{6}}{y^{2}}}\u003d(a^{2}-b^{2})^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe equation of normal to the ellipse S\u003d0 at any point theta is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( l\u003d{\\frac {ax}{\\cos \\theta }}-{\\frac {by}{\\sin \\theta }}\u003da^{2}-b^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet the pole of l\u003d0 w.r.t S\u003d0 be \\( P(x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe polar of P w.r.t S\u003d0 is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {xx_{1}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {yy_{1}}{b^{2}}}-1\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs these two equations represent the same line i.e polar of P, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eComparing the coefficients, we have \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {x_{\\cos }\\theta }{a^{3}}}\u003d{\\frac {-y_{1}\\sin \\theta }{b^{3}}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{a^{2}-b^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\sin \\theta \u003d{\\frac {-b^{3}}{y_{1}(a^{2}-b^{2})}},\\cos \\theta \u003d{\\frac {a^{3}}{x_{1}(a^{2}-b^{2})}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSquaring and adding \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 1\u003d\\sin ^{2}\\theta +\\cos ^{2}\\theta \u003d{\\frac {a^{6}}{x_{1}^{{2}}(a^{2}-b^{2})^{2}}}+{\\frac {b^{6}}{y_{1}^{{2}}(a^{2}-b^{2})^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {a^{6}}{x_{1}^{{2}}}}+{\\frac {b^{6}}{y_{1}^{{2}}}}\u003d(a^{2}-b^{2})^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore the pole lies on the curve \\( {\\frac {a^{6}}{x^{2}}}+{\\frac {b^{6}}{y^{2}}}\u003d(a^{2}-b^{2})^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cpre\u003eShow that the poles of the tangents to the circle  \\( x^{2}+y^{2}\u003da^{2}+b^{2}\\, \\)  w.r.t the ellipse  \\( {\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}\u003d1\\, \\)  lies on  \\( {\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{4}}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{4}}}\u003d{\\frac  {1}{a^{2}+b^{2}}}\\, \\) \n\u003c/pre\u003e \n\u003cp\u003eAny point on the given circle is of the form \\( P((a^{2}+b^{2})\\cos \\alpha ,(a^{2}+b^{2})\\sin \\alpha )\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe tangent to the given circle at \\( P(\\alpha )\\, \\) is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x\\cos \\alpha +y\\sin \\alpha \u003d{\\sqrt {a^{2}+b^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( Q(x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\) be the pole of this tangent w.r.t teh given ellipse is \\( {\\frac {xx_{1}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {yy_{1}}{b^{2}}}\u003d1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese two equations represent the same line,hence comparing the coefficients, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {(a^{2})\\cos \\alpha }{x_{1}}}\u003d{\\frac {(b^{2})\\sin \\alpha }{y_{1}}}\u003d{\\frac {{\\sqrt {a^{2}+b^{2}}}}{1}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\cos \\alpha \u003d{\\frac {x_{1}({\\sqrt {a^{2}+b^{2}}})}{a^{2}}},\\sin \\alpha \u003d{\\frac {y_{1}({\\sqrt {a^{2}+b^{2}}})}{b^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSquaring and adding,we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 1\u003d\\sin ^{2}\\alpha +\\cos ^{2}\\alpha \u003d{\\frac {x_{1}^{{2}}(a^{2}+b^{2})}{a^{4}}}+{\\frac {y_{1}^{{2}}(a^{2}+b^{2})}{b^{4}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {x_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{4}}}+{\\frac {y_{1}^{{2}}}{b^{4}}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{a^{2}+b^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the locus of the poles of the tangetns of the circle w.r.t the ellipse is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{4}}}+{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{4}}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{a^{2}+b^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eA chord PQ of an ellipse subtends a right angle at the centre of the ellipse \\( S\u003d0\\, \\) .Show that the point of intersection of tangents at P and Q lies on the ellipse \\( {\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{4}}}+{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{4}}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {1}{b^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet the tangents at P and Q intersects at \\( R(x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\) ,then PQ is the chord of tangents drawn from \\( (x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore \\( PQ\u003d{\\frac {xx_{1}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {yy_{1}}{b^{2}}}\u003d1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe equation of the pair of lines CP and CQ is obtained by homogenising the equation of S\u003d0 with PQ. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe combined equation is \\( {\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}\u003d[{\\frac {xx_{1}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {yy_{1}}{b^{2}}}]^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}[{\\frac {1}{a^{2}}}-{\\frac {x_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{4}}}]-{\\frac {2x_{1}y_{1}xy}{a^{2}b^{2}}}+y^{2}[{\\frac {1}{b^{2}}}-{\\frac {y_{1}^{{2}}}{b^{4}}}]\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut angle PCQ is 90. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore,the coefficients of square of x and square of y is equal to zero. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( [{\\frac {1}{a^{2}}}-{\\frac {x_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{4}}}]+[{\\frac {1}{b^{2}}}-{\\frac {y_{1}^{{2}}}{b^{4}}}]\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {x_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{4}}}+{\\frac {y_{1}^{{2}}}{b^{4}}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {1}{b^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the point of intersection of tangents at P and Q lies on the ellipse \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{4}}}+{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{4}}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {1}{b^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eProve that the pair of tangents drawn to \\( 9x^{2}+16y^{2}\u003d144\\, \\) are perpendicular to eachother. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven \\( S\\equiv 9x^{2}+16y^{2}\u003d144\\, \\) and Let the point be \\( (x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( S_{1}\\equiv 9xx_{1}+16yy_{1}-144\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( S_{{11}}\\equiv 9x_{1}^{{2}}+16y_{1}^{{2}}-144\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore,equation to the pair of tangents is \\( S_{1}^{{2}}\u003dSS_{{11}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (9xx_{1}+16yy_{1}-144)^{2}\u003d(9x^{2}+16y^{2}-144)(9x_{1}^{{2}}+16y_{1}^{{2}}-144)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSeparating the coefficients of \\( x^{2}\\, \\) and \\( y^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 81x_{1}^{{2}}+256y_{1}^{{2}}-81x_{1}^{{2}}-256y_{1}^{{2}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFrom the above,the sum of the coefficients of squares of x and y is zero,which is the condition for the two lines to be perpendicular. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence the two tangents drawn on the given ellipse are perpendicular to each other. \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eShow that the equation of the auxiliary circle of the ellipse \\( {\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}\u003d1\\, \\) is \\( x^{2}+y^{2}\u003da^{2}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe equation to the ellipse is \\( {\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}\u003d1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe equation to the tangent of the ellipse is \\( y\u003dmx\\pm {\\sqrt {a^{2}m^{2}+b^{2}}},y-mx\u003d\\pm {\\sqrt {a^{2}m^{2}+b^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe equation to the perpendicular from either focus \\( (\\pm ae,0)\\, \\) on this tangent is given by \\( y\u003d{\\frac {-1}{m}}(x\\pm ae),my+x\u003d\\pm ae\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo find the locus of point of intersection of the above two equations,eliminate m from them. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSquaring and adding the two equations,we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (y-mx)^{2}+(my+x)^{2}\u003da^{2}m^{2}+b^{2}+a^{2}e^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}(1+m^{2})+y^{2}(1+m^{2})\u003da^{2}m^{2}+a^{2}(1-e^{2})+a^{2}e^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (x^{2}+y^{2})(1+m^{2})\u003da^{2}(m^{2}+1)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}+y^{2}\u003da^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore the locus is the auxiliary circle concentric with the ellipse. \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eTangents at right angles are drawn to the ellipse \\( S\u003d0\\, \\) .Show that the locus of the midpoints of chords of contact is the curve \\( [{\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}]^{2}\u003d{\\frac {x^{2}+y^{2}}{a^{2}+b^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( P(x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\) be the mid point of a chord QR of the given ellipse. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEquation to chord QR is \\( S_{1}\u003dS_{{11}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {xx_{1}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {yy_{1}}{b^{2}}}\u003d{\\frac {x_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {y_{1}^{{2}}}{b^{2}}}\u003dk\\, \\) (say) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet the tangents at Q and R to the ellipse meet at M. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore coordinates of M are \\( \\left({\\frac {-a^{2}x_{1}}{a^{2}k}},{\\frac {-b^{2}y_{1}}{b^{2}k}}\\right)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\left({\\frac {-x_{1}}{k}},{\\frac {-y_{1}}{k}}\\right)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven that the tangents MQ and MR are perpendiculars. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMlies on director circle \\( x^{2}+y^{2}\u003da^{2}+b^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {x_{1}^{{2}}}{k^{2}}}+{\\frac {y_{1}^{{2}}}{k^{2}}}\u003da^{2}+b^{2},k^{2}\u003d{\\frac {x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{2}+b^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( [{\\frac {x_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {y_{1}^{{2}}}{b^{2}}}]^{2}\u003d{\\frac {x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{2}+b^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore the locus of P is \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( [{\\frac {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}]^{2}\u003d{\\frac {x^{2}+y^{2}}{a^{2}+b^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eP is a point on the ellipse \\( S\u003d0\\, \\) and Q is its corresponding point on the auxiliary circle.       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eState and prove \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eGronwall\u0027s lemma\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLemma: Let \\( r(t)\\, \\) be continuous for \\( |t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta \\, \\) and satisfy the inequalities \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( 0\\leq r(t)\\leq \\epsilon +\\delta {\\Big |}\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}r(s)ds{\\Big |}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003efor some non-negative constants \\( \\epsilon \\, \\) and \\( \\delta \\, \\) . Then \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( 0\\leq r(t)\\leq \\epsilon \\exp \\left\\{\\delta |t-t_{0}|\\right\\}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eProof: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt is sufficient to consider the case \\( t\\geq t_{0}\\, \\) . The proof for the other case is the same. Let \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( R(t)\u003d\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}r(s)ds\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eThen \\( R(t)\\, \\) is continuous and differentiable, and \\( R\u0027\u003dr\\, \\) . Hence the inequality takes the form \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( 0\\leq R\u0027\\leq \\epsilon +\\delta R\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eNow multiply both sides by the non-negative function \\( \\exp \\left\\{-\\delta (t-t_{0})\\right\\}\\, \\) , so that \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( 0\\leq \\left[R\\exp \\left\\{-\\delta (t-t_{0})\\right\\}\\right]\u0027\\leq \\epsilon \\exp \\left\\{-\\delta (t-t_{0})\\right\\} \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eNow integrate the inequality from \\( t_{0}\\, \\) to \\( t\\, \\) : \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( 0\\leq R\\exp \\left\\{-\\delta (t-t_{0})\\right\\}\\leq {\\frac {\\epsilon }{\\delta }}\\left[1-\\exp \\left\\{-\\delta (t-t_{0})\\right\\}\\right]\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eor \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( 0\\leq R\\leq {\\frac {\\epsilon }{\\delta }}\\left[\\exp \\left\\{\\delta (t-t_{0})\\right\\}-1\\right]\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eBut, \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( 0\\leq r\u003dR\u0027\\leq \\epsilon +\\delta R\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eor \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( 0\\leq r\\leq \\epsilon \\exp \\left\\{\\delta (t-t_{0})\\right\\}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003ewhich completes the proof. \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eDescribe \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003ePicard Iteration\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTheorem- Let \\( f(x,t)\\, \\) be continuous for \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( |t-t_{0}|\\leq \\alpha ,|x-x_{0}|\\leq \\beta \\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eand satisfy a \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eLipschitz condition\u003c/a\u003e with constant \\( L\\, \\) in this region. Let \\( |f(x,t)|\\leq M\\, \\) there and let \\( \\delta \u003d\\min \\left\\{\\alpha ,\\beta /M\\right\\}\\, \\) . Then the initial value problem \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( x(t)\u003dx_{0}+\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}f(x(s),s)ds\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003ehas a unique solution for \\( |t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta \\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eProof- The uniqueness of the solution has already been established in \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eODE0.3\u003c/a\u003e. The existence of the solution is proved in three steps. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e(i) Define the following sequence of iterates: \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{0}(t)\u003dx_{0}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{1}(t)\u003dx_{0}+\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}f(x^{0}(s),s)ds\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e... \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{{N+1}}(t)\u003dx_{0}+\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}f(x^{N}(s),s)ds\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The first approximation \\( x^{0}\\, \\) is made by neglecting the integral. The next \\( x^{1}\\, \\) is made by using \\( x^{0}\\, \\) in the intgrand as a correction term. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn order for the iterates to be defined, it is required to prove that each iterate stays within its domain of definition of \\( f(x,t)\\, \\) . It will be shown that the iterates are defined for \\( |t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta \\, \\) and satisfy the inequalities \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( |x^{{N+1}}(t)-x_{0}|\\leq \\beta ({\\mathrm {for}}|t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta )\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eThe first step of induction is easy: \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( |x^{{0}}(t)-x_{0}|\u003d0\\leq \\beta ({\\mathrm {for}}|t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta )\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eThe induction hypothesis is to assume that \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( |x^{r}(t)-x_{0}|\\leq \\left|\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}|f(x^{N}(s),s)|ds\\right|\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\leq M|t-t_{0}|\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\leq \\beta ({\\mathrm {for}}|t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta )\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eThe completes the induction. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e(ii) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNext it is shown that the sequence of iterates is uniformly and absolutely convergent. From the general term of the iteration it is clear that \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{{N+1}}(t)-x^{N}(t)\u003d\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}\\left\\{f(x^{N}(s),s)-f(x^{{N-1}}(s),s)\\right\\}ds\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eTake the norm of both sides and use the Lipschitz condition. \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( |x^{{N+1}}(t)-x^{N}(t)|\\leq L{\\Bigg |}\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}{\\Big |}x^{N}(s)-x^{{N-1}}Big|ds{\\Bigg |}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eThis produces a sequence of inequalities. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFrom part (i), \\( |x^{1}(t)-x^{0}(t)|\\leq M|t-t_{0}|\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe induction hypothesis is \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( |x^{r}(t)-x^{{r-1}}(t)|\\leq ML^{{r-1}}{\\frac {|t-t_{0}|^{r}}{r!}}(r\u003d1,...,N)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eNow it follows that \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( |x^{{N+1}}(t)-x^{N}(t)|\\leq {\\frac {ML^{N}}{N!}}{\\Bigg |}\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}|s-t_{0}|^{N}ds{\\Bigg |}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003dML^{N}{\\frac {|t-t_{0}|^{{N+1}}}{(N+1)!}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eNow \\( x^{N}(t)\\, \\) can be written as the partial sum \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{0}(t)+\\sum _{{r\u003d1}}^{N}\\left\\{x^{r}(t)-x^{{r-1}}(t)\\right\\}\u003dx^{N}(t)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eBut the series on the left is domainated term-by-term by the series \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( x_{0}+\\sum _{{r\u003d1}}^{N}ML^{{r-1}}{\\frac {|t-t_{0}|^{r}}{r!}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eAs \\( m\\to \\infty \\, \\) , this series is uniformly and asymptotically convergent to \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( x_{0}+{\\frac {M}{L}}\\left[\\exp\\{L|t-t_{0}|\\}-1\\right]\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eSo by the comparison test, \\( x^{N}(t)\\, \\) comverges uniformly for \\( |t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta \\, \\) to a limit function \\( x(t)\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e(iii) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAgain from the general term of the iteration, it can be seen that each iterate is a continuous function of \\( t\\, \\) for \\( |t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta \\, \\) . Hence, since \\( x^{N}(t)\\, \\) converges uniformly to \\( x(t)\\, \\) , it follows that \\( x(t)\\, \\) is a continuous function of \\( t\\, \\) for \\( |t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta \\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt follows from \\( |x^{{N+1}}(t)-x_{0}|\\leq \\beta ({\\mathrm {for}}|t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta )\\, \\) that as \\( N\\to \\infty \\, \\) , \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( |x(t)-x_{0}|\\leq \\beta ({\\mathrm {for}}|t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta )\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eIt remains to show that \\( x(t)\\, \\) satisfies the IVP \\( x(t)\u003dx_{0}+\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}f(x(s),s)ds\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( N\\to \\infty \\, \\) in the general iteration term. \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{{N+1}}(t)\\to x(t)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eand \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}f(x^{N}(s),s)ds\\to \\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}f(x(s),s)ds\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eFinally using the Lipschitz condition, \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\Bigg |}\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}\\left\\{f(x(s),s)-f(x^{N}(s),s)\\right\\}ds{\\Bigg |}\\leq {\\Bigg |}\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}L|x(s)-x^{N}(s)|ds{\\Bigg |}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\leq L\\delta \\max _{{|t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta }}|x(t)-x^{N}(t)|\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eand the right hand side tends to zero as \\( N\\to \\infty \\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eSolve \\( u\u0027+3u\u003d0,\\,\\,u(0)\u003d2\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFind the \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eintegrating factor\u003c/a\u003e \\( \\rho \u003de^{{\\int 3dx}}\u003de^{{3x}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMultiply it through the original equation:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( e^{{3x}}u\u0027+3e^{{3x}}u\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNotice the left hand side (LHS) of the last equation implies that\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {d}{dx}}\\left[e^{{3x}}u\\right]\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIntegrate wrt x:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( e^{{3x}}u\u003dc\\, \\) where \\( c \\) is a constant.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u(x)\u003dce^{{-3x}}\\, \\) is the homogeneous solution. Plug in the IC to get:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u(0)\u003dc\u003d2\\, \\) . So the unique solution that satisfies this IC is:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u(x)\u003d2e^{{-3x}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eOrdinary Differential Equations\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}y\u0027\u0027+7xy\u0027+8y\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe adjoint of an equation in the form\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( a(x)y\u0027\u0027+b(x)y\u0027+c(x)y\u003d0\\, \\) is\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( a(x)y\u0027\u0027+[2a\u0027(x)-b(x)]y\u0027+[a\u0027\u0027(x)-b\u0027(x)+c(x)]y\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo the adjoint for this DE is:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}y\u0027\u0027-3xy\u0027+3y\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAny solution of the adjoint equation is an integrating factor for the original problem. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y\u003dx\\, \\) is one solution. Multiply \\( x\\, \\) through the original DE.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{3}y\u0027\u0027+7x^{2}y\u0027+8xy\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis is an exact equation, since\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {d}{dx}}[a(x)y\u0027+b(x)y]\u003da\u0027(x)y\u0027+a(x)y\u0027\u0027+b\u0027(x)y+b(x)y\u0027\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( \u003da(x)y\u0027\u0027+[a\u0027(x)+b(x)]y\u0027+b\u0027(x)y\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the case of an exact equation the last relation equals 0, so\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( a(x)\u003dx^{3},a\u0027(x)\u003d3x^{2}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( b\u0027(x)\u003d8x,b(x)\u003d4x^{2}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {d}{dx}}[x^{3}y\u0027+4x^{2}y]\u003d0\\, \\) . Integrating, \u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{3}y\u0027+4x^{2}y\u003dc_{1}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( y\u0027+4x^{{-1}}y\u003dc_{1}x^{{-3}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUse the integrating factor \\( e^{{\\int 4x^{{-1}}dx}}\u003dx^{4}\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{4}y\u0027+4x^{3}y\u003dc_{1}x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {d}{dx}}[x^{4}y]\u003dc_{1}x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( x^{4}y\u003d{\\frac {c_{1}}{2}}x^{2}+c_{2}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally,\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y\u003d{\\frac {c_{1}}{2}}x^{{-2}}+c_{2}x^{{-4}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003d\u003dAlternate Solution\u003d\u003d \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( x^{2}y\u0027\u0027+7xy\u0027+8y\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis equation is recognizable as an Euler equation since the exponent on the \\( x \\) is the same as the order of the derivative in each term. So try for a solution in the form \\( y\u003dx^{r} \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y\u003dx^{r},\\quad y\u0027\u003drx^{{r-1}},\\quad y\u0027\u0027\u003dr(r-1)x^{{r-2}} \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubstituting these in the equation gives: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{2}r(r-1)x^{{(r-2)}}+7xrx^{{(r-1)}}+8x^{r}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{r}(r^{2}+6r+8)\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (r+2)(r+4)\u003d0,\\quad r\u003d-2,\\ -4\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe solution is therefore \\( y\u003dAx^{{-2}}+Bx^{{-4}},\\ x\\neq 0\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eOrdinary Differential Equations\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( y\u0027\u0027+2y\u0027+5y\u003de^{{-x}}\\sin(2x)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirst, solve the homogeneous equation to get \\( y_{h} \\) . Then, guess a particular solution \\( y_{p} \\) and add them together to get the general solution \\( y\u003dy_{h}+y_{p} \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y_{h}\u0027\u0027+2y_{h}\u0027+5y_{h}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSet up the characteristic equation and solve.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( m^{2}+2m+5\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo,\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( m\u003d{\\frac {-2\\pm {\\sqrt {4-20}}}{2}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( m\u003d-1\\pm 2i\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore, the solution to the homogeneous equation is\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y_{h}\u003dc_{1}e^{{-x}}\\cos(2x)+c_{2}e^{{-x}}\\sin(2x)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( y_{h}\u003de^{{-x}}[c_{1}\\cos(2x)+c_{2}\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eNow, check the homogeneous solution to see if any new information can be gained. Start by taking the first and second derivatives of \\( y_{h} \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y_{h}\u0027\u003de^{{-x}}[(-2c_{1}-c_{2})\\sin(2x)+(-c_{1}+2c_{2})\\cos(2x)]\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y_{h}\u0027\u0027\u003de^{{-x}}[(-4c_{1}-2c_{2})\\cos(2x)-(-2c_{1}+4c_{2})\\sin(2x)]-e^{{-x}}[(-2c_{1}-c_{2})\\sin(2x)+(-c_{1}+2c_{2})\\cos(2x)]\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( y_{h}\u0027\u0027\u003de^{{-x}}[(-3c_{1}-4c_{2})\\cos(2x)+(4c_{1}-3c_{2})\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubstitution of these derivatives into the homogeneous version of the original differential equation and collection of the exponential and trig functions gives the following relations.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( e^{{-x}}\\cos(2x)[-4c_{1}+c_{1}-4c_{2}-2c_{1}+2c_{2}+5c_{1}]\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( e^{{-x}}\\sin(2x)[4c_{1}-3c_{2}-4c_{1}-2c_{2}+5c_{2}]\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo from the first equation, \\( c_{1} \\) is arbitrary and \\( -2c_{2}\u003d0 \\) , so \\( c_{2}\u003d0 \\) . From the second equation, no new information is obtained. Therefore, a better homogeneous equation is\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y_{h}\u003dc_{1}e^{{-x}}\\cos(2x)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eNow a particular solution should be guessed. Based on the nonhomogeneous part of the original DE, \\( e^{{-x}}\\sin(2x) \\) , a first guess is \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y_{p}\u003dAe^{{-x}}[c_{3}\\cos(2x)+c_{4}\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) , with \\( A \\) , \\( c_{3} \\) , and \\( c_{4} \\) undetermined constants. \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut, the homogeneous solution appears as one of the terms of the guessed particular solution, so that term should be multiplied by \\( x \\) . Now, a guess for the particular solution is\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y_{p}\u003dAe^{{-x}}[c_{3}x\\cos(2x)+c_{4}\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFind the first and second derivatives of \\( y_{p} \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y_{p}\u0027\u003dAe^{{-x}}[-2c_{3}x\\sin(2x)+c_{3}\\cos(2x)+2c_{4}\\cos(2x)]-Ae^{{-x}}[c_{3}x\\cos(2x)+c_{4}\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( y_{p}\u0027\u003dAe^{{-x}}[-c_{3}x\\cos(2x)-2c_{3}x\\sin(2x)+(c_{3}+2c_{4})\\cos(2x)-c_{4}\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y_{p}\u0027\u0027\u003dAe^{{-x}}[2c_{3}x\\sin(2x)-c_{3}\\cos(2x)-4c_{3}x\\cos(2x)-2c_{3}\\sin(2x)-2(c_{3}+2c_{4})\\sin(2x)-2c_{4}\\cos(2x)]\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( -Ae^{{-x}}[-c_{3}x\\cos(2x)-2c_{3}x\\sin(2x)+(c_{3}+2c_{4})\\cos(2x)-c_{4}\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( y_{p}\u0027\u0027\u003dAe^{{-x}}[-3c_{3}x\\cos(2x)+4c_{3}x\\sin(2x)+(-2c_{3}-4c_{4})\\cos(2x)+(-4c_{3}-3c_{4})\\sin(2x)]\u003de^{{-x}}\\sin(2x)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubstitute these derivatives into the original DE to get these relations:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( Ae^{{-x}}[(-3c_{3}-2c_{3}+5c_{3})x\\cos(2x)+(2c_{3}+2c_{3}-4c_{3})x\\sin(2x)+\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( (-c_{3}-2c_{4}-c_{3}-2c_{4}+2c_{3}+4c_{4})\\cos(2x)+(-4c_{3}-4c_{4}+c_{4}-2c_{4}+5c_{4})\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo comparing the coefficients of \\( x\\sin(2x) \\) and \\( x\\cos(2x) \\) gives no information about \\( c_{3} \\) except that it is arbitrary so far. The other terms give the relations\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -4c_{3}\u003d1\\, \\) so that \\( c_{3}\u003d{\\frac {-1}{4}}\\, \\) , and\u003cbr\u003e \\( c_{4} \\) is arbitrary, so that the particular solution is\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y_{p}\u003de^{{-x}}[-{\\frac {1}{4}}x\\cos(2x)+c_{4}\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, the general solution is \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y(x)\u003dy_{h}+y_{p}\u003de^{{-x}}[-{\\frac {1}{4}}x\\cos(2x)+c_{1}\\cos(2x)+c_{4}\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eOrdinary Differential Equations\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( y\u0027\u0027-3y\u0027+2y\u003d3e^{{x}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSet up and solve the characteristic equation for the homogeneous solution.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( m^{2}-3m+2\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( m\u003d{\\frac {3\\pm {\\sqrt {9-8}}}{2}}\u003d{\\frac {3}{2}}\\pm {\\frac {1}{2}}\u003d2,1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo the solution to the homogeneous equation is \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y_{h}\u003dc_{1}e^{{2x}}+c_{2}e^{{x}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGuess a particular solution similar to the structure of the nonhomogeneous part of the DE. Multiply the exponential term by \\( x \\) since it is included in the homogeneous solution.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y_{p}\u003dAxe^{{x}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTake first and second derivatives of \\( y_{p} \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y_{p}\u0027\u003dAxe^{{x}}+Ae^{{x}}\u003dAe^{{x}}(x+1)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y_{p}\u0027\u0027\u003dAe^{{x}}+Ae^{{x}}(x+1)\u003dAe^{{x}}(x+2)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePlug these derivatives into the original problem.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( Ae^{{x}}(x+2-3(x+1)+2x)\u003d3e^{{x}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( -Ae^{{x}}\u003d3e^{{x}}\\, \\) so that \\( A\u003d-3\\, \\) and so the particular solution is \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y_{p}\u003d-3xe^{{x}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, the general solution is\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y\u003dy_{h}+y_{p}\u003dc_{1}e^{{2x}}+c_{2}e^{{x}}-3xe^{{x}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eOrdinary Differential Equations\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( y\u0027\u0027-y\u0027+2y\u003d10e^{{-x}}\\sin(x)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFind a particular solution \\( y_{p}\\, \\) , by finding a generalization of the equation which has the original problem as the complex part. \\( y_{z}\\, \\) is the imaginary particular part.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (D^{2}-D+2)y_{z}\u003d10e^{{(-1+i)x}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe right hand side of the first equation is the complex part of the right hand side of the last equation. Solve for \\( y_{z} \\) and find the imaginary part of the answer. This will be the answer to the original problem.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y_{z}\u003d{\\frac {10e^{{(-1+i)x}}}{(-1+i)^{2}-(-1+i)+2}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y_{z}\u003d{\\frac {10e^{{(-1+i)x}}}{3-3i}}\u003d{\\frac {10}{3}}{\\frac {(1+i)}{2}}e^{{-x}}(\\cos(x)+i\\sin(x))\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFind the imaginary part of the last equation.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y_{p}\u003d{\\mathrm {Im}}(y_{z})\u003d{\\frac {5}{3}}e^{{-x}}(\\cos(x)+\\sin(x))\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eOrdinary Differential Equations\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eA ball is thrown straight up from the ground. How high will it go?\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe height of the ball at time \\( t\\, \\) is \\( x(t)\\, \\) , and the force acting on the ball is \\( -mg\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNewton\u0027s second law gives the relation\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( m{\\frac {d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}}+mg\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( m\u003d1\\, \\) for convenience.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}}+g\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIntegrate the last equation.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {dx(t)}{dt}}+gt+C\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo get \\( C\\, \\) , start with an initial velocity \\( v_{0}\\, \\) and set \\( t\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( v_{0}+C\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo now,\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {dx}{dt}}+gt-v_{0}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIntegrate again.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x(t)+{\\frac {1}{2}}gt^{2}-v_{0}t+D\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSince we have set \\( x(0)\u003d0\\, \\) , \\( D\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe equation of position is \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x(t)\u003d-{\\frac {1}{2}}gt^{2}+v_{0}t\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo find the maximum, set the first derivative equal to 0.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -gt+v_{0}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( t_{{max}}\u003d{\\frac {v_{0}}{g}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCheck that the second derivative at this point is negative.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x\u0027\u0027\\left({\\frac {v_{0}}{g}}\\right)\u003d-g\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo the answer is this point \\( t_{{max}}\\, \\) evaluated in the position function.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x_{{max}}\u003dx\\left({\\frac {v_{0}}{g}}\\right)\u003d{\\frac {v_{0}^{2}}{2g}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eOrdinary Differential Equations\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eCalculus\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eConsider the \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003einitial value problem\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/p\u003e  \\( {\\dot {x}}\u003d|x|^{{2/q}},x(0)\u003d0\\, \\)  \n\u003cp\u003ewhere \\( \\,q \\) is a positive integer. Find all values of \\( \\,q \\) for which there is a unique solution. In the latter case, justify your answer by using an appropriate theorem. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( q\u003d1\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\dot {x}}\u003d|x|^{2}\u003dx^{2}, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCheck the \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eLipschitz condition\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( |f(x,t)-f(y,t)|\u003d|x^{2}-y^{2}|\\leq |x+y||x-y|\u003dL|x-y|\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo \\( f\\, \\) is Lipschitz if \\( x\\, \\) is bounded. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolving the DE, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\dot {x}}\u003dx^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {dx}{dt}}\u003dx^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {dx}{x^{2}}}\u003ddt\\implies {\\frac {-1}{x}}\u003dt+c\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x\u003d{\\frac {-1}{t+c}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x(0)\u003d{\\frac {-1}{c}}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere is no solution to this DE. \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( q\u003d2\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\dot {x}}\u003d|x|\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCheck Lipschitz. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( |f(x,t)-f(y,t)|\u003d||x|-|y||\\leq L|x-y|\\, \\) is true. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolve the DE. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\dot {x}}\u003d|x|,x(0)\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eif \\( x\u0026lt;0\\, \\) , \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {dx}{dt}}\u003d-x\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {dx}{-x}}\u003ddt\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -\\ln x\u003dt+c_{1}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x(t)\u003d-e^{{t+c_{1}}}\\,\u003dc_{2}e^{t} \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x(0)\u003dc_{2}\u003d0\\implies c_{2}\u003d0\\implies x\u003d0\\, \\) is the unique solution. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e If \\( x\u003d0\\, \\) , \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {dx}{dt}}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x(t)\u003dc_{3}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x(0)\u003d0\\implies c_{3}\u003d0\\implies x\u003d0\\, \\) is the unique solution. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e If \\( x\u0026gt;0\\, \\) , \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {dx}{dt}}\u003dx\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {dx}{x}}\u003ddt\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\ln x\u003dt+c_{4}\\, \\) solution. \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( q\u003dn\\geq 3\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\dot {x}}\u003d|x|^{{2/n}}\u003dx^{{2/n}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTest Lipschitz. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( |x^{{2/n}}-y^{{2/n}}|\u003d|(x^{{1/n}}+y^{{1/n}})(x^{{1/n}}-y^{{1/n}})|\\leq |x^{{1/n}}+y^{{1/n}}||x-y|\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut \\( (x^{{1/n}}+y^{{1/n}})\\, \\) is not bounded by a constant so \\( x\\, \\) is not Lipschitz and therefore there is not a unique solution. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolve the DE. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\dot {x}}\u003d|x|^{{2/n}}\u003dx^{{2/n}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{{-2/n}}dx\u003ddt\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {nx^{{\\frac {n-2}{n}}}}{n-2}}\u003dt+c_{1}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x^{{\\frac {n-2}{n}}}\u003d{\\frac {n-2}{n}}(t+c_{1})\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x(t)\u003d\\left[{\\frac {n-2}{n}}(t+c_{1})\\right]^{{\\frac {n}{n-2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x(0)\u003d\\left[{\\frac {n-2}{n}}c_{1}\\right]^{{\\frac {n}{n-2}}}\u003d0\\implies c_{1}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo \\( x(t)\u003d\\left[{\\frac {n-2}{n}}t\\right]^{{\\frac {n}{n-2}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are infinitely many solutions because the equation holds for all \\( n\\geq 3\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eSolve the system of ODE\u0027s: \\( {\\begin{cases}x_{t}\u003d6x-3y\\\\y_{t}\u003d2x+y\\end{cases}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGuess the solutions \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x\u003dAe^{{\\lambda t}},x_{t}\u003d\\lambda Ae^{{\\lambda t}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( y\u003dBe^{{\\lambda t}},y_{t}\u003d\\lambda Be^{{\\lambda t}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePlug these guesses into the original equation.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\lambda Ae^{{\\lambda t}}\u003d6Ae^{{\\lambda t}}-3Be^{{\\lambda t}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( \\lambda Be^{{\\lambda t}}\u003d2Ae^{{\\lambda t}}+Be^{{\\lambda t}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWrite this system of equations in matrix form.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\begin{bmatrix}6-\\lambda \u0026amp;-3\\\\2\u0026amp;1-\\lambda \\\\\\end{bmatrix}} \\) \\( {\\begin{bmatrix}A\\\\B\\end{bmatrix}}\u003d{\\begin{bmatrix}0\\\\0\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFind lambda by taking the determinant of the matrix.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( (6-\\lambda )(1-\\lambda )+6\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( 6-7\\lambda +\\lambda ^{2}+6\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( \\lambda ^{2}-7\\lambda +12\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( \\lambda \u003d{\\frac {7\\pm {\\sqrt {49-48}}}{2}}\u003d{\\frac {7\\pm 1}{2}}\u003d3,4\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are two values for lambda, so there will be two solutions and the sum of these two solutions is the general solution.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e is \\( x\u003dC_{1}e^{{3t}},y\u003dC_{1}e^{{3t}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf \\( \\lambda \u003d4\\, \\) ,\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e B\u003dC_{2},A\u003d(3/2)C_{2}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThen the general solution is\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\(       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind a fundamental matrix, \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003echaracteristic multipliers\u003c/a\u003e (Floquet multipliers) and \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003echaracteristic exponents\u003c/a\u003e (Floquet exponents) for the system \\( {\\begin{cases}x_{1}\u0027\u003d-x_{1}+x_{2}\\\\x_{2}\u0027\u003d\\left(1+\\cos t-{\\frac {\\sin t}{2+\\cos t}}\\right)x_{2}\\end{cases}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStart with the second equation since it does not involve the first. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {dx_{2}}{dt}}\u003d\\left(1+\\cos t-{\\frac {\\sin t}{2+\\cos t}}\\right)x_{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSeperate variables. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {dx_{2}}{x_{2}}}\u003d\\left(1+\\cos t-{\\frac {\\sin t}{2+\\cos t}}\\right)dt\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIntegrate. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\ln x_{2}\u003dt+\\sin t+\\ln(2+\\cos t)+c_{1}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExponentiate. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x_{2}\u003dc_{2}e^{{t+\\sin t}}(2+\\cos t)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow use this equation in the first ODE. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x_{1}\u0027\u003d-x_{1}+c_{2}e^{{t+\\sin t}}(2+\\cos t)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x_{1}\u0027+x_{1}\u003dc_{2}e^{{t+\\sin t}}(2+\\cos t)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUse the \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eintegrating factor\u003c/a\u003e \\( \\rho \u003de^{{\\int dt}}\u003de^{t}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\left[e^{t}x_{1}\\right]\u0027\u003dc_{2}e^{{2t+\\sin t}}(2+\\cos t)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIntegrate. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( e^{t}x_{1}\u003dc_{2}e^{{2t+\\sin t}}+c_{3}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMultiply by \\( e^{{-t}}\\, \\) (which is okay because it\u0027s always positive). \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x_{1}\u003dc_{2}e^{{t+\\sin t}}+c_{3}e^{{-t}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA fundamental matrix is \\( X(t)\u003d{\\begin{bmatrix}{\\frac {\\partial x_{1}}{\\partial c_{2}}}\u0026amp;{\\frac {\\partial x_{1}}{\\partial c_{3}}}\\\\{\\frac t)\u0026amp;0\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( X^{{-1}}(0)\u003d{\\begin{bmatrix}0\u0026amp;1/3\\\\1\u0026amp;-1/3\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\(       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFor the differential equation \\( u\u0027\u0027+a_{1}(t)u\u0027+a_{2}(t)u\u003d0\\, \\) , where \\( a_{i}(t+T)\u003da_{i}(t)\\, \\) for all \\( t(i\u003d1,2)\\, \\) , show that the characteristic multipliers \\( \\rho _{1}\\, \\) and \\( \\rho _{2}\\, \\) satisfy the relation \\( \\rho _{1}\\rho _{2}\u003d\\exp \\left\\{-\\int _{0}^{T}a_{1}(t)dt\\right\\}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( x_{1}\u003du,x_{2}\u003du\u0027\\, \\) . Now the equation can be written as a first order system: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( x_{1}\u0027\u003dx_{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( x_{2}\u0027\u003d-a_{1}(t)x_{2}-a_{2}(t)x_{1}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( A\u003d{\\begin{bmatrix}0\u0026amp;1\\\\-a_{2}(t)\u0026amp;-a_{1}(t)\\\\\\end{bmatrix}} \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Assume we have two linearly independent solutions \\( u^{1}\\, \\) and \\( u^{2}\\, \\) .       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFor the equation \\( u\u0027\u0027+(\\delta +\\epsilon \\cos t+\\epsilon \\sin 2t)u\u003d0\\, \\) show that the conditions for \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eparametric resonance\u003c/a\u003e are \\( \\epsilon \u003d0\\, \\) and \\( \\delta \u003dk^{2}\\, \\) or \\( (k+1/2)^{2},(k\u003d0,1,2,...)\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let \\( \\epsilon \u003d0\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThen \\( u\u0027\u0027+\\delta u\u003d0\\, \\) has two L.I. solutions \\( \\cos {\\sqrt {\\delta }}t\\, \\) and \\( {\\frac {\\sin {\\sqrt {\\delta }}t}{{\\sqrt {\\delta }}}}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo the \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003efundamental matrix\u003c/a\u003e fundamental matrix. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe monodromy matrix \\( B\\, \\) is the inverse of the fundamental matrix evaluated at zero times the fundamental matrix evaluted at the period of the coefficients. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( B\u003dX^{{-1}}(0)\\cdot X(2\\pi )\u003dI\\cdot X(2\\pi )\u003dX(2\\pi )\u003d{\\begin{bmatrix}\\cos {\\sqrt {\\delta }}2\\pi \u0026amp;{\\frac {\\sin
