      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eConsider the system of equations \\( {\\begin{cases}x\u0027\u003dy-xf(x,y)\\\\y\u0027\u003d-x-yf(x,y)\\end{cases}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFind a \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eLyapunov function\u003c/a\u003e to determine the stability of the equilibrium solution \\( (0,0)\\, \\) . Consider the three cases in your calculations: a) \\( f(x,y)\\, \\) positive semidefinate, b) \\( f(x,y)\\, \\) positive definite and c) \\( f(x,y)\\, \\) negative definate. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\begin{cases}x\u0027\u003dy-xf(x,y)\\\\y\u0027\u003d-x-yf(x,y)\\end{cases}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( L\u003dx^{2}+y^{2}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {\\partial L}{\\partial t}}\u003d2x{\\dot {x}}+2y{\\dot {y}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d2x\\left[y-xf(x,y)\\right]+2y\\left[-x-yf(x,y)\\right]\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d-2x^{2}f(x,y)-2y^{2}f(x,y)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d-f(x,y)[2x^{2}+2y^{2}]\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf \\( f(x,y)\\, \\) is positive semidefinite, then \\( {\\frac {\\partial L}{\\partial t}}\\leq 0\\, \\) so the zero solution is uniformly stable. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf \\( f(x,y)\\, \\) is positive definite, then \\( {\\frac {\\partial L}{\\partial t}}\u0026lt;0\\, \\) so the zero solution is asymptotically stable. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf \\( f(x,y)\\, \\) is negative definite, then \\( {\\frac {\\partial L}{\\partial t}}\u0026gt;0\\, \\) so the zero solution is unstable. \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( y\u0027+xy\u003dxy^{2}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA \u003ca href\u003d\"http://mathworld.wolfram.com/BernoulliDifferentialEquation.html\" rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eBernoulli Equation\u003c/a\u003e has the form \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y\u0027+p(x)y\u003dq(x)y^{n}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd for these types of DE\u0027s a substitution of \\( z\u003dy^{{1-n}}\\, \\) is recommended. In the present problem, \\( n\u003d2\\, \\) and so\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( z\u003dy^{{-1}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y\u003dz^{{-1}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y\u0027\u003d-{\\frac {z\u0027}{z^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubstituting these new variables into the original equation,\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( -{\\frac {z\u0027}{z^{2}}}+{\\frac {x}{z}}\u003d{\\frac {x}{z^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( z\u0027-xz\u003d-x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUse the integrating factor \\( e^{{\\int -xdx}}\u003de^{{-x^{2}/2}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( e^{{-x^{2}/2}}z\u0027-e^{{-x^{2}/2}}xz\u003d-e^{{-x^{2}/2}}x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {d}{dx}}[e^{{-x^{2}/2}}z]\u003d-e^{{-x^{2}/2}}x\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( e^{{-x^{2}/2}}z\u003de^{{-x^{2}/2}}+c_{1}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( z\u003d1+c_{1}e^{{x^{2}/2}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUndoing the substitution \\( z\u003dy^{{-1}} \\) ,\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y^{{-1}}\u003d1+c_{1}e^{{x^{2}/2}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y\u003d(1+c_{1}e^{{x^{2}/2}})^{{-1}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eOrdinary Differential Equations\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

    {
      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {1}{y}}\u003d{\\frac {y\u0027\u0027}{1+y\u0027^{2}}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMultiply both sides by \\( 2y\u0027\\, \\) :\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {2y\u0027}{y}}\u003d{\\frac {2y\u0027y\u0027\u0027}{1+y\u0027^{2}}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Observe that the numerator of the term on the right side is the derivative (with respect to \\( x \\) ) of the denominator of that term (indeed, that is why the factor \\( 2y\u0027 \\) was chosen -- a sort of \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eintegrating factor\u003c/a\u003e). Integrate both sides with respect to \\( x \\) ; the result is\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( 2\\ln |y|\u003d\\ln(1+y\u0027^{2})+a\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e (Alternatively, since the differential equation does not explicitly involve \\( x \\) , the substitution \\( {\\frac {dy}{dx}}\u003dp,{\\frac {d^{2}y}{dx^{2}}}\u003dp{\\frac {dp}{dy}} \\) converts the equation to a first-order equation in \\( p \\) and \\( y \\) which is separable. Integrating and back-substituting \\( dy/dx\\, \\) for \\( p\\, \\) yields the same result as given above, as of course it must.)\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Exponentiating both sides, we get \\( y^{2}\u003dc^{2}(1+y\u0027^{2})\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e where \\( c^{2}\u003de^{a}\\, \\) (we are free to write \\( c^{2} \\) since \\( e^{a}\u0026gt;0 \\) for all real \\( a \\) ).\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolving the above for \\( y\u0027 \\) ,\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y\u0027\u003d\\pm {\\frac {{\\sqrt {y^{2}-c^{2}}}}{c}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Divide both sides by \\( {\\sqrt {y^{2}-c^{2}}} \\) and integrate:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int {\\frac {dy}{{\\sqrt {y^{2}-c^{2}}}}}\u003d\\int \\pm {\\frac {dx}{c}} \\) (where we have used \\( y\u0027dx\u003ddy \\) in the integral on the left)\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUse the trig substitution \\( y\u003dc\\,\\sec(\\theta ) \\) , \\( dy\u003dc\\,\\sec(\\theta )\\tan(\\theta )\\,d\\theta \\) to get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int \\sec(\\theta )\\,d\\theta \u003d\\pm \\int {\\frac {dx}{c}}\\qquad \\) Integrating, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\ln {|\\sec(\\theta )+\\tan(\\theta )|}\u003d\\pm x/c+d\\, \\) or after back-substitution,\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\ln {|y/c+{\\sqrt {y^{2}/c^{2}-1}}|}\u003d\\pm x/c+d\\qquad \\) Exponentiating both sides and multiplying both sides by \\( c \\) ,\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y+{\\sqrt {y^{2}-1}}\u003dce^{{\\pm (x/c)+d}}\\qquad \\) Solving this for \\( y \\) ,\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y\u003d{\\frac {c\\left(e^{{2(\\pm (x/c)+d)}}+1\\right)}{2e^{{\\pm (x/c)+d}}}}\u003dc\\,{\\frac {e^{{\\pm (x/c)+d}}+e^{{\\mp (x/c)-d}}}{2}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEither case may be written in the form \\( y\u003dc\\cosh(x/c\\,+\\,b)\\, \\) where \\( b \\) and \\( c \\) are arbitrary constants, as may be verified by substituting this solution into the original differential equation.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eOrdinary Differential Equations\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eGiven the differential equation \\( x^{{3}}y\u0027\u0027+4x^{{2}}y\u0027+3y\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ei.e., \u0026nbsp; \\( y\u0027\u0027+{\\frac {4x^{{2}}}{x^{{3}}}}y\u0027+{\\frac {3}{x^{{3}}}}y\u003d0, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e? \\( y\u0027\u0027+{\\frac {4}{x}}y\u0027+{\\frac {3}{x^{{3}}}}y\u003d0, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo \\( P(x)\u003d{\\frac {4}{x}},Q(x)\u003d{\\frac {3}{x^{{3}}}}, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\therefore x\u003d0 \\) is a singular point because the functions P(x) and Q(x) are not analytic at x\u003d0. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo check for regularity consider the functions \\( (x-0) \\) ,P(x) and \\( (x-0)^{{2}} \\) ,Q(x)\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ei.e., \\( x{\\frac {4}{x}} \\) and \\( x^{{2}}{\\frac {3}{x^{{3}}}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ei.e., 4 and \\( {\\frac {3}{x}} \\) which are not analytic at \\( x\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHence x\u003d0 is and irregualr singular point \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eUsing Frobenius\u0027 Theorem find two linearly independent solutions to the following equation. \\( x\u003d0 \\) is a regular singular point. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\displaystyle 2x^{{2}}y\u0027\u0027-xy\u0027+\\left(x^{{2}}+1\\right)y\u003d0 \\) \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e \n\u003cspan\u003eProblem Setup\u003c/span\u003e \n\u003cp\u003eSubstitute:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( y\u003d\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}\\, \\) , \\( \\displaystyle y\u0027\u003d\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-1}} \\) , and \\( \\displaystyle y\u0027\u0027\u003d\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)\\left(n+r-1\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-2}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhich yields:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\displaystyle 2x^{{2}}\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)\\left(n+r-1\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-2}}-x\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-1}}+x^{{2}}\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}+\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimplify:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\displaystyle \\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}2\\left(n+r\\right)\\left(n+r-1\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}-\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}+\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r+2}}+\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe now want to have all the powers of x match. In order to do this we will substitute k for the value of n:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\displaystyle \\underbrace {{\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}2\\left(n+r\\right)\\left(n+r-1\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}}}_{{k\u003dn}}-\\underbrace {{\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}}}_{{k\u003dn}}+\\underbrace {{\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r+2}}}}_{{k\u003dn+2}}+\\underbrace {{\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}}}_{{k\u003dn}}\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhich yields:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\displaystyle \\sum _{{k\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}2\\left(k+r\\right)\\left(k+r-1\\right)C_{{k}}x^{{k+r}}-\\sum _{{k\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(k+r\\right)C_{{k}}x^{{k+r}}+\\sum _{{{\\color {red}k\u003d2}}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{{\\color {red}k-2}}}x^{{{\\color {red}k+r}}}+\\sum _{{k\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{k}}x^{{k+r}}\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNotice that in the third term, the index of summation, the index for the constant, and exponent of \\( x \\) all changed. Now, in order to add together the sums we need to have the indexes for each sum match. To do this we list the terms for each sum at \\( k\u003d0,1,... \\) until each index is the same. In this example we need to have the \\( k\u003d0 \\) indexes match the \\( k\u003d2 \\) index so we list the terms at \\( k\u003d0 \\) and \\( k\u003d1 \\) . In order to reduce the amount of work required we will add together the sums where \\( k\u003d0 \\) and then factor out the \\( C_{k} \\) term. At this point we can also factor out the \\( x^{r} \\) term.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\displaystyle \\left[\\sum _{{k\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left[2\\left(k+r\\right)\\left(k+r-1\\right)x^{{k}}-\\left(k+r\\right)x^{{k}}+x^{{k}}\\right]C_{{k}}+\\sum _{{k\u003d2}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{k-2}}x^{{k}}\\right]x^{{r}}\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFrom the sum:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\displaystyle \\sum _{{k\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left[2\\left(k+r\\right)\\left(k+r-1\\right)x^{{k}}-\\left(k+r\\right)x^{{k}}+x^{{k}}\\right]C_{{k}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe first two terms are:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\displaystyle \\left[2\\left(0+r\\right)(0+r-1)x^{{0}}-(0+r)x^{{0}}+x^{{0}}\\right]C_{{0}}\u003d\\left(2r^{{2}}-3r+1\\right)C_{{0}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eand\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\displaystyle \\left[2\\left(1+r\\right)\\left(1+r-1\\right)x^{{1}}-(1+r)x^{{1}}+x^{{1}}\\right]C_{{1}}\u003d\\left(2r^{{2}}+r\\right)C_{{1}}x \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhich finally gives us:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\displaystyle x^{{r}}\\cdot \\left[\\left(2r^{{2}}-3r+1\\right)C_{{0}}+\\left(2r^{{2}}+r\\right)C_{{1}}x+\\sum _{{k\u003d2}}^{{\\infty }}\\left[2\\left(k+r\\right)\\left(k+r-1\\right)x^{{k}}-\\left(k+r\\right)x^{{k}}+x^{{k}}\\right]C_{{k}}+C_{{k-2}}x^{{k}}\\right]\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e \n\u003cspan\u003eSolving\u003c/span\u003e \n\u003cp\u003eNow we are ready to solve the equation. We start by equating the terms on the left hand side with the terms on the right hand side (which are all equal to zero). Which gives us the following implications:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e(1) \\( \\displaystyle \\left(2r^{{2}}-3r+1\\right)C_{{0}}\u003d0\\rightarrow \\left(2r-1\\right)\\left(r-1\\right)C_{0}\u003d0 \\) hence \\( \\displaystyle r\u003d1 \\) and \\( \\displaystyle r\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e(2) \\( \\displaystyle \\left(2r^{{2}}+r\\right)C_{{1}}x\u003d0 \\) hence \\( \\displaystyle C_{1}\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e(3) \\( \\displaystyle \\left[2\\left(k+r\\right)\\left(k+r-1\\right)x^{{k}}-\\left(k+r\\right)x^{{k}}+x^{{k}}\\right]C_{{k}}+C_{{k-2}}x^{{k}}\u003d0\\;,\\;k\u003d2,3,4,\\ldots \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\;\\Rightarrow C_{{k}}\u003d{\\frac {-C_{{k-2}}}{2\\left(k+r\\right)(k+r-1)-\\left(k+r\\right)+1}}\\;,\\;k\u003d2,3,4,\\ldots \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe can now substitute the values for \\( r \\) that satisfy (1) into (3) to yield two different recurrence relations: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e(4) \\( \\displaystyle r\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}\\;,\\;C_{{k}}\u003d{\\frac {-C_{{k-2}}}{2\\left(k+{\\frac {1}{2}}\\right)(k+{\\frac {1}{2}}-1)-\\left(k+{\\frac {1}{2}}\\right)+1}}\\;,\\;k\u003d2,3,4,\\ldots \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( \\displaystyle \\Rightarrow \\;C_{{k}}\u003d{\\frac {-C_{{k-2}}}{k\\left(2k-1\\right)}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e(5) \\( \\displaystyle {\\displaystyle r\u003d1\\;,\\;C_{{k}}\u003d{\\frac {-C_{{k-2}}}{2\\left(k+1\\right)(k+1-1)-\\left(k+1\\right)+1}}\\;,\\;k\u003d2,3,4,\\ldots } \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( \\displaystyle \\Rightarrow \\;C_{{k}}\u003d{\\frac {-C_{{k-2}}}{k\\left(2k+1\\right)}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd then using our values for \\( k\\;,\\;k\u003d2,3,4,\\ldots \\) we can find the series solutions for the differential equation.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e    \\( \\displaystyle k \\)   (4) \\( \\displaystyle \\;\\;C_{{k}}\u003d{\\frac {-C_{{k-2}}}{k\\left(2k-1\\right)}} \\)   (5) \\( \\displaystyle \\;\\;C_{{k}}\u003d{\\frac {-C_{{k-2}}}{k\\left(2k+1\\right)}} \\)    \\( \\displaystyle 2 \\)   \\( \\displaystyle C_{{2}}\u003d{\\frac {-C_{{0}}}{6}} \\)   \\( \\displaystyle C_{{2}}\u003d{\\frac {-C_{{0}}}{10}} \\)    \\( \\displaystyle 3 \\)   \\( \\displaystyle C_{{3}}\u003d0 \\)   \\( \\displaystyle C_{{3}}\u003d0 \\)    \\( \\displaystyle 4 \\)   \\( \\displaystyle C_{{4}}\u003d{\\frac {-C_{{2}}}{28}}\u003d{\\frac {C_{0}}{168}} \\)   \\( \\displaystyle C_{{4}}\u003d{\\frac {-C_{{2}}}{36}}\u003d{\\frac {C_{0}}{360}} \\)    \\( \\displaystyle 5 \\)   \\( \\displaystyle C_{{5}}\u003d0 \\)   \\( \\displaystyle C{5}\u003d0 \\)    \\( \\displaystyle 6 \\)   \\( \\displaystyle C_{{6}}\u003d{\\frac {-C_{{4}}}{66}}\u003d{\\frac {-C_{0}}{11088}} \\)   \\( \\displaystyle C_{{6}}\u003d{\\frac {-C_{{4}}}{78}}\u003d{\\frac {-C_{0}}{28080}} \\) \n\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003cbr\u003e \n\u003cp\u003eAnd so on... \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis gives us the terms for our infinite sum and from that we have the solutions to the differential equation. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor (4) where \\( \\displaystyle r\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}} \\) let \\( \\displaystyle C_{0}\u003d1 \\) so the sum is \\( \\displaystyle y_{{1}}(x)\u003dx^{{{\\frac {1}{2}}}}\\left(1-{\\frac {1}{6}}x^{{2}}+{\\frac {1}{168}}x^{{4}}-{\\frac {1}{11088}}x^{{6}}+\\ldots \\right) \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor (5) where \\( \\displaystyle r\u003d1 \\) let \\( \\displaystyle C_{0}\u003d1 \\) so the sum is \\( \\displaystyle y_{{2}}(x)\u003dx\\left(1-{\\frac {1}{10}}x^{{2}}+{\\frac {1}{360}}x^{{4}}-{\\frac {1}{28080}}x^{{6}}+\\ldots \\right) \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhich means the general solution \\( \\displaystyle y\u003dC_{{1}}y_{{1}}(x)+C_{{2}}y_{{2}}(x) \\) is:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\displaystyle y\u003dC_{{1}}x^{{{\\frac {1}{2}}}}\\left(1-{\\frac {1}{6}}x^{{2}}+{\\frac {1}{168}}x^{{4}}-{\\frac {1}{11088}}x^{{6}}+\\ldots \\right)+C_{{2}}x\\left(1-{\\frac {1}{10}}x^{{2}}+{\\frac {1}{360}}x^{{4}}-{\\frac {1}{28080}}x^{{6}}+\\ldots \\right) \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eWe use the method of Frobenius to obtain two linearly independent series solution. Where x\u003d0 is a regular singular point of the differential equation. The general solution on \\( (0,\\infty ) \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\displaystyle 2xy\u0027\u0027-\\left(3+2x\\right)y\u0027+y\u003d0 \\) \u003c/p\u003e \n\u003cspan\u003eProblem Setup\u003c/span\u003e \n\u003cp\u003eLet\u0026nbsp;:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\displaystyle y\u003d\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}} \\) , \\( \\displaystyle y\u0027\u003d\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-1}} \\) , and \\( \\displaystyle y\u0027\u0027\u003d\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)\\left(n+r-1\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-2}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubstitute into DE:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\displaystyle 2x\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)\\left(n+r-1\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-2}}-3\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-1}}-2x\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-1}}+\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimplify:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\displaystyle \\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}2\\left(n+r\\right)\\left(n+r-1\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-1}}-\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}3\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-1}}-\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}2\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}+\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe want to have all the powers of x match. In order to do this we will substitute k for the value of n:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\displaystyle \\underbrace {{\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}2\\left(n+r\\right)\\left(n+r-1\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-1}}}}_{{k\u003dn-1}}-\\underbrace {{\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}3\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-1}}}}_{{k\u003dn-1}}-\\underbrace {{\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}2\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}}}_{{k\u003dn}}+\\underbrace {{\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}}}_{{k\u003dn}}\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhich yields:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\displaystyle \\sum _{{{\\color {red}k\u003d-1}}}^{{\\infty }}2\\left(k+r+1\\right)\\left(k+r\\right)C_{{k+1}}x^{{{\\color {red}k+r}}}-\\sum _{{{\\color {red}k\u003d-1}}}^{{\\infty }}3\\left(k+r+1\\right)C_{{k+1}}x^{{{\\color {red}k+r}}}-\\sum _{{{\\color {red}k\u003d0}}}^{{\\infty }}2\\left(k+r\\right)C_{{k}}x^{{{\\color {red}k+r}}}+\\sum _{{{\\color {red}k\u003d0}}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{k}}x^{{{\\color {red}k+r}}}\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow, in order to add together the sums we need to have the indexes for each sum match. To do this we list the terms for the first and second sum at \\( k\u003d-1 \\) . In this example we need to have the \\( k\u003d-1 \\) indexes match the \\( k\u003d0 \\) . In order to reduce the amount of work required we will add together the sums where \\( k\u003d-1 \\) and then factor out the \\( C_{k}+1 \\) term. At this point we can also factor out the \\( x^{r} \\) term.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe first two terms are:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\displaystyle \\left[2r\\left(r-1\\right)C_{{0}}x^{{-1}}-3rC_{{0}}x^{{-1}}\\right]x^{{r}}\u003d\\left[r\\left(2r-5\\right)C_{{0}}x^{{-1}}\\right]x^{{r}} \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFrom the sum we have: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\displaystyle x^{{r}}\\left[\\sum _{{k\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left[2\\left(k+r+1\\right)\\left(k+r\\right)C_{{k+1}}-3\\left(k+r+1\\right)C_{{k+1}}-2\\left(k+r\\right)C_{{k}}+C_{{k}}\\right]x^{k}\\right]\u003dx^{{r}}\\left[\\sum _{{k\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}[C_{{k+1}}\\left(k+r+1\\right)\\left(2k+2r-3\\right)-C_{{k}}\\left(2k+2r-1\\right)]x^{k}\\right] \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally we now have:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\displaystyle x^{{r}}\\left[r\\left(2r-5\\right)C_{{0}}x^{{-1}}+\\sum _{{k\u003d0}}^{{\\infty }}[C_{{k+1}}\\left(k+r+1\\right)\\left(2k+2r-3\\right)-C_{{k}}\\left(2k+2r-1\\right)]x^{k}\\right]\u003d0 \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e \n\u003cspan\u003eSolving\u003c/span\u003e \n\u003cp\u003eNow we are ready to solve the equation. We start by equating the terms on the left hand side with the terms on the right hand side (which are all equal to zero). Which gives us the following implications:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e(1) \\( \\displaystyle r\\left(2r-5\\right)C_{{0}}\u003d0\\rightarrow \\) the indicial roots are: \\( \\displaystyle \\;r\u003d0\\; \\) and \\( \\displaystyle \\;r\u003d{\\frac {5}{2}}\\; \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e (2) \\( \\displaystyle C_{{k+1}}\\left(k+r+1\\right)\\left(2k+2r-3\\right)-C_{{k}}\\left(2k+2r-1\\right)\u003d0,\\;k\u003d0,1,2,\\ldots \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe recurrence relation is:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\;\\Rightarrow C_{{k+1}}\u003d{\\frac {C_{{k}}\\left(2k+2r-1\\right)}{\\left(k+r+1\\right)(2k+2r-3)}}\\;,\\;k\u003d0,1,2,\\ldots \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe can now substitute the values for \\( \\displaystyle r \\) that satisfy (1) into (2) to yield two different recurrence relations: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e(4) \\( r\u003d0\\;,\\;C_{{k+1}}\u003d{\\frac {C_{{k}}\\left(2k-1\\right)}{\\left(k+1\\right)(2k-3)}}\\;,\\;k\u003d0,1,2,\\ldots \\) \u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e(5) \\( r\u003d{\\frac {5}{2}}\\;,\\;C_{{k+1}}\u003d{\\frac {C_{{k}}\\left(2k+4\\right)}{\\left(2k+7\\right)(k+1)}}\\;,\\;k\u003d0,1,2,\\ldots \\) \u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now we can let \\( \\;k\u003d0,1,2,\\ldots \\) on equations (4) and (5) for the first 3 terms:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e    \\( \\displaystyle k \\)   (4) \\( \\displaystyle \\;\\;C_{{k+1}}\u003d{\\frac {C_{{k}}\\left(2k-1\\right)}{\\left(k+1\\right)(2k-3)}} \\)   (5) \\( \\displaystyle \\;\\;C_{{k+1}}\u003d{\\frac {C_{{k}}\\left(2k+4\\right)}{\\left(2k+7\\right)(k+1)}} \\)    \\( \\displaystyle 0 \\)   \\( \\displaystyle C_{{1}}\u003d{\\frac {C_{{0}}}{3}} \\)   \\( \\displaystyle C_{{1}}\u003d{\\frac {4}{7}}C_{{0}} \\)    \\( \\displaystyle 1 \\)   \\( \\displaystyle C_{{2}}\u003d{\\frac {-C_{{0}}}{6}} \\)   \\( \\displaystyle C_{{2}}\u003d{\\frac {4}{21}}C_{{0}} \\)    \\( \\displaystyle 2 \\)   \\( \\displaystyle C_{{3}}\u003d{\\frac {-C_{{0}}}{6}} \\)   \\( \\displaystyle C_{{3}}\u003d{\\frac {32}{693}}C_{{0}} \\) \n\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003cbr\u003e \n\u003cp\u003eAnd so on ... \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e For simplification purposes we let \\( \\displaystyle C_{0}\u003d1 \\) \u003cbr\u003e so we get the general solution to the differential equation on \\( (0,\\infty ) \\) \u0026nbsp;:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\displaystyle y(x)\u003dC_{{1}}\\left(1+{\\frac {1}{3}}x-{\\frac {1}{6}}x^{{2}}-{\\frac {1}{6}}x^{{3}}+\\ldots \\right)+C_{{2}}x^{{{\\frac {5}{2}}}}\\left(1+{\\frac {4}{7}}x+{\\frac {4}{21}}x^{{2}}+{\\frac {32}{693}}x^{{3}}+\\ldots \\right) \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( y\u0027\u0027-y\u003de^{{-t}},\\,\\,\\,y(0)\u003d1,y\u0027(0)\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\mathcal {L}}[y\u0027\u0027-y]\u003d{\\mathcal {L}}[e^{{-t}}]\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( Y\u003d{\\mathcal {L}}[y]\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\mathcal {L}}[y\u0027\u0027-y]\u003d{\\mathcal {L}}[y\u0027\u0027]-{\\mathcal {L}}[y]\u003ds^{2}Y-sf(0)-f\u0027(0)-Y\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003ds^{2}Y-s-Y\u003d{\\frac {1}{s+1}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt this point all the information from the IC\u0027s are encoded into the transform. Solve for \\( Y \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( Y\u003d{\\frac {s^{2}+s+1}{(s+1)(s^{2}-1)}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eFind the partial fraction decomposition of \\( {\\frac {s^{2}+s+1}{(s+1)(s^{2}-1)}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {s^{2}+s+1}{(s+1)(s^{2}-1)}}\u003d{\\frac {s^{2}+s+1}{(s+1)^{2}(s-1)}}\u003d{\\frac {A}{(s+1)^{2}}}+{\\frac {B}{s+1}}+{\\frac {C}{s-1}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMultiply both sides by the common denominator.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( s^{2}+s+1\u003dA(s-1)+B(s+1)(s-1)+C(s+1)^{2}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( s^{2}+s+1\u003ds^{2}(B+C)+s(A+2C)+(-A-B+C)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompare coefficients.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( B+C\u003d1,\\,\\,\\,A+2C\u003d1,\\,\\,\\,-A-B+C\u003d1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSolve this system of equations. The augmented matrix has equations as rows and variables as columns. The last column is the value of each equation.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\begin{bmatrix}A\u0026amp;B\u0026amp;C\u0026amp;{}\\\\0\u0026amp;1\u0026amp;1\u0026amp;1\\\\1\u0026amp;0\u0026amp;2\u0026amp;1\\\\-1\u0026amp;-1\u0026amp;1\u0026amp;1\\\\\\end{bmatrix}}\u003d{\\begin{bmatrix}A\u0026amp;B\u0026amp;C\u0026amp;{}\\\\1\u0026amp;0\u0026amp;2\u0026amp;1\\\\-1\u0026amp;-1\u0026amp;1\u0026amp;1\\\\0\u0026amp;1\u0026amp;1\u0026amp;1\\\\\\end{bmatrix}}\u003d{\\begin{bmatrix}A\u0026amp;B\u0026amp;C\u0026amp;{}\\\\1\u0026amp;0\u0026amp;2\u0026amp;1\\\\0\u0026amp;-1\u0026amp;3\u0026amp;2\\\\0\u0026amp;1\u0026amp;1\u0026amp;1\\\\\\end{bmatrix}}\u003d{\\begin{bmatrix}A\u0026amp;B\u0026amp;C\u0026amp;{}\\\\1\u0026amp;0\u0026amp;2\u0026amp;1\\\\0\u0026amp;-1\u0026amp;3\u0026amp;2\\\\0\u0026amp;0\u0026amp;4\u0026amp;3\\\\\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo \\( C\u003d3/4,\\,\\,\\,B\u003d1/4,\\,\\,\\,A\u003d-1/2\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {s^{2}+s+1}{(s+1)(s^{2}-1)}}\u003d{\\frac {-1/2}{(s+1)^{2}}}+{\\frac {1/4}{s+1}}+{\\frac {-1/2}{s-1}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e  \n\u003cp\u003eSo \\( Y\u003d{\\frac {-1/2}{(s+1)^{2}}}+{\\frac {1/4}{s+1}}+{\\frac {-1/2}{s-1}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUse the tables \u003ca href\u003d\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laplace_transform\" rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e to find the inverse Laplace transforms.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( y(t)\u003d{\\mathcal {L}}^{{-1}}[Y]\u003d{\\frac {-1}{2}}(te^{{-t}})+{\\frac {1}{4}}e^{{-t}}+{\\frac {3}{4}}e^{t}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eOrdinary Differential Equations\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the Laplace transform of \\( f(t)\u003d{\\begin{cases}1\u0026amp;0\u0026lt;t\\leq 1\\\\-1\u0026amp;1\u0026lt;t\\leq 2\\end{cases}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUse this property:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( L\\{g(t)\\}\u003d{\\frac {\\int _{0}^{P}e^{{-st}}g(t)\\,dt}{1-e^{{-Ps}}}}\\, \\) , with period P.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( L\\{f(t)\\}\u003d{\\frac {\\int _{0}^{2}e^{{-st}}f(t)\\,dt}{1-e^{{-2s}}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d{\\frac {\\int _{0}^{1}e^{{-st}}(1)\\,dt+\\int _{1}^{2}e^{{-st}}(-1)\\,dt}{1-e^{{-2s}}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d{\\frac {{\\frac {-e^{{-st}}}{s}}{\\bigg |}_{{t\u003d0}}^{1}+{\\frac {e^{{-st}}}{s}}{\\bigg |}_{{t\u003d1}}^{2}}{1-e^{{-2s}}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d{\\frac {{\\frac {1}{s}}(1-2e^{{-s}}+e^{{-2s}})}{1-e^{{-2s}}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d{\\frac {{\\frac {1}{s}}(1-e^{{-s}})^{2}}{(1+e^{{-s}})(1-e^{{-s}})}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d{\\frac {1}{s}}\\left({\\frac {1-e^{{-s}}}{1+e^{{-s}}}}\\right)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d{\\frac {1}{s}}\\left({\\frac {e^{{s/2}}-e^{{-s/2}}}{e^{{s/2}}+e^{{-s/2}}}}\\right)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d{\\frac {1}{s}}\\tanh {\\frac {s}{2}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eOrdinary Differential Equations\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eLet \\( X\\, \\) and \\( Y\\, \\) be \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003emetric spaces\u003c/a\u003e, and \\( f:X\\to Y\\, \\) be a \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003emapping\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e(i) Prove that if \\( f^{{-1}}(G)\\, \\) is \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eopen\u003c/a\u003e whenever \\( G\\subset Y\\, \\) is open, then \\( f\\, \\) is \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003econtinuous\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e(ii) Prove that \\( f\\, \\) is continuous \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eif and only if\u003c/a\u003e \\( f^{{-1}}(F)\\, \\) is \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eclosed\u003c/a\u003e whenever \\( F\\subset Y\\, \\) is closed. \u003c/p\u003e \n\u003cspan\u003e(i)\u003c/span\u003e \n\u003cp\u003e Suppose \\( f^{{-1}}(G)\\, \\) is open whenever \\( G\\subset Y\\, \\) is open. Let \\( x_{0}\\in X\\, \\) and \\( \\epsilon \u0026gt;0\\, \\) . Since the \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eball\u003c/a\u003e \\( B(f(x_{0}),\\epsilon )\\, \\) is open, so is \\( f^{{-1}}\\left[B(f(x_{0}),\\epsilon ))\\right]\\, \\) . Since \\( f(x_{0})\\in B(f(x_{0}),\\epsilon ),x_{0}\\in f^{{-1}}\\left[B(f(x_{0}),\\epsilon )\\right]\\, \\) . Since \\( f^{{-1}}\\left[B(f(x_{0}),\\epsilon )\\right] \\) is open there exists a \\( \\delta \u0026gt;0\\, \\) such that \\( B(x_{0},\\delta )\\subset f^{{-1}}\\left[B(f(x_{0}),\\epsilon )\\right]\\, \\) . This implies \\( f(B(x_{0},\\delta ))\\subset B(f(x_{0}),\\epsilon )\\, \\) making \\( f\\, \\) continuous at \\( x_{0}\\, \\) . Since \\( x_{0}\\, \\) was arbitrary, \\( f\\, \\) is continuous. \u003c/p\u003e \n\u003cspan\u003e(ii)\u003c/span\u003e \n\u003cp\u003eSuppose \\( f^{{-1}}(F)\\, \\) is closed whenever \\( F\\in Y\\, \\) is closed. Let \\( G\\subset Y\\, \\) be open. Then \\( G^{c}\\, \\) is closed. By the hypothesis, \\( f^{{-1}}(G^{c})\\, \\) is closed. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf \\( x\\in f^{{-1}}(G^{c})\\, \\) , then \\( f(x)\\in G^{c},f(x)\\notin G,x\\notin f^{{-1}}(G)\\, \\) and \\( x\\in \\left[f^{{-1}}(G)\\right]^{c}\\, \\) . Similarly, if \\( x\\in \\left[f^{{-1}}(G)\\right]^{c}\\, \\) then \\( x\\notin f^{{-1}}(G),f(x)\\notin G,f(x)\\in G^{c}\\, \\) , and \\( x\\in f^{{-1}}(G^{c})\\, \\) . Therefore \\( f^{{-1}}(G^{c})\u003d\\left[f^{{-1}}(G)\\right]^{c}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow, \\( f^{{-1}}(G^{c})\u003d\\left[f^{{-1}}(G)\\right]^{c}\\, \\) is closed, so \\( f^{{-1}}(G)\\, \\) is open. So \\( f^{{-1}}(G)\\, \\) is open whenever \\( G\\subset Y\\, \\) is open. From part (i), \\( f\\, \\) is continuous. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSuppose \\( f\\, \\) is continuous. Let \\( G\\subset Y\\, \\) be closed. Let \\( \\{x_{n}\\}\\subset f^{{-1}}(G)\\, \\) converge to \\( x\\in X\\, \\) . Since \\( f\\, \\) is continuous \\( \\{f(x_{n})\\}\\subset G\\, \\) converges to \\( f(x)\\in Y\\, \\) . Since \\( G\\, \\) is closed, \\( f(x)\\in G\\, \\) and so \\( x\\in f^{{-1}}(G)\\, \\) which means \\( f^{{-1}}(G)\\, \\) is closed (since this is the limit of the arbitrary sequence chosen above). Therefore \\( f^{{-1}}(G)\\, \\) is closed whenever \\( G\\, \\) is closed. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

Prove that \\( x(t)\\, \\) is \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003econtinuous\u003c/a\u003e when \\( x_{n}(t)\\, \\) is continuous for all \\( n\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSuppose \\( x_{n}(t)\\, \\) is continuous for all \\( t\\in [0,1]\\, \\) , and all \\( n\\, \\) .       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eShow that any \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eCauchy sequence\u003c/a\u003e in a \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003emetric space\u003c/a\u003e is always \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003ebounded\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e  Let \\( \\{x_{j}\\}_{{j\u003d1}}^{\\infty }\\, \\) be a Cauchy sequence in the metric space \\( (X,d)\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Since \\( \\{x_{j}\\}\\, \\) is Cauchy, there exists an \\( M\\, \\) such that \\( d(x_{{M+1}},x_{j})\u0026lt;1\\, \\) for all \\( j\u0026gt;M\\, \\) . For \\( 1\\leq j\\leq M\\, \\) , let \\( \\delta _{j}\u003dd(x_{{M+1}},x_{j})\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now choose \\( \\delta \u0026gt;\\max _{{j\\in (1,...,M)}}\\{1,\\delta _{j}\\}\\, \\) . Let \\( B\u003dB(x_{{M+1}},\\delta )\\subset X\\, \\) . Notice for \\( 1\\leq j\\leq M,d(x_{{M+1}},x_{j})\u003d\\delta _{j}\u0026lt;\\delta \\, \\) , so \\( x_{j}\\in B\\, \\) . For \\( j\u0026gt;M,d(x_{{M+1}},x_{j})\u0026lt;1\u0026lt;\\delta \\, \\) , so \\( x_{j}\\in B\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e We have \\( \\{x_{j}\\}\\subset B\\, \\) making \\( \\{x_{j}\\}\\, \\) bounded. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e In general, any Cauchy sequence in a metric space is bounded.  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eLet \\( x_{j},y_{j}\\in {\\mathbb {R}}\\, \\) for \\( j\u003d1,2,...,n\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e \n\u003cspan\u003e(i)\u003c/span\u003e \n\u003cp\u003eShow that \\( \\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}x_{j}y_{j}\\leq \\left(\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}x_{j}^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\left(\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}y_{j}^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( f(t)\\, \\) be a \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003equadratic function\u003c/a\u003e \\( f(t)\u003dt^{2}\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}x_{j}^{2}+2t\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}x_{j}y_{j}+\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}y_{j}^{2}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( f(t)\u003d\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}(t^{2}x_{j}^{2}+2tx_{j}y_{j}+y_{j}^{2})\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}(tx_{j}+y_{j})^{2}\\geq 0\\, \\) for \\( t,x_{j},y_{j}\\in {\\mathbb {R}}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSince the \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eparabola\u003c/a\u003e \\( f(t):{\\mathbb {R}}\\to {\\mathbb {R}}\\, \\) has at most one zero, its \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003ediscriminant\u003c/a\u003e is less than or equal to zero. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 4\\left(\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}x_{j}y_{j}\\right)^{2}-4\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}x_{j}^{2}\\cdot \\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}y_{j}^{2}\\leq 0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e And therefore \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}x_{j}y_{j}\\leq |\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}x_{j}y_{j}|\\leq \\left(\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}x_{j}^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\left(\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}y_{j}^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e \n\u003cspan\u003e(ii)\u003c/span\u003e \n\u003cp\u003eUse (i) to prove that \\( \\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|x_{j}y_{j}|\\leq \\left(\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|x_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\left(\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|y_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the result (i), replace \\( x_{j} \\) by \\( |x_{j}| \\) and \\( y_{j} \\) by \\( |y_{j}| \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|x_{j}y_{j}|\u003d\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|x_{j}||y_{j}|\\leq \\left(\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|x_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\left(\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|y_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|x_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}+\\left(\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|y_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNotice \\( \\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|x_{j}+y_{j}|^{2}\\leq \\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}\\left(|x_{j}|+|y_{j}|\\right)^{2}\\, \\) by the \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003etriangle inequality\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|x_{j}|^{2}+2\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|x_{j}y_{j}|+\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|y_{j}|^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\leq \\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|x_{j}|^{2}+2\\left(\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|x_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\left(\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|y_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}+\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|y_{j}|^{2}\\, \\) from (ii). \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d\\left[\\left(\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|x_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}+\\left(\\sum _{{j\u003d1}}^{n}|y_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\right]^{2}\\, \\)       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eUse the inequality \\( \\alpha \\beta \\leq {\\frac {\\alpha ^{p}}{p}}+{\\frac {\\beta ^{q}}{q}}\\, \\) for \\( \\alpha ,\\beta \\geq 0,{\\frac {1}{p}}+{\\frac {1}{q}}\u003d1\\, \\) to prove that \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int _{a}^{b}\\left|f(t)g(t)\\right|dt\\leq \\left(\\int _{a}^{b}\\left|f(t)\\right|^{p}\\right)^{{1/p}}\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}\\left|g(t)\\right|^{q}\\right)^{{1/q}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e for \\( p\u0026gt;1\\, \\) and \\( {\\frac {1}{p}}+{\\frac {1}{q}}\u003d1\\, \\) , and then use this to prove the triangular inequality: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\left(\\int _{a}^{b}\\left|f(t)+g(t)\\right|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}\\leq \\left(\\int _{a}^{b}\\left|f(t)\\right|^{p}\\right)^{{1/p}}+\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}\\left|g(t)\\right|^{p}\\right)^{{1/p}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e \n\u003cspan\u003eFirst Part\u003c/span\u003e \n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( {\\hat {f}}\\, \\) and \\( {\\hat {g}}\\, \\) be such that \\( \\int _{a}^{b}|{\\hat {f}}|^{p}dt\u003d\\int _{a}^{b}|{\\hat {g}}|dt\u003d1\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let \\( \\alpha \u003d|{\\hat {f}}|\\, \\) and \\( \\beta \u003d|{\\hat {g}}|\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Using the inequality, \\( |{\\hat {f}}{\\hat {g}}|\\leq |{\\hat {f}}||{\\hat {g}}|\\leq {\\frac {|{\\hat {f}}|^{p}}{p}}+{\\frac {|{\\hat {g}}|^{q}}{q}}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow integrate from \\( a\\, \\) to \\( b\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int _{a}^{b}|{\\hat {f}}{\\hat {g}}|dt\\leq \\int _{a}^{b}{\\frac {|{\\hat {f}}|^{p}}{p}}dt+\\int _{a}^{b}{\\frac {|{\\hat {g}}|^{q}}{q}}dt\u003d{\\frac {1}{p}}+{\\frac {1}{q}}\u003d1\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSet \\( {\\hat {f}}\u003d{\\frac {f}{\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|f|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}}}\\, \\) and \\( {\\hat {g}}\u003d{\\frac {g}{\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|g|^{q}dt\\right)^{{1/q}}}}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePlug these into the previous equation and multiply by the denominator: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int _{a}^{b}|fg|dt\\leq \\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|f|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|g|^{q}dt\\right)^{{1/q}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e \n\u003cspan\u003eSecond Part\u003c/span\u003e \n\u003cp\u003e \\( |f+g|^{p}\u003d|f+g||f+g|^{{p-1}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\leq (|f|+|g|)|f+g|^{{p-1}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( |f||f+g|^{{p-1}}+|g||f+g|^{{p-1}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int _{a}^{b}|f+g|^{p}dt\\leq \\int _{a}^{b}|f||f+g|^{{p+1}}dt+\\int _{a}^{b}|g||f+g|^{{(p-1)q}}dt\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFrom the first part, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int _{a}^{b}|f||f+g|^{{p-1}}dt\\leq \\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|f|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|f+g|^{{(p-1)q}}\\right)^{{1/q}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int _{a}^{b}|g||f+g|^{{p-1}}dt\\leq \\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|g|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|f+g|^{{(p-1)q}}\\right)^{{1/q}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\frac {1}{p}}+{\\frac {1}{q}}\u003d1\\implies q+p\u003dpq\\implies (p-1)q\u003dp\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Adding these two integrals, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\int _{a}^{b}|f+g|^{p}dt\\leq \\left[\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|f|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}+\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|g|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}\\right]\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|f+g|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/q}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Multiply both sides by the inverse of the last term and use \\( 1-{\\frac {1}{q}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{p}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( \\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|f+g|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}\\leq \\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|f|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}+\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|g|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",
      "uuid": "53d76607-cc30-4bbc-a968-6b419f57545b",

Prove that \\( M\\, \\) is compact in \\( (X,||\\cdot ||_{1})\\, \\) if and only if \\( M\\, \\) is compact in \\( (X,||\\cdot ||_{2})\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSince \\( M\\, \\) is compact in \\( (X,||\\cdot ||_{1})\\, \\) , every sequence \\( \\{x_{n}\\}\\, \\) in \\( M\\, \\) has a convergent subsequence \\( \\{x_{{n_{k}}}\\}\\, \\) that converges to \\( x\\in M\\, \\) .       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eShow that the four points in the Argand plane represented by the complex numbers are the vertices of a square \\( 2+i,4+3i,2+5i,3i\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFrom the given complex numbers,we can derive the points in the plane as \\( (2,1)(4,3)(2,5)(0,3)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let the points represent the four sides of a squate respectively \\( A,B,C,D\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now writing the line equation \\( AB\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\bar {AB}}\u003d(y-1)\u003d({\\frac {3-1}{4-2}})(x-2)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\bar {AB}}\u003d(y-1)\u003d(x-2)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Simplifying further we get \\( {\\bar {AB}}\u003dx-y-1\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now writing the line equation \\( BC\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\bar {BC}}\u003d(y-3)\u003d({\\frac {5-3}{2-4}})(x-4)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\bar {BC}}\u003d(y-3)\u003d(4-x)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\bar {BC}}\u003dx+y-7\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now writing the line equation \\( CD\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\bar {CD}}\u003d(y-5)\u003d({\\frac {3-5}{0-2}})(x-2)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\bar {CD}}\u003d(y-5)\u003d(x-2)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\bar {CD}}\u003d-x+y-3\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Now writing the line equation \\( DA\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\bar {DA}}\u003d(y-3)\u003d({\\frac {1-3}{2-0}})(x-0)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\bar {DA}}\u003d(y-3)\u003d(-1)(x)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( {\\bar {DA}}\u003dx+y-3)\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The slope of \\( {\\bar {AB}}\u003d1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The slope of \\( {\\bar {BC}}\u003d-1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The slope of \\( {\\bar {CD}}\u003d1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The slope of \\( {\\bar {DA}}\u003d-1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e From these slopes,the slopes of opposite sides are equal,which means they are parallel to each other and product of the one to the next is -1,which means they are perpendicular. The lenth of \\( AB\u003d{\\sqrt {(2-4)^{2}+(1-3)^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( AB\u003d{\\sqrt {8}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The lenth of \\( BC\u003d{\\sqrt {(4-2)^{2}+(3-5)^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( BC\u003d{\\sqrt {8}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The lenth of \\( CD\u003d{\\sqrt {(2-0)^{2}+(5-3)^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( CD\u003d{\\sqrt {8}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The lenth of \\( DA\u003d{\\sqrt {(2-0)^{2}+(1-3)^{2}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( DA\u003d{\\sqrt {8}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e From the above all the sides are equal. Hence all these conditions prove that the numbers form the vertices of a square. \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eEvaluate \\( {\\mathrm {Re}}\\left[(a+bi)^{p}\\right]\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e \n\u003cspan\u003ewith complex variables\u003c/span\u003e \n\u003cp\u003eWrite \\( (a+bi)^{p}\u003de^{{\\tan ^{{-1}}p{\\frac {b}{a}}}}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow \\( {\\mathrm {Re}}\\left[e^{{\\tan ^{{-1}}p{\\frac _{{j\u003d0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac {(-1)^{j}}{j!}}(-p)_{j}a^{j}b^{{p-j}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\mathrm       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the Laurent series for \\( {\\frac {1}{z^{2}(z-1)}}\\, \\) about all its singular points. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe singularities are \\( z\u003d0,1\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCentered at the singular point \\( z_{0}\u003d0\\, \\) there are two possible Laurent series. One valid for \\( 0\u0026lt;|z|\u0026lt;1\\, \\) and one for \\( |z|\u0026gt;1\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the domain \\( 0\u0026lt;|z|\u0026lt;1\\, \\) , \\( {\\frac {1}{z^{2}(z-1)}}\u003d-{\\frac {1}{z^{2}}}\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{\\infty }z^{n}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d-\\sum _{{n\u003d0}}^{\\infty }z^{{n-2}}\u003d-\\sum       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the residues of \\( f(z)\\, \\) at all its isolated singular points and at infinity (if infinity is not a limit point of singular points), where \\( f(z)\\, \\) is given by \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {z^{{2n}}}{(1+z)^{n}}},n\\in {\\mathbb {Z^{+}}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis has a pole at \\( z\u003d-1\\, \\) of multiplicity \\( k\u003dn\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUse the formula \\( {\\mathrm {Res}}_{{z\u003dz_{0}}}f(z)\u003d{\\frac {1}{(k-1)!}}\\lim _{{z\\to z_{0}}}{\\frac {d^{{k-1}}}{{dz}^{{k-1}}}}\\left[(z-z_{0})^{k}f(z)\\right]\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\mathrm {Res}}_{{z\u003d-1}}f(z)\u003d{\\frac {1}{(n-1)!}}\\lim _{{z\\to -1}}{\\frac {d^{{n-1}}}{{dz}^{{n-1}}}}(z+1)^{n}f(z)\u003d{\\frac {1}{(n-1)!}}\\lim _{{z\\to -1}}{\\frac {d^{{n-1}}}{{dz}^{{n-1}}}}z^{{2n}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe derivative can be computed like this: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {d^{{n-1}}}{{dz}^{{n-1}}}}z^{{2n}}\u003d(2n)(2n-1)(2n-2)\\cdot \\cdot \\cdot (2n-n)z^{{2n-(n-1)}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003emultiplicand numerador and denominador for \\( (n-1)!\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d{\\frac {(2n)!}{(n-1)!}}z^{{n+1}}\u003d{\\frac {(2n)!}{(n-1)!}}z^{{n+1}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\mathrm {Res}}_{{z\u003d-1}}f(z)\u003d{\\frac {1}{(n-1)!}}\\lim _{{z\\to -1}}{\\frac {(2n)!}{(n-1)!}}z^{{n+1}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d{\\frac {(2n)!}{[(n-1)!]^{2}}}\\lim _{{z\\to -1}}z^{{n+1}}\u003d{\\frac {(2n)!}{[(n-1)!]^{2}}}\\cos(n+1)\\pi \\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf \\( f(z)\\, \\) is analytic except at isolated singular points, then the sum of all the residues of \\( f(z)\\, \\) equals 0. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore \\( {\\mathrm {Res}}_{{z\u003d\\infty       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eFind the residues of \\( f(z)\\, \\) at all its isolated singular points and at infinity (if infinity is not a limit point of singular points), where \\( f(z)\\, \\) is given by \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( f(z)\u003d{\\frac {e^{z}}{z^{2}(z^{2}+9)}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis has poles at \\( z\u003d0\\, \\) of multiplicity \\( k\u003d2\\, \\) and at \\( z\u003d\\pm 3i\\, \\) of multiplicity \\( k\u003d1\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor the simple roots, the residue is the numerator divided by the first derivative of the denominator when both are evaluated at the root. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\mathrm {Res}}_{{z\u003d-3i}}f(z)\u003d{\\frac {e^{z}}{4z^{3}+18z}}{\\Big |}_{{z\u003d-3i}}\u003d{\\frac {e^{{-3i}}}{4(27i)+18(-3i)}}\u003d{\\frac {e^{{-3i}}}{54i}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\mathrm {Res}}_{{z\u003d3i}}f(z)\u003d{\\frac {e^{z}}{4z^{3}+18z}}{\\Big |}_{{z\u003d3i}}\u003d{\\frac {e^{{3i}}}{4(27(-i))+18(3i)}}\u003d{\\frac {-e^{{3i}}}{54i}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor 0, use the formula \\( {\\mathrm {Res}}_{{z\u003dz_{0}}}f(z)\u003d{\\frac {1}{(k-1)!}}\\lim _{{z\\to z_{0}}}{\\frac {d^{{k-1}}}{{dz}^{{k-1}}}}\\left[(z-z_{0})^{k}f(z)\\right]\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\mathrm {Res}}_{{z\u003d0}}\u003d\\lim _{{z\\to 0}}{\\frac {d}{dz}}z^{2}f(z)\u003d\\lim _{{z\\to 0}}{\\frac {d}{dz}}{\\frac {e^{z}}{z^{2}+9}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d\\lim _{{z\\to 0}}{\\frac {(z^{2}+9)e^{z}-e^{z}2z}{(z^{2}+9)^{2}}}\u003d{\\frac {9}{9^{2}}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{9}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf \\( f(z)\\, \\) is analytic except at isolated singular points,       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eEvaluate \\( I\u003d\\int _{0}^{{2\\pi }}{\\frac {\\sin ^{2}\\theta }{5+4\\cos \\theta }}\\,d\\theta \\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMake the change of variables so the integral will be around the unit circle. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {1}{z}}\u003de^{{-i\\theta }},\\cos \\theta \u003d{\\frac {e^{{i\\theta }}+e^{{-i\\theta }}}{2}},\\sin \\theta \u003d{\\frac {e^{{i\\theta }}-e^{{-i\\theta }}}{2i}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( dz\u003die^{{i\\theta }},d\\theta \u003d{\\frac {dz}{iz}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\cos \\theta \u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}\\left(z+{\\frac {1}{z}}\\right),\\sin \\theta \u003d{\\frac {1}{2i}}\\left(z-{\\frac {1}{z}}\\right)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( I\u003d\\int _{{|C|\u003d1}}{\\frac {\\left[{\\frac {1}{2i}}\\left(z-{\\frac {1}{z}}\\right)\\right]^{2}}{5+4\\left[{\\frac {1}{2}}\\left(z+{\\frac {1}{z}}\\right)\\right]}}{\\frac {dz}{iz}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003d{\\frac {-1}{4i}}\\int _{C}{\\frac {z^{4}-2z^{2}+1}{z^{2}(2z^{2}+5z+2)}}dz\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis integrand has poles \\( z\u003d0^{2},-2,{\\frac {-1}{2}}\\, \\) , but only \\( 0\\, \\) and \\( {\\frac {-1}{2}}\\, \\) are inside the unit circle. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( I\u003d{\\frac {-1}{4i}}2\\pi i\\left({\\mathrm {Res}}_{{z\u003d0}}+{\\mathrm {Res}}_{{z\u003d{\\frac {-1}{2}}}}\\right)\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\mathrm {Res}}_{{z\u003d0}}\u003d\\lim _{{z\\to 0}}{\\frac {d}{dz}}{\\frac {z^{4}-2z^{2}+1}{2z^{2}+5z+2}}\u003d...\u003d{\\frac {-5}{4}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\mathrm {Res}}_{{z\u003d{\\frac {-1}{2}}}}\u003d{\\frac {z^{4}-2z^{2}+1}{8z^{3}+15z^{2}+4z}}{\\Big |}_{{z\u003d{\\frac {-1}{2}}}}\u003d{\\frac {3}{4}}\\, \\)       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eEvaluate \\( \\int _{0}^{\\infty }{\\frac {dx}{x^{3}+1}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Consider the following four curves where \\( R\u0026gt;\\epsilon \u0026gt;0 \\) : \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\gamma _{1}:[0,R]\\to {\\mathbb {C}} \\) where \\( \\gamma _{1}(t)\u003dt \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\gamma _{2}:[0,{\\frac {2\\pi }{3}}]\\to {\\mathbb {C}} \\) where \\( \\gamma _{2}(t)\u003dRe^{{it}} \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eand \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\gamma _{3}:[0,R]\\to {\\mathbb {C}} \\) where \\( \\gamma _{3}(t)\u003dte^{{{\\frac {2\\pi i}{3}}}} \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe want to integrate \\( {\\frac {1}{z^{3}+1}} \\) over the closed contour \\( C\u003d\\gamma _{1}+\\gamma _{2}-\\gamma _{3} \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy the residue theorem we know that \u003c/p\u003e \n\u003cpre\u003e \\( \\int _{C}{\\frac  {dz}{z^{3}+1}}\u003d2\\pi \\;res_{{z\u003de^{{{\\frac  {\\pi i}{3}}}}}}\\left({\\frac  {1}{z^{3}+1}}\\right) \\) \n\u003c/pre\u003e \n\u003cp\u003eA very useful lemma is if \\( f\\,g \\) are holomorphic functions defined on an open set that contains the point \\( z_{0} \\) , and \\( z_{0} \\) is a simple zero of \\( g \\) then \\( res_{{z\u003dz_{0}}}{\\frac {f}{g}}\u003d{\\frac {f(z_{0})}{g^{\\prime }(z_{0})}} \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo we have \\( \\int _{C}{\\frac {dz}{z^{3}+1}}\u003d2\\pi i{\\frac {1}{3{\\left(e^{{{\\frac {\\pi i}{3}}}}\\right)}^{2}+0}}\u003d{\\frac {2\\pi i}{3}}e^{{-{\\frac {2\\pi i}{3}}}} \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow we integrate over each part of the contour, and then take the limit as \\( R \\) goes to infinity. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int _{{\\gamma _{1}}}{\\frac {dz}{z^{3}+1}}\u003d\\int _{0}^{R}{\\frac {dt}{t^{3}+1}} \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe \\( p \\) -test from single variable calculus tells us that this integral converges as \\( R \\) goes to infinity. Therefore we simply have \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\lim _{{R\\to \\infty }}\\int _{{\\gamma _{1}}}{\\frac {dz}{z^{3}+1}}\u003d\\int _{0}^{\\infty }{\\frac {dt}{t^{3}+1}} \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNext we see that \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\left|\\int _{{\\gamma _{2}}}{\\frac {dz}{z^{3}+1}}\\right|\u003d\\left|\\int _{0}^{{{\\frac {2\\pi }{3}}}}{\\frac {Rie^{{it}}dt}{{\\left(Re^{{it}}\\right)}^{3}+1}}\\right|\\leq \\int _{0}^{{{\\frac {2\\pi }{3}}}}\\left|{\\frac {Rie^{{it}}}{R^{3}e^{{3it}}+1}}\\right|dt \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor all \\( R \\) large enough we have \\( R^{3}-1\u0026gt;{\\frac {1}{2}}R^{3} \\) . Then getting back to out integral we have \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\left|\\int _{{\\gamma _{2}}}{\\frac {dz}{z^{3}+1}}\\right|\\leq \\int _{0}^{{{\\frac {2\\pi }{3}}}}{\\frac {|Ri||e^{{it}}|dt}{|R^{3}e^{{3it}}+1|}}\u0026lt;\\int _{0}^{{{\\frac {2\\pi }{3}}}}{\\frac {Rdt}{{\\frac {1}{2}}R^{3}}}\u003d{\\frac {2}{R^{2}}}\\int _{0}^{{{\\frac {2\\pi }{3}}}}dt\u003d{\\frac {4\\pi }{3R^{2}}} \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTaking the limit as both as \\( R \\) tend to infinity \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\lim _{{R\\to \\infty }}\\left|\\int _{{\\gamma _{2}}}{\\frac {dz}{z^{3}+1}}\\right|\\leq 0\\Rightarrow \\lim _{{R\\to \\infty }}\\int _{{\\gamma _{2}}}{\\frac {dz}{z^{3}+1}}\u003d0 \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow we have just one more curve to integrate. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\int _{{\\gamma _{3}}}{\\frac {dz}{z^{3}+1}}\u003d\\int _{0}^{R}{\\frac {e^{{{\\frac {2}{3}}\\pi i}}\\ dt}{t^{3}+1}} \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAgain taking the limit as \\( R \\) goes to infinity we get \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\lim _{{R\\to \\infty }}\\int _{{\\gamma _{3}}}{\\frac       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eProve that there are infinitely many primes. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let \\( q\u003d2\\cdot 3\\cdot 5\\cdot \\cdot \\cdot p+1 \\) where \\( p \\) is a prime. Then \\( q \\) is not divisible by any prime less than or equal to \\( p \\) . Now either \\( q \\) is prime or it is divisible by primes greater than \\( p \\) and less than \\( q \\) . In either case there is a prime greater than \\( p \\) , which proves the theorem. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e -Euclid \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eProve that there are infinitely many primes of the form \\( p\u003d6k-1\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSuppose on the contrary that there are just a finite number of these primes, say \u003ci\u003ep\u003c/i\u003e\u003csub\u003e1\u003c/sub\u003e, ..., \u003ci\u003ep\u003c/i\u003e\u003csub\u003e\u003ci\u003en\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/sub\u003e. Let \u003ci\u003ea\u003c/i\u003e \u003d \u003ci\u003ep\u003c/i\u003e\u003csub\u003e1\u003c/sub\u003e...\u003ci\u003ep\u003c/i\u003e\u003csub\u003e\u003ci\u003en\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/sub\u003e. Obviously, \u003ci\u003ea\u003c/i\u003e \u003d (?1)\u003csup\u003e\u003ci\u003en\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e modulo 6. If \u003ci\u003en\u003c/i\u003e is even, let \u003ci\u003eb\u003c/i\u003e \u003d \u003ci\u003ea\u003c/i\u003e + 4 and otherwise let \u003ci\u003eb\u003c/i\u003e \u003d \u003ci\u003ea\u003c/i\u003e + 6. Then \u003ci\u003eb\u003c/i\u003e \u003d 5 modulo 6 \u003d ?1 modulo 6. Moreover, any prime number \u003ci\u003eq\u003c/i\u003e dividing both \u003ci\u003ea\u003c/i\u003e and \u003ci\u003eb\u003c/i\u003e will also divide either 4 or 6, hence such a \u003ci\u003eq\u003c/i\u003e will equal 2 or 3. In particular, none of the \u003ci\u003ep\u003c/i\u003e\u003csub\u003e\u003ci\u003ej\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/sub\u003e will divide \u003ci\u003eb\u003c/i\u003e. Now write \u003ci\u003eb\u003c/i\u003e as a product of prime numbers. Since \u003ci\u003eb\u003c/i\u003e is odd, every prime factor \u003ci\u003eq\u003c/i\u003e of \u003ci\u003eb\u003c/i\u003e can be written as \u003ci\u003eq\u003c/i\u003e \u003d 6\u003ci\u003er\u003c/i\u003e + 1, \u003ci\u003eq\u003c/i\u003e \u003d 6\u003ci\u003er\u003c/i\u003e + 3 or \u003ci\u003eq\u003c/i\u003e \u003d 6\u003ci\u003er\u003c/i\u003e + 5. However, the last type (which is ?1 modulo 6) is already ruled out, since none of the \u003ci\u003ep\u003c/i\u003e\u003csub\u003e\u003ci\u003ej\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/sub\u003e divides \u003ci\u003eb\u003c/i\u003e. The second type only permits \u003ci\u003eq\u003c/i\u003e \u003d 3. Therefore \u003ci\u003eb\u003c/i\u003e, being the product of all its prime factors, is either 1 or 3 modulo 6 (since 3\u003csup\u003e\u003ci\u003em\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e \u003d 3 modulo 6), a contradiction which completes the proof. \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( u_{t}+uu_{x}\u003d0,u(x,0)\u003d{\\begin{cases}1,\u0026amp;x\\leq 0\\\\1-x,\u0026amp;0\u0026lt;x\\leq 1\\\\0,\u0026amp;x\u0026gt;1\\end{cases}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDefine \\( G(u)\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}u^{2}\\, \\) so \\( u_{t}+[G(u)]_{x}\u003d0\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe characteristic line is \\( x\u003dut+x_{0}\\, \\) (See \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003ePDEMOC14\u003c/a\u003e). \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut in the middle region \\( u\u003du(x_{0},0)\u003d1-x_{0}\\, \\) because the characteristics determine that \\( u\\, \\) is constant with respect to \\( t\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow \\( u\u003d1-x_{0}\\, \\) and \\( x\u003dut+x_{0}\\, \\) imply \\( u\u003d{\\frac {x-1}{t-1}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow we have the solution \\( u(x,t)\u003d{\\begin{cases}1,\u0026amp;x\\leq 0\\\\{\\frac {x-1}{t-1}},\u0026amp;0\u0026lt;x\\leq 1\\\\0,\u0026amp;x\u0026gt;1\\end{cases}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe shock is at \\( (1,1)\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere \\( u_{r}\\, \\) refers to the right limit for \\( x\\, \\) which is 0 and \\( u_{l}\\, \\) is the left limit which is 1. The shock line will determine where these regions meet and the constant solutions on either side of this line is the weak solution. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFind the shock condition \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\xi \u0027(t)\u003d{\\frac {G(u_{r})-G(u_{l})}{u_{r}-u_{l}}}\u003d{\\frac {{\\frac {-1}{2}}}{-1}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\xi (t)\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}t+c_{1}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePlug in the shock point found earlier and let \\( x\u003d\\xi \\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 1\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}+c_{1}\\implies c_{1}\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo now \\( \\xi (t)\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}t+{\\frac {1}{2}}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe weak solution is \\( u(x,t)\u003d{\\begin{cases}1,\u0026amp;x\\leq \\xi (t)\\\\0,\u0026amp;x\u0026gt;\\xi (t)\\end{cases}}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eSolve the \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003einitial value problem\u003c/a\u003e \\( a(u)u_{x}+u_{y}\u003d0\\, \\) with \\( u(x,0)\u003dh(x)\\, \\) and show the solution becomes singular for some \\( y\u0026gt;0\\, \\) unless \\( a(h(s))\\, \\) is a \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003enondecreasing function\u003c/a\u003e of \\( s\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The solution is \\( u(x,y)\u003dh(x-a(u)y)\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSuppose \\( x\u003ds\\, \\) at \\( y\u003d0\\, \\) so that \\( u(s,0)\u003dh(s)\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet \\( u\u003du_{x}\\, \\) along a \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003echaracteristic\u003c/a\u003e line \\( \\Gamma _{\\xi }\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {du}{dy}}\u003d{\\frac {\\partial u_{x}}{\\partial x}}x\u0027(y)+{\\frac {\\partial u_{x}}{\\partial y}}\u003du_{{xx}}a(u)+u_{{xy}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFrom the equation \\( u_{y}+a(u)u_{x}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ewe get \\( u_{{xy}}+a(u)u_{{xx}}+a\u0027(u)u_{x}u_{x}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\implies {\\frac {dw}{dt}}\u003d-a\u0027(u)u_{x}^{2}\u003d-a\u0027(h(s))w^{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTherefore, \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( w(y)\u003d{\\frac {h\u0027(s)}{1+a\u0027(h(s))h\u0027(s)y}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThus, \\( u_{x}\\, \\) becomes \\( \\infty \\, \\) on the characteristic line for some \\( y\u0026gt;0\\, \\) unless \\( a\u0027(h(s))h\u0027(s)y\\geq 0\\, \\) which is equivalent to saying that \\( a(h(s))\\, \\) is a non-decreasing function of \\( s\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eConsider \\( uu_{x}+u_{y}\u003d0\\, \\) with the IC \\( u(x,0)\u003dh(x)\u003d{\\begin{cases}u_{0}\u0026gt;0,\u0026amp;x\\leq 0\\\\u_{0}(1-x),\u0026amp;0\u0026lt;x\u0026lt;1\\\\0,\u0026amp;x\\geq 1\\end{cases}}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eShow that a shock develops at a finite time and describe the weak solution. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe chracteristic line is \\( x\u003duy+x_{0}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo see this, note that the characteristics are \\( {\\frac {dx}{dy}}\u003du\\, \\) so \\( x(y)\u003duy+c_{1},x(0)\u003dc_{1}\u003dx_{0}\\, \\) and \\( x\u003duy+x_{0}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExamine the middle of the region. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor \\( 0\u0026lt;x_{0}\u0026lt;1\\, \\) , \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u\u003du_{0}(1-x_{0})\u003du_{0}(1-x+uy)\\implies u\u003d{\\frac {u_{0}(1-x)}{1-u_{0}y}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow we know \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u(x,y)\u003d{\\begin{cases}u_{0}\u0026gt;0,\u0026amp;x\\leq 0\\\\{\\frac {u_{0}(1-x)}{1-u_{0}y}},\u0026amp;0\u0026lt;x\u0026lt;1\\\\0,\u0026amp;x\\geq 1\\end{cases}}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo \\( y\u003d{\\frac {1}{u_{0}}}\\, \\) is the shock and the characteristics intersect at \\( (1,{\\frac {1}{u_{0}}})\\, \\) . Next we\u0027d like to define \\( G(u)\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}u^{2}\\, \\) (in this case) so that the pde is in the form \\( [G(u)]_{x}+u_{y}\u003d0\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe jump condition taken from the far left side to the far right side is: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\xi \u0027(y)\u003d{\\frac {G(u_{r})-G(u_{l})}{u_{r}-u_{l}}}\u003d{\\frac {u_{0}}{2}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\xi (y)\u003d{\\frac {u_{0}}{2}}y+c_{2}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePlug in the shock \\( (1,{\\frac {1}{u_{0}}})\\, \\) to get \\( 1\u003d\\xi (y)\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}+c_{2}\\implies c_{2}\u003d{\\frac {1}{2}}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, \\( \\xi (y)\u003d{\\frac {u_{0}}{2}}y+{\\frac {1}{2}}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe weak solution is \\( u(x,y)\u003d{\\begin{cases}u_{0},\u0026amp;x\u0026lt;{\\frac {u_{0}}{2}}y+{\\frac {1}{2}}\\\\0,\u0026amp;x\u0026gt;{\\frac {u_{0}}{2}}y+{\\frac {1}{2}}\\end{cases}}\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003eConsider \\( uu_{x}+u_{t}\u003d0\\, \\) with the IC \\( u(x,0)\u003dh(x)\u003d{\\begin{cases}0,\u0026amp;x\u0026lt;0\\\\u_{0}(x-1),\u0026amp;x\u0026gt;0\\end{cases}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFind the weak solution. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen \\( y\u003d0\\, \\) , if \\( x\u0026gt;0\\, \\) then \\( u\u003du_{0}(x-1)\\, \\) but the characteristic line (see \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003ePDEMOC14\u003c/a\u003e) is \\( x\u003dut+x_{0}\\, \\) . f(x-y,y+\\ln(1-u))\u003d0\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis can be equivalently written using another arbitrary function \\( g\\, \\) . \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo now \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u(x,y)\u003d1-e^{{\\ln(1-\\sin {\\sqrt {y-x}})+y-x+{\\sqrt {y-x}}-y}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e The final       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( 3u_{x}+4u_{y}-2u\u003d1,u(x,0)\u003de^{x}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIntroduce the change of coordinates\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( \\xi \u003dAx+By\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e \\( \\eta \u003dCx+Dy\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo \\( u\\, \\) is now a function of \\( (\\xi ,\\eta )\\, \\) . Recompute the derivatives with respect to these new coordinates.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {\\partial u}{\\partial x}}\u003d{\\frac {\\partial u}{\\partial \\xi }}{\\frac {\\partial \\xi }{\\partial x}}+{\\frac {\\partial u}{\\partial \\eta }}{\\frac {\\partial \\eta }{\\partial x}}\u003dAu_{\\xi }\\ +Cu_{\\eta }\\, \\) ,\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {\\partial u}{\\partial y}}\u003d{\\frac {\\partial u}{\\partial \\xi }}{\\frac {\\partial \\xi }{\\partial y}}+{\\frac {\\partial u}{\\partial \\eta }}{\\frac {\\partial \\eta }{\\partial y}}\u003dBu_{\\xi }+Du_{\\eta }\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePlug these derivatives into the original equation.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( 3(Au_{\\xi }+Cu_{\\eta })+4(Bu_{\\xi }+Du_{\\eta })-2u\u003d1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u_{\\xi }(3A+4B)+u_{\\eta }(3C+4D)-2u\u003d1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChoose any values of \\( A,B,C,D \\) to make the problem easy to solve, with the caveat that \\( AD-BC\\neq 0 \\) . For example, let \\( C\u003d1,D\u003d-3/4 \\) so that the \\( u_{\\eta } \\) term goes away. Then let \\( A\u003d1/3,B\u003d0 \\) so that the \\( u_{\\xi } \\) coefficient equals unity. Then,\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u_{\\xi }-2u\u003d1\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUse the \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003eintegrating factor\u003c/a\u003e \\( e^{{\\int -2d\\xi }}\u003de^{{-2\\xi }}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( e^{{-2\\xi }}u_{\\xi }-e^{{-2\\xi }}2u\u003de^{{-2\\xi }}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {\\partial }{\\partial \\xi }}\\left[e^{{-2\\xi }}u\\right]\u003de^{{-2\\xi }}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( e^{{-2\\xi }}u\u003d{\\frac {-1}{2}}e^{{-2\\xi }}+f(\\eta )\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere \\( f(\\eta )\\, \\) is an undetermined function of \\( \\eta \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u(\\xi ,\\eta )\u003d{\\frac {-1}{2}}+e^{{2\\xi }}f(\\eta )\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u(x,y)\u003d{\\frac {-1}{2}}+e^{{{\\frac {2}{3}}x}}f(x-{\\frac {3}{4}}y)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow we determine the unique solution that corresponds to the \u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003einital condition\u003c/a\u003e \\( u(x,0)\u003de^{x}\\, \\) . Using the general solution above, set \\( y\u003d0 \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u(x,0)\u003d{\\frac {-1}{2}}+e^{{{\\frac {2}{3}}x}}f(x)\u003de^{x}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( f(x)\u003d{\\frac {e^{x}+{\\frac {1}{2}}}{e^{{{\\frac {2}{3}}x}}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut in the general solution, we have \\( f(x-{\\frac {3}{4}}y) \\) instead of \\( f(x)\\, \\) . So making the appropriate substitutions, \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( f(x-{\\frac {3}{4}}y)\u003d{\\frac {e^{{x-{\\frac {3}{4}}y}}+{\\frac {1}{2}}}{e^{{{\\frac {2}{3}}(x-{\\frac {3}{4}}y)}}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePlug this function into the general solution.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u(x,y)\u003d{\\frac {-1}{2}}+e^{{x-{\\frac {1}{4}}y}}+{\\frac {1}{2}}e^{{{\\frac {1}{2}}y}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",

      "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( z_{{xy}}\u003dx^{2}y,\\,\\,z(x,0)\u003dx^{2},\\,z(1,y)\u003d\\cos(y)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWrite \\( {\\frac {\\partial ^{2}z}{\\partial x\\partial y}}\u003dx^{2}y\\, \\) as\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {\\partial }{\\partial x}}\\left({\\frac {\\partial z}{\\partial y}}\\right)\u003dx^{2}y\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIntegrate wrt the partial \\( x \\) to get:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {\\partial z}{\\partial y}}\u003d{\\frac {1}{3}}x^{3}y+f(y)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIntegrate wrt the partial \\( y \\) to get:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( z(x,y)\u003d{\\frac {1}{6}}x^{3}y^{2}+F(y)+g(x)\\, \\) where \\( {\\frac {\\partial F}{\\partial y}}\u003df(y)\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSince the above formula for \\( z(x,y) \\) has two arbitrary and independent functions, it is the general solution to the PDE.       "authorSolution": "\u003cp\u003e \\( u_{{xx}}-u_{t}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor this problem, guess that the solution is in the form \\( e^{{ax+bt}}\\, \\) . Plug the guess into the original PDE to find that:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( a^{2}-b\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \\( a\u003d\\pm {\\sqrt {b}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e Let \\( b\u003dc_{1} \\) , a constant.     {
      "authorSolution": "\\( u_{t}\u003dku_{{xx}}\\, \\)  \\( u(0,t)\u003d0\\, \\) \n\u003cbr\u003e \\( u(l,t)\u003d0\\, \\) \n\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003cbr\u003e \\( u(x,0)\u003df(x)\\, \\) \n\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003cbr\u003e \n\u003cp\u003eFirst separate variables and plug back into the original equation.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u(x,t)\u003dX(x)T(t)\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( XT\u0027\u003dkX\u0027\u0027T\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFind the separated boundary conditions (worry about the initial condition later).\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( X(0)\u003dX(l)\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow seperate the two functions on either side of the equation. The reasoning is that if the left side is a function of \\( t \\) and it is equal to the right side, which is a function of \\( x \\) , then both sides of the equation must be equal to a constant. It\u0027s good to keep higher derivatives on top of lower ones, and keep the \\( k \\) with \\( T(t) \\) . When setting the next part equal to a constant, \\( -\\lambda \\) works best.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( {\\frac {T\u0027}{kT}}\u003d{\\frac {X\u0027\u0027}{X}}\u003d-\\lambda \\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis gives the two solutions to the ODEs:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( T(t)\u003dc_{1}e^{{-\\lambda kt}}\\, \\) \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( X(x)\u003dc_{2}\\cos({\\sqrt {\\lambda }}x)+c_{3}{\\frac {\\sin({\\sqrt {\\lambda }}x)}{{\\sqrt {\\lambda }}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the solution of \\( X(x) \\) the extra square root of \\( \\lambda \\) was added in the denominator so that we won\u0027t have to make a special case for \\( \\lambda \u003d0\\, \\) , which does not give interesting solutions anyway.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUse the separated boundary conditions on the function \\( X(x) \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( X(0)\u003dc_{2}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( X(l)\u003dc_{3}{\\frac {\\sin({\\sqrt {\\lambda }}l)}{{\\sqrt {\\lambda }}}}\u003d0\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNothing interesting would come from letting \\( c_{3}\u003d0\\, \\) , so \\( \\lambda _{n}\u003d{\\frac {n^{2}\\pi ^{2}}{l^{2}}},\\,\\,\\,n\u003d1,2,3,...\\, \\) . \\( n\\neq 0\\, \\) because \\( \\lambda \\neq 0\\, \\) . These values of lambda are the eigenvalues. The eigenfunctions are \\( \\sin({\\frac {n\\pi x}{l}}),\\,\\,\\,n\u003d1,2,3,...\\, \\) .\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor each value of n, a solution is then\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u_{n}(x,t)\u003dc_{1}e^{{-\\lambda _{n}kt}}c_{3}{\\frac {\\sin({\\sqrt {\\lambda _{n}}}x)}{{\\sqrt {\\lambda _{n}}}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUsing the principle of superposition, the formal solution is the sum of all possible solutions:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u(x,t)\u003d\\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{\\infty }u_{n}(x,t)\u003d\\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{\\infty }A_{n}e^{{-\\lambda _{n}kt}}\\sin({\\frac {n\\pi x}{l}}),A_{n}\u003d{\\frac {c_{1}c_{3}}{{\\frac {n\\pi }{l}}}}\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe initial condition gives\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u(x,0)\u003df(x)\u003d\\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{\\infty }A_{n}\\sin({\\frac {n\\pi x}{l}})\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis series is the Fourier sine series of \\( f(x) \\) , so the coefficient is given by\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( A_{n}\u003d{\\frac {2}{l}}\\int _{0}^{l}f(x)\\sin({\\frac {n\\pi x}{l}})\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo the final answer is\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u(x,t)\u003d\\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{\\infty }A_{n}e^{{-\\left({\\frac {n\\pi }{l}}\\right)^{2}kt}}\\sin({\\frac {n\\pi x}{l}}),\\,\\,\\,A_{n}\u003d{\\frac {2}{l}}\\int _{0}^{l}f(x)\\sin({\\frac {n\\pi x}{l}})\\,dx\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOr just for fun: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \\( u(x,t)\u003d{\\frac {2}{l}}\\sum _{{n\u003d1}}^{\\infty }\\left[\\int _{0}^{l}f(\\xi )\\sin({\\frac {n\\pi \\xi }{l}})\\,d\\xi \\right]e^{{-\\left({\\frac {n\\pi }{l}}\\right)^{2}kt}}\\sin({\\frac {n\\pi x}{l}})\\, \\) \u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca rel\u003d\"nofollow\"\u003ePartial Differential Equations\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e \u003c/p\u003e",
